name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the interim report by Jan Olbrycht, Isabelle Thomas, Janusz Lewandowski, Gérard Deprez, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on the Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027 – Parliament’s position with a view to an agreement (A8—0358/2018) (2018/0166R(APP)).

name: Jan Olbrycht
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Today's debate concerns the future financial perspective after 2020. But it should be noted that for the European Parliament this debate is very important and not just a purely financial analysis. The European Parliament followed the European Commission's approach to future finances very closely, and it was therefore very important for us to put forward proposals for the future of finances by the President of the Commission and the famous five scenarios. We expected the Commission's proposal to be a political choice for one of these scenarios, all the more so because, in the previous perspective, the 2020 strategy was still the basis for calculations today, so we expected the calculations presented to be a consequence of the adoption of a specific model of the European Union. This has not happened either in the Commission, in the Council or in Parliament, so the discussion on the multiannual perspective has in fact become a discussion about the model of the European Union and today it is of a very special importance.  Moreover, the European Parliament presented its preliminary position in line with the Commission's previous positions in March 2018, ahead of the European Commission's position in May. We have read the European Commission's proposal very carefully and have stated that this proposal, in terms of the size of the budget, by the European Parliament is not acceptable, because we believe that this size of the budget will not allow the tasks to be carried out.  On the other hand, the European Parliament has expressly agreed with the European Commission on a number of elements proposed in the multiannual financial perspective, in its position, which was presented after the Presentation of the European Commission. Firstly, the European Parliament agreed that new tasks that will need to be financed after 2020 should be taken into account, i.e. matters relating to defence, border protection, the asylum system. The European Parliament has agreed, as regards the design of the future budget, on a new way of allocating policies, but also of funds, and has therefore taken this as a starting point for further discussion. The European Parliament also agreed that today's challenges facing the European Union mean that we need to increase spending on research, on exchange activities through Erasmus, on small and medium-sized enterprises, and on this parliament has put forward its proposals to increase spending. Parliament, on the other hand, does not agree with the financing of new tasks by reducing old, so-called traditional policies, even if we take into account the shortcomings of the post-Brexit situation.  Parliament presents its proposal in its report, showing this time the exact calculations and translation into the language of the specific financial solutions of our general position on the size of the budget, i.e. 1.3% of gross national income. This is the Starting Position of the European Parliament. The European Parliament is ready to negotiate, it is ready for swift action that could result in the completion of the work in due time.

name: Isabelle Thomas
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, remember, two years ago in this Chamber, after the British chose to leave us, we are swearing our hand on our hearts that we would never again give the breakers of Europe the opportunity to prevail. Since then, nothing, immobility, the division of states, the total lack of solidarity, the broken promises. So how can we be surprised that the same causes produce the same effects? The far right is 40% in France, Italy - the most federalist of us - has fallen into Europhobia and, in Germany, xenophobic nationalists have entered the Bundestag. Let us face it: the disintegration of the European Union is under way. Today, what is the Last Chance Commission proposing? A first-class burial, budget cuts that only dilute European ambition: minus 16% for the CAP, less 10% for cohesion, less 7% for the social fund, less 45% for funds for the poorest regions. The Commission has submitted to the least budgetary dictated by the governments, and this at the risk of the future of the Union and despite the speeches, such as that of Emmanuel Macron in this Chamber or the one that Angela Merkel will do later. It is therefore possible to extol the European merits with impunity in front of the cameras and to work underhand to cut off his food. Is it so difficult to listen to our fellow citizens? The messages are recurrent and clear. The field testimonies and the Eurobarometer surveys converge: the priorities expressed are the fight against poverty and exclusion, employment, social protection and public health, the climate emergency, migration. All these policies come at a cost and all these changes must be accompanied. The energy transition cannot be reduced to fuel taxes. Do you have to be deaf not to hear the messages of citizens? These political priorities must be re-edsary-like. The European budget must be taken out of its systemic undersizing. One comparison sums it all up: the US federal budget accounts for 22% of U.S. wealth, while the EU budget is painfully 1%. In Europe, austerity is indeed everywhere, it is not the preserve of national budgets, it also plagues the European Union budget. Today we have the opportunity to write another story, which is what we are proposing in this report. We have consulted all the sectoral committees of this Parliament, we have heard from the representatives of European civil society and I would like to thank all the teams who have made this possible. This is a first for the multi-year financial framework: we have built a rigorous, cost-effective counter-budget to meet the Commission. We demand the maintenance of the EU's pillars of agricultural policy and cohesion, we strengthen flagship programmes such as Erasmus or the Youth Employment Initiative, and we guarantee a target of 30% of EU spending on combating climate change. We are creating programmes against child poverty and to support workers in decarbonisation. By budgetary sincerity, as the real guardian of Article 311 of the Treaty, we defend a responsible European budget raised to 1.3% of the Union's wealth and the introduction of new own resources to finance it. Ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, we are the European Parliament, we are the democratic institution elected by direct universal suffrage, the legitimate voice of our citizens and their territories, we have a duty to give Europe the means to act in line with their expectations. Our hand must not tremble and, once is not customary, I will paraphrase President Juncker: the financial framework 2021-2027 is the budget of last chance for Europe. Give us this mandate and swear in this House not to agree to a budget that would defy European ambition. Let's dare the rebound, let's be the honor of Europe!

name: Janusz Lewandowski
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Multiannual budgets, the so-called financial framework, are a positive differentiator of the European budget. It is positive because they allow for predictable financing of multiannual programmes and investment programmes are by their very nature multiannual. Never – as is clear from my experience – is it ever business as usual. I remember, on the side of the European Parliament, that in 2004-2005 it was a historic enlargement of the European Union, but an extension to so-called net beneficiaries, without net contributors, and therefore it was a problem for net contributors. At the time I was designing the 2014-2020 budget, it was at a time of great economic crisis when Brussels was calling for a tightening of the belt, which also did not facilitate budget negotiations on the european budget side. Today, this condition is Brexit, but this is not a very big condition that threatens European budgets, because many capital cities, including the largest net contributor, Berlin, and the largest net beneficiary, Poland, declare the possibility of increasing their own contribution to the European budget. So that this will for these negotiations to be concluded before the European elections must be confirmed in the course of the agreements, in the transition from positioning countries – because that is easy; positioning the countries that are happening now, this is such a protocol of divergence, and this is an easy matter. The aim, on the other hand, is to move on to the phase of agreeing on the final draft, which is a much more difficult phase, namely finding a common position between the Member States and entering into negotiations with the European Parliament. Together with Gérard Deprez, I am responsible for the revenue side of the European budget. Here we have a paradox: this site has been heavily criticised for many years, and at the same time it has been very stable for many years – it has been unreformable since the late 1980s. The reason, of course, is the UK rebate and the unsusundliness to opt out of the UK rebate. This entailed various other privileges for Member States, mainly net contributors. At the moment, when we are already negotiating without The United Kingdom, it seems that we have some window of opportunity, that is, we have some opportunity to reform the income side as well, but this must be based on two iron rules. Firstly, the so-called fiscal sovereignty remains in national parliaments and cannot be compromised. Any amendment must be ratified by the national parliaments of all Member States. But there is a second principle: if we are introducing some of the European Union's so-called own resources – and there is a whole list of candidates – this must involve a reduction in the contribution from gross domestic product, that is, it must not mean an increase in the burden on the citizens of the European Union. Only on such a condition can the income side be reformed, including, of course, various other sources of income, including penalties, which should be included in the European budget. I think we have a chance this time, and this is clearly written and will be clearly voted on in the So-called Interim Report of the European Parliament: for us, the income side and the expenditure side is one package, that is one thing. Of course, we know very well that, in the case of the revenue side, the European Parliament has much less room to play than on the expenditure side.

name: Jean Arthuis
text: rapporteur, on behalf of Gérard Deprez. Madam President, Madam Minister, Commissioner, my dear colleagues, my colleague Gérard Deprez cannot be with us and I speak on his behalf. Our plenary will vote tomorrow on the negotiating position proposed by your Committee on Budgets. Our interim report reflects the vision of what the next post-2020 multi-year fiscal framework should be and its funding with new own resources. This report is the result of more than two years of work, of which the rapporteurs Jan Olbrycht and Isabelle Thomas for the MFF (multi-year financial framework), Gérard Deprez and Janusz Lewandowski for own resources, should be thanked and congratulated. This report presents the European Union's long-term budget and specifies, for each heading and for each programme, the amounts of the appropriations allocated. It is the culmination of our two previous resolutions voted on 14 March and 30 May of this year, respectively. By its vote, Parliament means its unity and willingness for the next negotiations with the Council and the ministers of the European Union. In view of our full preparation, I would like to regret that the Member States have made no significant progress in finding a common position. I trust the Austrian Presidency to activate the process and reach an agreement by the end of this year. By raising the overall spending ceiling for the multi-year financial framework to 1.3% of the gross national income of the 27 COUNTRIES of the European Union, Parliament is being reasonable.  It intends to take on new priorities: youth, with the tripling of appropriations for the Erasmus programme and the doubling of funding for the youth employment initiative, but also digital research, climate, defence and migration. Yes, the aim is to meet these new priorities, without cutting funding for agricultural and cohesion policies. Finally, and I welcome this, the interim report calls for identifying the measures that States are funding at the national level, without any real effectiveness in the face of the challenges of globalisation. Therefore, if it appears that these expenditures would be more effective by placing them in the European budget, we can imagine taking the European Union budget beyond, well beyond, 1.3% of gross national income (GNI), without increasing overall public expenditure in Europe. In other words, it is about starting to shape the budget of a world power.  With regard to the European Union's own resources, we must admit that the current system is extremely complex, unfair, non-transparent and totally incomprehensible to European citizens. The new system must result in a substantial reduction in direct contributions from Member States. The aim is to finally get out of the tyranny of the so-called 'rightful return', so contrary to the principle of solidarity and so contrary to the community spirit. It is clear that the provision of new resources should not in any way imply an increase in the tax burden on European taxpayers. As the United Kingdom prepares to leave the European Union, let us use this circumstance to dislocate, in the name of fairness, the maquis of rebates, rebates and other benefits granted in negotiations as clandestine as they are questionable. Ladies and gentlemen, it is time to tax the activities of the digital giants for the profits they make in Europe, to tax financial transactions as well. In any event, the resources thus collected will be recovered by the Member States and made available to the European Union budget. It is therefore not infringing on the tax prerogatives of states. The interim report on the post-2020 MFF and new own resources aims to consolidate a Europe that speaks to European citizens, a Europe that gives itself the means to meet their expectations, a Europe that prepares their future and protects them. We have yet to reach an agreement with the Council.

name: Karoline Edtstadler
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, first of all thank you very much to everyone for being present today as Parliament prepares its position on the multiannual financial framework (MFF). The MFF file is considered a top priority by this Presidency and the Council is working at full speed on the file.  Ministers discuss the issue every month when they meet in the General Affairs Council and experts meet every week to discuss the proposals in detail. No efforts are spared to make as much progress as possible before the end of the year. But as we dig deeper into the Commission proposals we also identify more and more elements that will require difficult discussions and, ultimately, difficult compromises.  This was obvious also yesterday when ministers had a substantial debate in the General Affairs Council on the MFF proposals. Yesterday, ministers identified by the Presidency some topics as key future ones and we have to look at this. To name just a few: many ministers intervened on the overall size and distribution of the budget; the weight of national contributions, the size and protection of national envelopes in cohesion, or the external convergence in agriculture. Those are not issues that will be easy to solve.  And let us not forget the necessity to achieve unanimity in the Council. So if you look at the number of issues on the table and their complexity, and if you take into account the overall political context of our work, it is increasingly clear that it will take time to finalise the Council position. The MFF is not only about numbers, because behind numbers we are talking about policies. That’s why these negotiations are an all-encompassing exercise and a highly political one. It is not a secret that some elements are so sensitive that they will require guidance from the highest level. This being said, work doesn’t stop in the Council. We are all very much aware that cooperation with Parliament will be essential to conclude this file. This is why the vote taking place this week in Parliament is very important and the interim report you will adopt I am sure will be looked at in detail by delegations.  This is also why the Presidency insists on keeping Parliament informed about the progress in the Council and organises exchanges of views regularly between the two institutions. In that spirit, yesterday evening my General Affairs Council colleague discussed with Parliament’s negotiating team the latest developments in the Council on this field.  This dialogue and our debate today are very important to make sure that we understand the position of one another and our respective constraints and expectations.  I hope I managed to convey the complexity of the discussions in the Council and the difficult choices that await Member States down the line. I hope you can take this back with you.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has had on the council. With today's interim report, Parliament defines its position on all the programmes and on the structure of the budgetary framework proposed by the Commission in May and June for the next decade. I would like to thank the rapporteurs, all the committees and the Committee on Budgets , with Mr Arthuis in particular – for the work behind it. If we take the timeframe from May this year to the present day, the Council and Parliament have made considerable progress. Parliament will vote tomorrow. The Council has already made intensive use of the last few weeks under the Bulgarian and Austrian Presidencies at working level and in the Council in general, and the negotiating box is practically ready. On the basis of this, the policy level can now begin to bring about results in the negotiations. Ladies and gentlemen, I am grateful that important horizontal issues are indisputable. Parliament and the Council accept the seven years as a timeframe. The seven chapters - the headings - and thus a visible policy are accepted by the Council and Parliament. We agree between the Commission and Parliament that new own resources are useful for broadening the revenue side and will have to discuss this in the coming weeks on the basis of various proposals.  The fact that the rule of law must be included in the budgetary framework is accepted by a majority of Parliament and the Council. The fact that we need a high degree of flexibility in order to respond promptly to new problems and tasks should, I believe, also be acceptable on the basis of the Commission's proposal from the Council and Parliament.  Who knows today what the challenges are for Europe 2026? A high degree of flexibility between the headings and programmes and the financial years therefore seems to me to be sensible and necessary, as in the midterm review and the reform adopted by Parliament and the Council a few years ago. The programmes are therefore accepted. There are considerations in Parliament for a few complementary programmes – the tourism programme, the structural change of coal regions. It is undisputed that we need to help on the road to a low-carbon future for Europe. The only question is this: should cohesion, research and general programmes be used to target the coal regions and co-finance their structural change, or is a specific programme more sensible, as proposed by Parliament's Committee on Industry? I believe that, having the horizontal issues, the seven headings, the classic programmes are largely indisputable, the crucial point is: what funding do the programmes need?  We have three main pillars: Pillar 1 – agricultural policy, Pillar 2 - cohesion policy, Pillar 3 – the addition of new programmes or growing programmes that represent the future and new tasks. We used to have agriculture and cohesion with 40% = 80% each in the budget framework, currently at around 70%. The Commission is proposing a moderate reduction to around 60% – 30% agricultural, 30% cohesion. These cuts – 5% in the agricultural sector and 6.3% in the cohesion sector – have been criticised. But I say to you quite frankly, even in the knowledge of the Council debate and the expectations of some Member States that the framework does not exceed 1.0% of the GNI, to believe that the British can go and bring cohesion and agriculture into the future without cuts seems to me to be very realistic – accepted as a starting point, but since we end up needing 27 Member States – unanimity – and Parliament must agree to this, Parliament must agree to this. , I would ask you to be somewhat flexible, not only in the budget itself, but also in politics, and to accept moderate cuts. When a wealthy uncle goes with the British, the gifts under the Christmas tree will no longer be chosen, but tend to be a little less or more efficient. The third pillar – doubling Erasmus+, increasing research, Horizon Europe, stabilisation, Connecting Europe or much more for neighbourhood and the world, for foreign policy, for our approach to combating reasons for flight – I believe that the third pillar – proposed by us with 34% – shows where Europe's added value exists if Europe invests jointly, across borders within the EU and across borders with our Mediterranean neighbours. , in the Maghreb, Sahel, Subsahel, Middle East or Western Balkans. So for me the crucial open point is: 1.3 - 1.0 – 1,114 and: When do we decide? The sooner, the better. The lesson of the current budgetary framework must be that whoever adopted the Execution rules, as it happened then, have been lost time in 2014 and 2015. Investments at European level will not be realised by this budget in the first and second years. That is why it should be possible to adopt it in 2019 – not in 2020, but in 2019. Since this is an election – your election, the European election – we would prefer us to continue to try everything to be ready by April next year. That would be the best option. The second best would be autumn next year, the worst would be autumn 2020. That is why the European Council of 13 and 14 December is of crucial importance. And our expectation to the European Council, our request, is for the European Council to take on the priority of Europe's budgetary framework alongside Brexit and migration, that is, the permanent issues. Early adoption could then be possible, provided that the Member States and the Council and Parliament are willing to compromise. Europe would then show that, with a stable budgetary basis, it can go into the next decade successfully and collectively.

name: Željana Zovko
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the DEVE committee. - Dear Chairman, at the outset, I would like to congratulate my colleagues on a well-prepared report that includes proposals as well as further steps to create a new Multiannual Financial Framework, which will take into account the UNITED KINGDOM's exit from the European Union. New Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027  it must reflect the Union's priorities, as well as propose mechanisms to mobilise available funds as effectively as necessary in the event of growing crises. The multiannual framework so far has proved inflexible and ineffective in responding to crises, and this could best be seen in the event of a migrant crisis affecting the European Union.  Likewise, taking into account the Union's priorities, and I think, including the Western Balkans, as well as the enlargement strategy published at the beginning of this year, it was expected that the Commission would increase funding for the IPU in its proposal, in order to assist candidate countries and potential candidates in advancing the rule of law, economic well-being and the functioning of institutions. This would help meet priorities and strategy. As this has not happened, I welcome the rapporteur's efforts to increase these funds, so that the Union's priorities can indeed be met in a timely manner with sufficient resources. In view of this, I will support the report.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which We have reached a broad consensus in the Committee on Trade: the Union's trade policy must become more visible in the multiannual financial framework, including in the titles. It has a far-reaching influence on national and international economic relations and on everyday life, on people's production and consumption. We want a new indicator of the success of coherent trade policy, namely its contribution to achieving the UN's 2030 sustainable development goals. To this end, we recommend that sufficient resources be made available to prepare an improved ex ante and ex post evaluation of agreements. The partnership programme must be maintained and, offensively, sufficient resources must be available to support civil society in partner countries. This is the only way to monitor the implementation of the agreements, in particular those relating to the protection of workers and the environment. We are concerned that this task could disappear from the proposed mega-instrument for external action. And yes, we would have liked the Committee on Budgets to take greater account of our work.

name: Inés Ayala Sender
text: rapporteur of the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. – Madam President, I would like to point out that the need, right now, for a previous strategy such as Europe 2020 makes us wonder from the Committee on Budgetary Control that just in order to assess and assess the results budget we do not have that fundamental basis for a sound strategy. That is, they no longer serve only the components and commit spending on the budget in a regular and legal way, and even with errors increasingly close to 2%, which we welcome, but we also need tangible results for the promises we continue to make in terms of socio-economic recovery and decent job creation. And the first error in budgetary control is to underbudget new and urgent ambitions. Hence the expenditures of migration, cooperative self-sufficiency in security and defence, the strengthening and Europeanisation of development cooperation or the fight against climate change, but also the fight against poverty and indebtedness of society and citizens, therefore need a budget counter-project such as today. And we also need those sources of own resources that eliminate the final marketing of the night from the long knives. We saloicat simplification, although we need fewer objectives and indicators, but clearer and more significant, as well as aligning the budget to legislative cycles and also measures to reduce the difference between commitments and payments.

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. Mr President, thanks to co-rapporteur, Mrs Ayala Sender for her contribution. The Committee on Budgetary Control has historically focused on the legality of spending. Fortunately, in recent years, there has also been an increasing focus on efficiency. The hundreds of billions of euros we spend here must also achieve a political goal. Spending the money is not for nothing. It's not about redistributing money. It is about achieving clear political goals. They must therefore be well defined and the results must be very easy to measure. I hope that both the European Commission and the Council, as well as the members of this House, will read the Court's reports carefully, because it says time and time again in every policy area that this efficiency is not good. Only last week, a very critical report was published on the common agricultural policy, as proposed by the European Commission. I'm glad we're going to green. But the way in which the Commission wants to green is with non-measurable targets, i.e. the money is spent, but the environmental objectives will not be met. So a call to the Commission on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control: look again very emphatically at the effectiveness, the achievement of the political goals.

name: Brando Benifei
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Multiannual Financial Framework measures the level of ambition and therefore the effectiveness of the Union's policies for the next seven years. I believe that we can no longer afford to set ourselves major objectives – I am thinking of agenda 2020 – and then not put the necessary resources into pursuing these objectives. If we continue along this path, we will frustrate the ambitions of our citizens, the expectations of our fellow European citizens, and we will do Europe a disse good.  That is why we must continue with work to increase resources for clear objectives. In the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, we need to increase the allocation of the European Social Fund plus in order to transform the European pillar of social rights into concrete actions. We must increase resources to combat youth unemployment. We must give greater support to local and regional authorities, direct support to meet the challenge of the social and working integration of refugees. We must put on the table the Guarantee for Children, a tool designed to break the disadvantage of more than 25 million children who are on the threshold of poverty and at risk of social exclusion. I am sure that the Council will be able to take our side in this battle and provide the Child Guarantee with the necessary resources. Children are the future of Europe. We hope for a unity of purpose from this point of view.

name: Ivo Belet
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Mr President, I would first and foremost like to thank the rapporteurs for this work, because it is ambitious. It is realistic, however, and it focuses on investments that bring real added value and which really shows the citizens of Europe that Europe can make a difference. Two examples: the Life Plus programme, which Parliament is calling for to be doubled. I think that's really necessary. And secondly, Just Energy Transition Fund, I think that is really necessary, also to prove to the people that Europe is also there to protect its citizens, 'to protect the citizens'. But there are, of course, also wishes from our committee, explicit questions on the health programme, Health Programme, to make it a full-fledged programme, given the revolutionary changes, digital e-health, cross-border evolutions in health care that are coming. Finally, those who are calling for Europe to be allowed to do with a smaller budget, with 27 Member States, who are erring when you see the challenges we face. You cannot loudly proclaim that Europe must protect its people and then cut the budget. That is why it is essential that we also make use of these own resources and make them a breaking point.

name: Dominique Riquet
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. Madam President, the Committee on Transport shares with the Commissioner the general remarks on the budget, but I would like, with regard to our specific subject, to make a few remarks and regrets. The interconnection mechanism for Europe, which was created by the Commission, represents an undeniable success which is at the heart of investment, but also of the single market, as the engine that irrigates it. It is also at the heart of a number of other problems, including environmental problems. I regret that its staffing has not been sufficient and I also regret that the transfer under centralised management of 20 billion, from the competitiveness funds, has not been accepted, which would have allowed, without cutting the European budget, to have better management of our resources. Everyone agrees - and I think the Commission is also - that centralised management is better than management that is not. Finally, the agencies we defend, because their tasks have increased considerably. On the other hand, their means have increased much less, while they have a central role. We should also highlight tourism, which deserves, as in the treaties, to finally have its place and to be accompanied by a clean budget line and not just projects. Madam President, we hope that these considerations will be taken into account.

name: Derek Vaughan
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. – Madam President, cohesion policy is the EU’s main investment tool. All our regions benefit from structural funds. Therefore, I would hope that all Members in the Chamber would oppose the suggested 10% cut for cohesion funds in the next MFF. Cohesion funds also provide good value. Every euro invested generates an extra EUR 2.40 of investment. Therefore, our report calls for a majority of funds – 61% – to go to less-developed regions, for all regions to continue receiving structural funds in the future, a reversal of cuts to Interreg, a reversal of the cuts to the co—financing rates, and of course further simplification – something we all call for. Finally, President, Commissioner and the Council member, I would urge you – and the committee would urge you – to get an agreement on the MFF as soon as possible to avoid delays in the implementation of further programmes.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the adoption of the Multiannual Financial Framework is a key moment in defining the direction of the Union for the following period.  For this reason, the MFF should, in our view, be linked to the political cycle of Parliament and the Commission, and it is necessary for the reform on the revenue side to be reflected in the expenditure in order to identify the policies and programmes that are a priority and have real added value at European level. Furthermore, it is unthinkable that Parliament should not be involved on an equal footing with the Council at all stages and aspects of negotiating, approving and revising the MFF, as the Treaties provide.  Finally, cross compliance clauses. The one on the Rule of Law, which is very delicate, must not and cannot become a political instrument in the hands of a party or a current of thought. Then what we suggest we study is related to the migration issue. The phenomenon has a dimension and roots that call into question the entire international community. That is precisely why the approach can only be intrinsically common and respectful of fundamental rights. Ladies and gentlemen, the Union's resilience is in danger of playing a role in this.

name: Iratxe García Pérez
text: draftser of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. – Madam President, the budget is the most powerful political instrument we have to make will a reality, and that is why incorporating the gender perspective into the next financial framework is a mandatory and essential issue.  And we also need to strike a balance between being able to ensure this cross-cutting but also implementing specific policy instruments on equality between men and women.  And that is why it is essential that when we talk about structural funds and regional policy, that when we talk about the common agricultural policy, that when we put in place cooperation policy instruments, we take into account the gender perspective.  But it is also essential, indispensable and mandatory that we be able to ensure specific instruments in the fight against gender-based violence, to incorporate specific measures for the reconciliation of family and work life; that we are aware that European policy needs this gender perspective to fulfil one of the fundamental values of the Union, which is equality between men and women.

name: President. –
text: Colleagues, there are three committees to which I will give the floor later in the debate, they are just not present at the moment, so I am going to move immediately to our speakers from the political groups.

name: José Manuel Fernandes
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Madam President, I would like to greet the Commissioner, the Representative of the Council, all colleagues and all colleagues. Parliament is united and there is a great heterogeneity here, even within each group. We have a majority position, we did our homework. The Council is not ready, Parliament is ready to start negotiations.  If the Council delays, there is a risk of the interruption of programmes such as Erasmus+, direct payments to farmers, support for small and medium-sized enterprises, support for researchers, innovation, support for regions, social cohesion, territorial cohesion. Madam Representative of the Council, Madam Representative of the Council, I have a question for the Representative of the Council, but she is not listening to the debate.

name: President. –
text: I think Minister Edtstadler is listening to the debate so do you want to put your question to her? Please wait, your microphone was not switched on. When I switch my microphone off then you can continue.

name: José Manuel Fernandes
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Madam Representative of the Council, do you not think that the European Union needs predictability, it needs stability and that only this can give confidence? Why is the Council good at proclaiming and bad at acting? We don't just need statements, we need action.  I have another question: do you think that the next Parliament will have a better majority in favour of the European Union and could it have a better agreement for the next Multiannual Financial Framework?  There's a point where I agree with you. He says that the Multiannual Financial Framework is not just figures and I ask him why they only care about the ceiling, which is a number. The only thing they care about is 1% of Gross National Income. Don't you think our methodology is more correct? What do we do? Addition method. What the other year? Each policy we give a value, we add up and, in the end, gave 1.3% of the Gross National Income. How do they do it? Subtraction method. The numbers: 1% and then distribute. Wrong methodology.  The European Union needs action and to respond to the challenges ahead, and we therefore defend the Multiannual Financial Framework adopted in this parliamentary term.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, this week the Lux Prize is missed and the protagonist of one of the films, which is a documentary, says a phrase that has been recorded to me: "They live in a parallel reality, building their lives outside the system, ignoring the circumstances, and do not see the moment when these circumstances change dramatically". And I think that's what's happening: that the circumstances of Europe and the world are changing. And some have not yet noticed, they still think about the budget as ten years ago. As if there were no new problems, as if there were no new needs, as if the scenario had not changed. And we're not there anymore. We are in the post-Brexit era, when, paradoxically, support for the European project has increased greatly. We are also at a time when nationalisms within and outside the Union are re-emerging, when fear overcomes hope. We are at a time when the scare of the economic crisis is going on, but its medium- and long-term effects are more present than ever. Inequality and climate change are the biggest challenges we face in the next decade. And the European Parliament does not want to ignore the circumstances, the compromises, or its responsibility. And that is why we have a proposal for the period 2021—2027 sensible, reasonable, argued and, above all, supported by a large majority of Members. Left, center and right; north and south; of founding countries and the last countries that joined this project. Because we believe in the European Union project; because what we are advocating are budgets for the Europe of the future, for innovative agriculture, to reduce inequalities between regions and between people, to make the Union a welcoming land, to be an example of the fight against climate change, to be a vanguard in research or cultural creation and to be a welcome land , too, the paradise of tax justice. We don't want a council to work out. If you're having trouble with unanimity, change that rule. We want a Council that provides solutions. Change your circumstances and work for an agreement in which everyone wins and not everyone loses.

name: Bernd Kölmel
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, Commissioner Oettinger, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. Thank you for your speech here today. With what you have said, you are speaking much more from the heart of our group than the colleagues from the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats and the other left-wing groups have said. And to your address, I would like to make it quite clear: if you don't know the destination, you can't find the way. A year and a half ago, President Juncker presented a White Paper outposing five scenarios, and he promised that we would discuss these five scenarios – ranging from limiting the EU's competences to establishing a quasi-own state – that we would discuss this possibility with the citizens of the EU and then represent the will of the citizens. I ask you: in which country has this discussion taken place comprehensively? In Germany, at least not. And if we do not know what the citizens want, then I cannot understand at all that some here claim that they are speaking for the majority of the citizens if we are now calling for a 30% increase in the budget. 30% more on the departure of the second largest net contributor: for me, this is without any basis, there is something wrong somewhere. Accordingly, I must also say that we would simply have to rethink the structure of the budget. There are good approaches here. For example, that we have one more budget line is fully in line with our opinion. We must also address new priorities accordingly, and we must provide these priorities with sufficient financial resources. But this also means that we keep checking: what are we giving out so far? And when we see that we still have an agricultural budget that is close to 30%, that is still far too much. The EU is not threatened by famine, but it is threatened by a traffic attack, especially in the big cities. We are threatened by being left behind in digitalisation. We are also threatened, still, by a migration crisis. We have to spend money here, but not on an agricultural budget that is simply oversized and ultimately overgrown. Cohesion policy is basically a good instrument, but we should limit it to the less developed regions. I think it is a contradiction in our view that we should also promote better developed regions through cohesion policy. Finally, the EU should not give the impression that, if it has enough money, it can solve all the citizens' problems. That is misleading. We should make it clear that subsidiarity, personal responsibility and good framework conditions are ultimately the key to a good EU. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I would like to thank Mr Kölmel for what he has said.  You are proposing massive cuts to agriculture. What are your goals to offer our young farmers a future that will ensure our food in this world. I care. Do you not think that robotics, machine learning and artificial intelligence should be endowed in agriculture with research, framework programmes, sensor technology? What are your objectives for healthy, future-oriented agriculture?

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure . Mr Rübig, thank you very much for this question. In agriculture, it will be clear that this is not a detached area in the EU that somehow has an eternity character and is sacrosanct. Of course, we cannot reduce the appropriations there from 100 to 0. But we need a controlled decline with the possibility of using these freed-up funds better, more efficiently in the future challenges that the EU must face. This is, of course, the area of research; I mentioned digitalisation, and so did migration. These points are clearly more important at the moment.

name: Nils Torvalds
text: On the other: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Perhaps in the context of this financial framework, we have seven or eight different challenges. The first concerns education, research and innovation. It turned out during the previous framework that when the EU added money, the Member States took the opportunity to remove money. It was therefore a zero-sum game that Europe did not really win much on. The second challenge concerns structural programmes. When we look at developments in eastern Central Europe – the countries that have lived under various forms of dictatorship for almost 80 years – and how their structural programmes work, we are faced with a suspicion that structural programmes are simply not properly sized. The third challenge will be our climate policy. We are facing major challenges there, and I suspect that we are already falling behind a little and that we are not keeping up with the pace that we should actually be keeping in relation to the Paris Agreement. We have major security challenges, both internal security and security in a world sometimes determined by Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin. It may therefore be that we need more security and rehabilitation. We have challenges relating to agricultural policy. We must have agricultural policy which also succeeds in putting emphasis on carbon dioxide being seized via agriculture. Finally, there is perhaps the greatest challenge in terms of what I call Margaret Thatcherism. Most Member States have only one thought, a Margaret Thatcher thought, in their head: 'I want my money back'. That is, of course, a disastrous stupidity. We must learn to think in other terms that this is about a European future, that it is about our common European challenges, and that is the way to go.

name: Jordi Solé
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the European Union is in trouble and our answer to this troubled situation must be built on political ambition and clear goals. But to achieve these goals we need resources and I would say we need more resources than those we have now. We need to manage better, sure, but we also need more money to tackle social and environmental challenges. Talking always about challenges and the need to deliver, but missing the opportunity to make more funds available, which is completely feasible, would be much too inconsistent. Parliament is proposing, through this report and previous reports, a stronger multiannual budget. It’s not 100% the kind of budget with the kind of priorities that my Group and I would like to see. It’s certainly not the Greens/EFA’s MFF but still, Parliament’s proposal is definitely better than the Commission’s proposal and it’s sending the Council a clear message: we are prepared for the negotiations, we did our homework, now it’s your turn and we will not accept further steps backwards.  For the many living in precarious conditions, they cannot wait. Social and regional inequalities cannot keep growing further. The climate and energy transition cannot wait. Progress on sustainable development cannot see more delays. Youngsters looking for more opportunities cannot wait. The defence of our core values cannot surrender to populists of all kinds wishing to undermine democracy and individual and collective freedoms. We also need to see substantial changes on the own resources side. There is only one way to increase the budget without Member States complaining about their increased contributions and their need to justify them to their citizens, and this is by having new own resources. We support the Commission’s proposal in this regard, but more concrete steps will have to be taken if the goal of 40% of Member States’ contributions is to be attained in the near future. We need responsible ambitions and a forward—looking MFF. We need to stick to our proposals, otherwise I’m afraid we won’t be able to support an MFF that is not up to the current challenges.

name: Younous Omarjee
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, where is Europe protecting? In the unprecedented cuts in funding for cohesion policy? In the reduction of the funds allocated to farmers? In the absence of an increase in the European Fund for Aid to the Most Deprived when, throughout Europe, poverty explodes? You have made choices, Commissioner, including the one, welcomed by arms dealers and going to war, to increase the defence budget thirtyfold. Our peoples want peace. For the environment and climate action, there will be just two billion euros more when it would have been much more ambitious to achieve the objectives of the Paris conference and really initiate the energy transition. All this is done within a framework of liberal reforms that will continue to fall throughout the Member States and in an austere framework that is maintained. Your budget is seven years of misfortune, seven more years of misfortune for the peoples of Europe.

name: Raymond Finch
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, you discuss in your long—term budget your current proposals to spend over EUR 1.2 trillion of taxpayers’ money across this period. That figure is almost impossible to comprehend and virtually every speaker I have heard this morning wants more. Britain, one of your largest contributors, is leaving the EU, and yet you decide to increase the amount of money you want to spend. It really makes no sense at all. You want to spend EUR 75 billion on EU administration, an increase of EUR 6 billion. You want to spend EUR 12 billion – a 22% increase – on the European Defence Fund that includes military mobility, collaborating in defence capabilities and further standardising defence industrial capacity. Where is this money coming from? You want to create an EU level common corporate tax base, an EU plastic tax and take revenues from the failed Emissions Trading scheme, amongst other sources.  The peoples of Europe do not want more powers handed to unaccountable EU institutions which will just fritter their money away. They do not want to create an armed and aggressive EU superstate and they do not want to give tax—raising powers to the EU. This is everything the Remain campaign in the British referendum told us that the EU was not. Your elections next year, in spite of all your moral propaganda that you’ll spend on it, will bring in hundreds of Eurosceptic MEPs precisely because of your hubris. Despite Brexit, unfortunately, Britain will still be contributing billions to you for possibly decades to come because our government has sold us out. We will make more concessions and I think this is what you’re banking on: getting more and more money from the poor benighted British taxpayers. You need to understand this must stop.

name: Marco Zanni
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, many of you welcome Parliament's position on the next Multiannual Financial Framework, calling it ambitious and courageous, but, in my opinion, this is a utopian nonsense, once again. We would all like endless resources for research, for farmers, for young people, for infrastructure, for work, but the reality is much more complex. There are few resources for the Eu ropean Union budget and we must bear in mind that those who actually put money in this budget, that is to say the Member States, and rightly ask for a strong say in this matter, have different priorities from our own. Instead, the European Parliament and the Commission want to force the times without considering that, from May, the next European Parliament and the next Commission could have different priorities. The aim is also to take powers away from the Member States, by lifting unanimity, by introducing new taxes, by calling them own resources, and by also linking the use of funds to absurd economic and political conditionalities. The mechanism of the European budget is as simple as it is perverse, especially for a net contributor country such as my own country. We give 100 every year to Brussels and we get back about 70, and 30 have already been lost, among other things, to fatten the costs of European bureaucracy for which austerity is never worth. And that 70 then we can only use it for certain expenses and for certain conditions. This will also have to change on the budget and the Multiannual Financial Framework from May.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI).
text: Madam President, this multiannual financial framework is also sealed by the priorities of European business groups, in competition with American, Chinese, etc., and their flexibility in crises expected of you, always at the expense of the people. Typical is the reduction in the funds of the common agricultural policy, which of course does not harm large but small farmers, the increased subsidisation of business groups, priority sectors in global competition and the neighbourhood policy spearheaded by the Union's intervention in Africa. What is mentioned in the road to labour rights, the European social pillar, and tackling extreme poverty means additional subsidisation of enterprises, generalisation of flexible employment and the work of pensioners to the death. The principle of unanimity is abolished, military expenditure and repression are strongly strengthened, as well as the European Union's intervention mechanisms, such as non-governmental organisations, to promote the Union's unpopular fundamental principles, and new unpopular taxes are planned to strengthen the Union's own resources. The bottom line is that new suffering awaits the people. The way out is their fight against the European Union and monopolies.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the EU has to take some very important decisions in a very short time. There is Brexit, the budget and also a lot of other regulations and laws regarding the horizontal policies, and all this should be done before the elections. Europe politically is not in a very good period, and I think that the budget is one of the most important decisions because it will show that Europe will go forward stronger and committed to supporting its citizens to have a better future. So Parliament will vote tomorrow on a very important text showing what it wants, which means supporting the new policies, but at the same time keeping the traditional policies at the level to be accepted by the Member States.  I think this is a new approach – to start from the bottom and not to distribute the money from the top – and I think it’s a good signal also for the European Council. Your responsibility, Commissioner, is to convince. I know it is very difficult in the European Council to have a decision before the elections.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this is a debate on the European budget but, as Magritte would say, this is not a debate on the European budget, it is a debate about what Europe we want. If we want a Europe that survives the existing one or a Europe that looks to the future, a Europe that is capable of growth, that is able to give the answers that citizens expect at work, on unemployment, on responses to young people, on research, on new transport, on social policies, on policies to combat climate change. The Europe that survives, on the other hand, is the europe that is sufficient for itself, the one that stands still, the One that has no ambitions and that has no courage, that stands still to watch a world that grows, that changes, that improves, but that is not able to give itself answers, instead it is only there to complain about what it is unable to do. This is the Europe that the Member States want, it is not the Europe that I think of, it is not the Europe that this European Parliament largely thinks of. The Europe we think of is the Europe that beats nationalism and beats sovereignty, which is so frightening, with politics and not with conferences or slogans. The Europe that beats nationalism and sovereignty puts so much policy into it for young people, for small and medium-sized enterprises, for municipalities, for our research bodies and for universities. The Europe that beats nationalism and sovereignty has its own resources, it has its own revenue, it has a tax that allows it to survive, and this is a tax that does not ask the Member States for money, that does not ask the citizens for money. It may seem like a miracle, it may seem that we have done a miracle, but it is not a miracle, it is simply concreteness, it is simply the ability to have a vision, it is simply fantasy in making politics and inventing things. Ask for money and ask for funding from those who do not pay taxes today, that is, the digital multinationals, the multinationals that have their headquarters in tax havens to those who produce great pollution, to those who put taxes on large financial transactions. This is the method of financing the policies we want for the future.  This is the Europe that does not survive, but which, through an arid instrument such as the budget, is capable of restoring a dream to its citizens, and this dream is a dream that starts from the great values of Europe and its roots.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The EU budget should correspond to, not limit, the political ambitions of the European Union. In accepting new priorities such as strengthening the protection of the Union's external borders, improving security and additional support for the countries of the south of the Union, it must be emphasised very strongly that this must not be done at the expense of the countries of Central and Eastern Europe, so that the proposal to cut cohesion policy spending by more than 20% for fourteen countries in this area of the European Union and the CAP, and in particular its second pillar, is simply unacceptable. After all, the objectives pursued by both policies have not lost their relevance, moreover, both policies, as has been proven many times, have high European added value and respond in part to new challenges such as climate protection and digitalisation. It should also be recalled that the original idea of the Cohesion Fund was to burden the countries of the old Union with contributions to this fund in view of their access to the markets of the newly adopted countries and, as a result, these countries have obtained and continue to receive huge economic and financial benefits, and therefore these burdens should continue to apply.  It is also necessary to offset direct cap subsidies between the old and the new Member States. This inequality lasts for fourteen years and will last at least two more years until the end of this financial perspective. Without this levelling, it can be considered that the agriculture of the countries of Central and Eastern Europe is discriminated against, and this is prohibited by the Treaties.

name: Jan Huitema (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I am very much in favour of spending more money on these issues, for those challenges that individual Member States cannot tackle alone, such as migration, climate, security and innovation. But as with any business, every association and also in the national budget, if you spend more money somewhere, you also have to look at where you can save money and at least be critical that the money is spent effectively. Here the European Parliament is completely missing out! On each budget line, proposed cuts are reversed or even more money is demanded. That doesn't give the voter confidence. It pretends to be a European money tree, instead of realising that the money is coming from the taxpayer. That is why I am also very much in favour of introducing the so-called European Salmon Standard. If you spend more money somewhere, you have to cut back somewhere else to rebalance the budget. However, the European Parliament is doing exactly the opposite. Before it wants to approve the new multiannual budget, it is calling for the introduction of new European taxes. This is not constructive. First, the European Parliament must show that it can handle European taxpayers' money carefully.

name: Helga Trüpel (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has With the new MFF, the multiannual financial framework, we are making a strategic decision for the next seven years of European policy, or we are not doing so. Chancellor Merkel will be here this afternoon, and The German Finance Minister, Mr Scholz, has made a very cautious proposal. It is also only 1% of GDP, while Commissioner Oettinger wants much more. And Parliament is, of course, even more ambitious when we ask for 1.3%. However, the Commission's 1.12% is also significantly more than what we had at the beginning of this financial programming period. And we also need this because we have such increased expenditure. I do not agree with the previous speaker. We must do more for education, for empowerment of young people, for solidarity in the European Union. That is why the European Solidarity Corps. However, we must also use our European budget for ecological transformation. Just think of the storms now in the south of France and Mallorca. We need to get away from the carbon industry, and we need to change our way of production and way of life. To do this, we also need the European budget. That is why 30% for climate protection projects. We need to invest more in research, we really need to pool resources in defence policy, because it is a profoundly European spirit to work together. In all these policy areas, we need – as we always say in English: a commitment for change. We want to use the European budget to convince the citizens that we are really delivering, because we are making a policy that benefits them. And where do we get the money from? We must also take it out of the digital tax. With the new American digital companies, we have the biggest monopolies we have ever had, which are so rich: Apple, Google, Facebook. And it is right to tax them appropriately and for this money to go to national and European budgets. Then we will have a win-win situation and we will finally be able to push through new priorities in the European budget.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, defence policy will go from around EUR 500 million to EUR 17 billion; security policy from EUR 1.9 billion to EUR 24 billion; and we will also move from a policy of development cooperation to a border outsourcing policy amounting to EUR 114 billion conditional and insolidary.  This is what marks the next multiannual financial framework when we make in practice and resources all the speeches we are hearing from the Commission and the Council. These are your priorities and your fears, to this day.  The MFF should be a medium-term plan, a plan that would serve to strengthen the political lines and principles we want to defend— which in my view should be equality, social justice, the fight against climate change or internal cohesion — and this can only be achieved with a flexible framework and not by putting a ceiling on own resources and expenditure , which snnchers us more and more towards a future of more austerity.  You know that 1.08% of the Commission or 1.3% of the European Parliament of Gross National Income is not sufficient and that, in a budget, it should generally be around 8% to avoid inequalities; a budget — that of the European Union — which should grow and should be complementary to national budgets and, of course, corrected by the per capita income of each Member State.  Clearly, it is not just about having more resources, but about spending them better and making decisions more democratic and therefore looking to the future of all.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD).
text: – It is not only the figures that are important today in the debate on the new multiannual financial framework. Much more important are the basic principles on which we must agree. One of them is the useful, rational and efficient use of funds. This is what must reduce social exclusion, unemployment, and promote economic breakthroughs. However, how do people explain why, at the end of each funding period, after billions of investments in many sectors of the economy, the risk of poverty in the European Union does not decrease, but becomes higher. I would like an explanation on another point. If funding for the Defence Fund is expected to increase compared to the previous period, does this mean that the European Union is building and financing its own army and abandoning the collective security organisation NATO? Madam President, I am categorically opposed to the new fund, which is named in the programme, perhaps as a beautiful name for the rights and values of justice, with the help of which, and almost two billion euros, is intended to defend and promote globalist ideas. I believe that farmers or ignalina are more needed to close those two billions.

name: André Elissen (ENF).
text: Mr President, the majority of the European Parliament envisions an even more absurd and expensive multianne financial framework than the Commission has previously proposed. The Netherlands is also being snuffed out the annual discount of more than 1 billion euros. The budget submitted by the Commission has already been met with a hard time, but the proposed amendments make it much worse. The budget would supposedly contain far too little money to solve all the problems imaginable in Europe and the world. But that is not the Union's task at all! What once began as economic cooperation has become a multi-headed monster that interferes in everything, at the expense of individual states that are often very capable of solving their own problems. Brussels bureaucrats really don't need that. I call on Parliament to stop implementing the UN's sustainable development goals, to stop pursuing an inclusive Europe, to stop the obsession with gender neutrality, to stop climate hysteria, to stop the Islamisation of Europe and to stop hugging non-Western immigrants.  Finally, I have tabled an amendment to maintain the Dutch rebate. The Netherlands has been paying billions of euros more than we receive for many years. The fact that it is considered to remove the annual rebate at all is ridiculous and unacceptable. Now is the time to make the most of the effort and to adjust the budget considerably. The failed EU project has cost far too much for decades. Stop this madness!

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union makes it an essential objective to ensure harmonious development, to reduce differences between regions and to reduce the underdevelopment of disadvantaged regions.  The Commission's proposal for a budget for the next seven years does not meet this expectation. Together, the three funds that make up cohesion would be reduced by 10%, and the Cohesion Fund itself by 45%. Parliament's report considers this unacceptable and seeks to restore the current level of resources. This should be supported. What is no longer is that the report would further undermine national sovereignty. The proposal for the Union's own resources does not take into account the fact that tax policy is a national competence. A qualified majority would be sufficient for the adoption of the budget in the Council, rather than a unanimous vote. On an issue of this weight, it is appropriate to maintain a full consensus.

name: Paul Rübig (PPE).
text: Madam President McGuinness, President-in-Office of the Council, Secretary of State Edtstadler, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his excellent work. The Commission's proposals are now on the table. I believe that, for us, it is a question of organising the timing correctly, and the December Council can clearly set the guidelines here, as the evaluation is in the final stage. So we can start the deal. I believe that setting goals and setting dates is the right way to move things forward. I expect A clear statement from Chancellor Merkel this afternoon on own resources. I believe that we should treat Internet companies and the Aunt Emma shop – the Greißler, as we say in Austria – equally in taxation. Co2 and cross-border levies could also be added to the European budget, thereby reducing the burden on national budgets. I believe that this would be a very crucial question of principle. I would also like to thank Mr Viotti, because Mr Viotti has very well stated that we should focus on the INVEST EU and coSME programmes, because, of course, small and medium-sized enterprises currently pay 80% of the tax in Europe and that is the basis for a good social policy. That is why the issue of the co-financing rate and the rule of law must also be put at the centre, because only that can save democracy in Europe.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Madam Minister, Europe has an appointment with history, Europe has an appointment with its history. At a time when other continental states are calling on us to speed up the organisation of living together - in the sense of 'making society together', you are proposing a budget at a discount, Commissioner. We do not agree, and you know it. No, it is not acceptable to reduce the cohesion budget at this very moment when our continent of 500 million Europeans must assert itself as a continent of balance on a world scale. No, it is not acceptable to reduce the budget of the Common Agricultural Policy, at a time when our food issues of biodiversity and human health have never been more pervasive. Yes, we need to address climate challenges, migration challenges, human health challenges, youth unemployment and peacekeeping, and energy issues. This MFF (multi-year financial framework) shows the limits of its structure linked to the 1% of the contribution of Member States and intergovernmentality. We urgently need to provide the European Union with its own resources and a real budget, to create a tax on the digital giants and on multinationals that are getting richer without relying on our European territories, to accept and accelerate the introduction of a tax on financial transactions, as well as the carbon tax at the borders. The future is at stake and, in the face of the lack of political courage of the Member States, the European Parliament must speak with one voice, a realistic, supportive and voluntary voice.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Brexit is a good opportunity for reformof the European budget. Unfortunately, it seems that we are missing this opportunity. For example, we might ask ourselves whether it is really necessary to put a third of the budget – about EUR 60 billion a year – into the agricultural sector. A 5% reduction is simply laughable. We are not after the war, when food was scarce, we are in 2018 and live in an abundance of food. The European Union is fighting against their waste.  Australia and New Zealand prove that it is possible to succeed even without subsidies. Moreover, the fact that subsidies are not the same for all countries is damaging agriculture in countries where subsidies are significantly lower. In my country, Slovakia, Slovak agriculture is being systematically and in the long term damaged and liquidated. On the other hand, we lack money for much more important things, such as.B. for the external protection of our border.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I’m a Central European, but I will not speak like one at the moment: I will not say whether Central Europe is treated well or badly. I want to say something different. The Multiannual Financial Framework is an opportunity: an opportunity to reform the policies and address the proper challenges in the right way. I am sure that Commissioner Oettinger has done a very good job. I’m not that sure about some of the Commissioners in terms of their ability to have reviewed and revised some of the policies and provided the right accent, so that was probably not an easy debate in the Commission.  At the same time, I need to address the Council and say that this is not about being forthcoming to the expectations of public opinion in terms of savings, without providing solid arguments as to why we are making this or that saving. We are talking about the need to implement policies to be competitive – politically and economically – on the world scene, and we are talking about new challenges. We want to finance it with the same budget. We need a serious revision and a serious review and we need political courage on the side of many of the Prime Ministers and Presidents. We are not talking about individual policies; we are talking about our abilities and our potential in the next six years. Some people in the Council are not getting that message. Parliament will be firm on these issues.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue—card question under Rules 162(8))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Mr Telička, you said that the Commission has done a good job, but we, the European Parliament, have come here with a different position. How do you explain that - the Commissioner has said today - that yes, the Commission agrees to cut itself from cohesion policies, from the common agricultural policy, from the money given to poorer areas, about what cohesion in the European Union and solidarity we are talking about, what European Union in which to have a similar standard of living, how will we be able to achieve the objectives of the Treaty?

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – Colleague, I was not talking about individual policies, I spoke about Commissioner Oettinger, and I stand by that. We have heard him here before, we heard him in the political group and I think that basically, the principles and also the aims that he has, I would subscribe to. What I would be critical of basically is the ability – and this is what I said of some of the individual Commissioners – and yes, whether it’s common agricultural policies, cohesion funding, whatever – I mean, there are other policies – I think that this is not just primarily as important as it is about cohesion, agriculture, it is across the spectrum, and this is the issue; the future of the European Union, our abilities, including these policies.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE).
text: – The budget debate is like describing an elephant – touching him by the foot and the tail and the limp – and, of course, we all love to emphasise precisely these special aspects. What matters, however, is another. And not so much whether we put thirty per cent into agricultural subsidies or twenty-five, it is important that agricultural subsidies are equal on the common market, not so that the Czech farmer receives less than That of Italy. More importantly, governments in the EU Council will finally get to the perception that the budget is based on own resources, own resources, I repeat own resources. This means that the working result of the Monti expert group must be realised. Otherwise, there is no point in this Parliament going here together and translating all the small official languages into all the major languages. Thank you!

name: Marie-Pierre Vieu (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, coincidentally on the agenda, Chancellor Merkel, the champion of budgetary rigour in Europe, will be here today in our premises, even as we discuss the multi-year financial framework. In Germany, these choices led to his popular disavowal and the rise of the far right. Tomorrow they will lead to the implosion of the European Union. It is therefore urgent that we consider another path, that of genuine European solidarity. However, the Commission is proposing a 5% reduction in budget here. This budget includes a 10% reduction for cohesion policy, while we have 87 million poor people, and 15% for the common agricultural policy. What about local agriculture? Finally, it renounces a real taxation on GAFA and remains timid on new resources. Here are my proposals: to coincide with the upcoming departure of Mrs Merkel with the abandonment of the dogma of austerity and to adopt a budget that meets social and environmental needs. It is at this price that we will roll back the xenophobic and authoritarian blazes.

name: Laura Agea (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is clear that we do not need more money, but better spent money. We are, of course, in favour of restoring funds for the common agricultural policy and also for social policies, but this must be done through cuts in administrative waste and programmes that are considered inefficient, for example the funds allocated to turkey. We must ensure that the European Social Fund can be used against poverty and unemployment, and we want it to provide resources and instruments for states that want to develop minimum income systems.  The proposal we are voting on is a dream book, beautiful but not feasible. We are talking about 200 billion more in total. The question is: who is going to put this EUR 200 billion? Certainly not own resources, as we would have us believe, because we obviously support their necessity and purpose, especially if we really manage to strike at circumvention, pollution and speculation, but it is also true that the European Court of Auditors has expressed doubts about their preparation in good time for the next multiannual budget and therefore we cannot support a proposal that more or less veiledly calls for greater contributions from the Italian citizens to the European budget.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Secretary of State, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her work on the work she has Last week, the Committee on Budgets adopted an MFF representing 1.3% of European GDP, which is EUR 1 324 billion at current prices and EUR 190 billion more than the Commission's proposal provided for.
