The Commission's proposal was already ambitious, as it provided for an increase in funding of 48 billion compared to the last MFF. The budget did not take into account the UK's exit as the second largest net contributor, nor did it start to streamline structures. Instead, new tasks and priorities are to be adopted, which represent added value for Europe. And that costs. The EU should focus more on issues such as external border protection, counter-terrorism or defence. Ten billion euros are estimated here every year. For research, innovation and digital, the new financial plan will be increased by 60% and for Erasmus+ by 50%. These are good and sensible priorities that lead to better protection of citizens and to more growth and employment. However, this focus must not automatically lead to a higher budget. On the contrary, flexibility is appropriate here and redeployments within the individual budget chapters are appropriate. 73% of the budget must not go to cohesion and agricultural policy, but to forward-looking areas. We need to rethink this, and it will therefore be difficult for the net contributors to decide on the budget.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab In the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture, we point out, inter alia, that the CAP plays an essential role in achieving the Union's key objectives, including food security, by providing consumers with high-quality, safe food at affordable prices and preserving the landscape and protecting the environment, as well as improving farmers' standard of living. What is it like with this living standards? Agricultural incomes account for only 50% of the average of other professional groups, and in addition half depend on CAP support, and some countries still have much lower subsidies. To this should be added still much worse living conditions in rural areas. As a result, the lack of young farmers is becoming increasingly acute. Farmers are facing a multiplicity of new tasks, often unrelated to agriculture, while the CAP budget is being systematically reduced.  We therefore call once again for the CAP budget to be maintained at least in real terms, given the fundamental role of this policy in ensuring the economic, environmental and social sustainability of European agriculture and the further development of rural areas and agriculture.

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Madam President, here in the European Parliament we want a future-oriented budget that will be able to respond to new challenges over the next few years.  Climate change, digital revolution, but also fight social inequality and reduce poverty. We need strong instruments to support economic and social cohesion in the European Union. This means a regional fund, financing infrastructure in the future; this means a social fund, implementing the Social Pillar everywhere. But it also means that in the euro area we have to introduce new instruments that do not yet exist and that end the economic and social divergence that has had enormous political costs. The euro area needs, like all monetary areas of the world, a banking union to ensure that investors, small and medium-sized enterprises have comparable conditions of access to credit to launch new projects and, above all, needs a euro area budget that supports future instruments, good public services, the focus on education and training , without which there is no future. The case Portuguese is highly illustrative. With the Socialist Government, we have changed economic policy, we have resumed employment growth, but we know full well that our effort can only take effect and ensure stronger prosperity if it is supported by this reform of the euro zone that can no longer be delayed.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8)).

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for the speech; it was very similar to some others – there was an interesting list of things that you wish to change. I was wondering, when you’ve gone into so much detail about the things you want to change – the new taxation, the new spending, the honourable ideas that you put forward from a socialist perspective – would you agree with me that to enact those things there is no other way to do it other than to diminish the power of national states and parliaments to such an extent that really the United States of Europe is the only way to enact your opinions and your ideas?

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – I don’t think that we need to reduce the power of national states. What we need to do is to strengthen this power by combining it with the power of the European Union in order to get the necessary resources to finance our budgets. A very good example is digital taxation. Yes, we need to use the full power of the European Union to impose on the big operators of the digital economy their duty to pay their taxes in the single market. Like that, we can finance better public services at national level. So Europe is a must for the power of national states and not a way to reduce it.

name: Nedzhmi Ali (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) translates the EU’s policy priorities in the budgetary means. We need a sufficient budget in order to achieve the objectives of the Union. Most important among them are sustainable economic growth; research and innovation; empowering young people; addressing the challenges of migration; strengthening the economic, social and territorial cohesion as well as security and defence; and also protecting the external borders and supporting the neighbouring countries. In this regard, the global level of the next MFF should be 1.3% of the EU Member States’ GNI. In this way, the Union will be able to meet emerging needs, challenges and new international commitments as well as to achieve the political objectives. MFF should support, with priority, the common agricultural and cohesion policy and oppose any radical cuts that would prevent the Union from closing the gap between the Member States. We support also the European Social Fund Plus and the integrated Youth Employment Initiative. For the next MFF, we need to increase accountability, simplification, transparency, performance-based budgeting and maintaining the necessary degree of flexibility. The new structure of MFF, with seven headings, is expected to ensure that these requirements are met.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, this proposal for a Multiannual Financial Framework, with cuts in the Common Agricultural Policy, cuts in Cohesion Policy and an increase in the headings of safety and defence, is no accident of course. It is part of a continuity line that comes from the past and eloquently reveals the genetic code of this European Union and its liberal and militaristic matrix.  This MFF proposal is not good for either Portugal or Europe. In addition to the cuts that include support for the outermost regions of the Azores and Madeira, we will have a strengthening of macroeconomic conditionality by tying Cohesion Policy to the European Semester. We are going to have a brutal increase in the co-financing of national states and we will also have a greater predominance of financial instruments. In other words, this proposal, far from compensating for the impacts of the Single Market and the policies of the euro on peripheral economies, will strengthen asymmetries between countries, strengthening the richest at the expense of the poorest. This is the solidarity of the European Union.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE).
text: – I am pleased that the European Parliament is now the most dynamic force on the post-2020 European Union budget. I therefore thank you very much to the rapporteurs, who have continued to work even in a situation where a Member State is not trying to reach a rapid agreement. I believe that it is necessary to require an increase in member states' contributions to 1.3% of gross national income, because, alongside the digital tax, it is the most effective way of implementing european joint programmes after Brexit. Next, maintaining cohesion and agricultural policy funding at least at the same level as it is today is essential. It would be very unfair to reduce the availability of these funds to those countries for which gross domestic product and direct payments are still lagging behind the European Union average. As is the case in the Baltic States, where, for example, infrastructure, although it is at the level of Italy, Spain, Greece, requires even more huge investments. In contrast, the fall in unemployment in our countries is due to people's exit to the most economically powerful Member States and to further increase the gross domestic product of already strong countries through their work. So this gap in the levels of development will only increase. Programmes such as Erasmus and Horizon, on the other hand, must clearly increase. Europe's competitiveness, opportunities for young people, our future scientific and innovation achievements depend on them. As far as security and border strengthening are concerned, there is no doubt that the solution here is only found at European level.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the current debate may seem to be about numbers and figures, but that is not the case. We are talking about the worker who is helping to relocate, having lost his job, thanks to the formation of the European Social Fund. We are talking about the student who can study abroad thanks to Erasmus. We are talking about the small business that manages to drive innovation and investment, thanks to COSME. So we are not talking about numbers, but about the lives of European citizens, and the citizens of Europe deserve an ambitious, strong budget adapted to the challenge of restoring Europe to solid growth.  That is why I am pleased that Parliament is still reiterating its message today: new policies need new resources from own resources. It is precisely the latter, in my opinion, that can prove decisive, such as the tax that affects the large multinationals of the web and others that could result from the abuses of globalisation. Let us give Europe the means to respond to the expectations of its citizens, without weighing on them yet.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I hear a lot of my colleagues here arguing what is lacking in the Commission proposal: somewhat more agriculture subsidies, support for youth employment, more regional funds, etc. All that is fine, but what I personally find lacking here is the answer to this question: what kind of Europe do we want to be? Should the EU do everything, or should we be big on the big things and small on the smaller things?  For my part, I want the EU to tackle the challenges that we have to tackle together: all the national challenges – migration, terrorism, the deepening of the single market, climate change, etc. But I also I want us to reflect on the lines that haven’t been effective at all – like the Globalisation Fund, for example. So the MFF should be a reflection on our priorities, not the ugly Christmas tree where everybody wants more and nobody wants less.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE).
text: Madam President, I believe - and we must all realise this - that the multiannual financial framework is a top issue for the European Union and for European citizens, which essentially determines the future and perspective of the European Union for years to come. It is clear what we want and what we want for Europe. It is clear to us that we need and demand a stronger, more social, more humane and more democratic European Union. A European Union based on young people and looking to the future. A European Union that respects and obliges member countries, but also acceding countries, to respect the rule of law and human rights. How do we do it? By strengthening policies for our young people, by strengthening Erasmus+, by giving employment to our young people, giving perspective, giving future, giving momentum. Giving perspective to small and medium-sized enterprises, strengthening our defence and security and strengthening policies on equality between men and women. It is inconceivable and unacceptable that the European Union is not yet reinforcing these policies and that there is inequality between men and women. But I think it is particularly important – because it was mentioned by the Commissioner but also by the European Council – that the rule of law and human rights need not only theoretical references. When we say that Europe is the European Union of the rule of law, we mean it. When there are candidate countries – such as Turkey – that do not respect human rights, that respect the rule of law, that invade Member States of the European Union – such as Cyprus – that challenge and offend sovereign rights and the EEZ, we must take measures and freeze the funds of the multiannual financial framework for Turkey.

name: John Howarth (S&D).
text: – Madam President, in the short time I have, I want to highlight two aspects of this report on the next seven—year budget. First of all, Europe needs to raise its game on investment and in science and research. Citizens in the EU want to see the Union addressing major public health issues. It is investment in research that will enable that to happen. These proposals are a step in the right direction, but they represent only a minimum investment. EUR 120 billion for Horizon Europe over seven years sounds like an awful lot of money, but remember that China invested twice as much as that in research last year alone. That is the context. If Europe is serious about competing, much more will need to be done. My second point is about climate. Although I would like to see the LIFE programme taking a higher share of the budget, I’m proud of the Parliament proposal to double funding in real terms. But, if we’re serious about meeting our Paris targets, we have to make fine words a reality, and that means we’re going to need a clear roadmap to get to that 30% spending target on climate action well before 2027.

name: Siegfried Mureşan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, we are going to discuss today – and then adopt together – a budget for the next seven years. Seven years is a long period of time in life and in budgetary terms. Many unexpected developments will occur during the next seven years, as they have also occurred during the current seven years. We needed to react to the migration and refugee crisis in a way which we did not foresee in 2013. This is why I fully support the proposal for more flexibility, put forward by Commissioner Ottinger and also presented and defended to us this morning. Flexibility will be important in the next seven years in order to respond to the unexpected developments which will occur. Also, predictability and stability is important. The beneficiaries of EU funds need to know that if something unexpected happens, their allocations will not be in danger – researchers, SMEs, Erasmus scholarships, farmers and the rural areas and the small communes which benefit from Cohesion Funds. So appropriate funding is also important. We have to tell the citizens of Europe that money spent through the EU budget is not money wasted but it’s money well spent, because very often it’s cheaper and more effective to spend money once at the level of the 27 Member States. Finally, I would just like to underline that the position which Parliament will adopt tomorrow will also contain EUR 500 million over the next seven years to defend the rule of law, the judiciary and human rights, which are fundamental EU values. It’s very good that Parliament proposes these EUR 500 million.

name: Karine Gloanec Maurin (S&D).
text: Madam President, defining the european Union's next multi-year financial framework is of course voting for a budget, but it is also drawing the outlines of a political ambition. However, the speeches follow one another to deplore it: the sustainability of the European Union has never been more threatened. The crisis of confidence expressed by our fellow Europeans leads us all to question ourselves. The ideological conflict that is now hitting our Union for the first time since the end of the Cold War obliges us to support an ambitious project and, therefore, a strengthened budget. Thus, I am particularly addressing the representative of the Presidency of the Council. It is time to get out of the Thatcherian posture of the States and properly address the challenges facing Europe, our Europe,. Of course, we must retain, at least at their current level, the European Union's historic solidarity policies, the common agricultural policy and the cohesion policy. We need to dedicate ambitious policies for youth, our research, our infrastructure. We need to be at the forefront of the transition to an economically and ecologically fairer world with clean resources and clean taxation. In the dynamics of the two co-reporters, whom I would once again like to thank for their tenacity, the Committee on Budgets is putting to the vote of the assembly a collective and collegial work, the fruit of an agreement reached between four political groups, it must be stressed.

name: Lambert van Nistelrooij (PPE).
text: Mr President, from the Committee on Regional Development, I would like to make three points. The first point is time is essential. Time. We need to make sure we learn from what happened last time. We were very late with the MFK and with the regulations. Those first years for cohesion policy (2015-2016) were largely lost years. So not just setting the budget is what our people ask for. The second point is the unprecedented reduction in the Cohesion Fund, 46%, partly because we have done well, because the economies have grown in the new Member States in particular, but still. We are now seeing a new EUR 10 billion being proposed from that fund to the Connecting Europe Facility. In the Committee on Regional Development, we have adopted a position: proportional, an appropriate share. We have said that 4 billion would be a responsible transfer and that any further transfer would be rejected. The third point I would like to make is the synergy between the various budget chapters, for example between research and development, the knowledge economy. We see that Horizon Europe, Horizon 2020 is used for 90% in particular in the old Member States. We cannot have a lopsided Europe. My proposal to conclude is to make better use of these cohesion funds to include this modern knowledge-based economy, including in the new Member States.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D).
text: – Mr President, two weeks ago, as part of the Euroscola project, I discussed with secondary school students in the mining region. The lives of several thousand families here depend on coal mining. Students understand very well that if we do not protect the environment, our air will no longer be breathable in this century. They asked me what would happen to mining families who lose their jobs. They must be reassured that we will allocate billions of euros to address the social, socio-economic and environmental consequences for those workers and their families who are adversely affected by the transition from coal to clean forms of energy. It is in our common interest that these people can get a corresponding job. I promised them that the European Union would help to solve this problem.

name: Andrey Novakov (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to start by breaking apart one urban legend – that there are net payers and net beneficiaries in this MFF. From my point of view, there are only net winners, and the cohesion policy is a very pure example of how everyone could benefit from EU funding. Recently, we celebrated one century after the end of World War I, during which you had to fight with your neighbours because of patriotism. Today, patriotism demands that you collaborate with your neighbour to understand each other and work together. Therefore, having us here is this room is already the beginning, but the real success is if we achieve together. Our ambition is EUR 1.3 trillion for the next seven years, and Parliament is ready to work on that to have the decision. Is the European Council ready for these negotiations? Let me remind you that we have an obligation to our citizens to have the decisions in the next six months – obliged not by regulation but morally.

name: Γιώργος Γραμματικάκης (S&D).
text: Mr President, at the Paris Climate Conference, the European Union was the force that led the global community to a much-needed agreement. But now revolutionary policies are needed to implement it. I think we need to devote at least 30% of the next budget to climate action in order to give the necessary impetus for a shift to a sustainable economy. We also need to create a genuine revenue system for the Union, based on the polluter pays principle, not only for those who pollute the environment and burden the climate but also for those who do not contribute what is theirs. And, of course, at the same time to reduce the taxation of labour, which currently disproportionately supports state budgets. These policies will have a great consequence. They can breathe new life into the European construction and become our new common vision, which we have been looking for so anxiously in recent years in the face of populism and the crisis.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE).
text: – I would like to summarise my position briefly on three points. Firstly, it is completely unacceptable that the next seven-year framework budget does not have at least as much funding for cohesion policy, regional development and the common agricultural policy as in the current seven-year period. This objective can be achieved without problems if the member states' budgetary contribution reaches 1.3% of their gross national income, which is what Parliament's proposal relates to. I ask everyone for their support. I will only quietly note that the institutions that talk about strengthening European powers and on a federal Europe – see Commission, see some Member States – are the ones who least want this common European effort. Secondly, it is unacceptable that central European countries, such as my country, which make good use of regional development resources, should Hungary the loser of the next seven-year framework budget.  Last but not least, a fictional idea based on all sorts of subjective aspects, so-called rule of law... (the President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Peter Jahr
text: Rapporteur of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Three brief observations. Firstly, I am glad that we only argue every seven years about the european Union's financial resources; sometimes it is more like the dance around the golden calf. Secondly, whoever orders should also pay. The question is: what has the European Parliament done? The European Parliament has done nothing but take up the wishes of the Member States, which are: no cuts in the agricultural budget, no cuts in the cohesion fund, more migration and defence policy, and now we have to talk together about funding.  Thirdly, ladies and gentlemen of the European Council, you see Parliament's decision as a powerful impetus for negotiations. Let us finally start serious financing negotiations. Parliament is ready, the Commissioner for Finance, Mr Oettinger, is ready. What is still missing is the serious willingness of the Member States. Now comes the time for serious work: no more Sunday speeches, serious work. Citizens have a right to a stable European budget.

name: Jerzy Buzek
text: draft opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I have only one point on behalf of the ITRE Committee that I would like to present to you, but I think it is important. Namely, we want broad support for our climate package, but there are regions in the European Union whose citizens will pay a lot for our energy transition. These are those regions (there are as many as 41) that have been very connected and are very coal-related, and it is necessary to show the citizens of these regions that the European Union is able to help them in a difficult situation. These are tens of millions of people in twelve different European countries, such as Romania, Slovakia, Germany, Spain. ITRE voted by a large majority on the transformation programme, it must be supported in our plenary vote, the Committee on Budgets has done the same. I still wanted to appeal to the Commissioner (thank you for your support) to prepare a proposal ....  (The President has received the speaker's vote)

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – Mr President! As the European Parliament's permanent rapporteur for Erasmus+, I would like to express my sincere thanks to my colleagues for the considerate decision, which is support for a threefold increase in the erasmus+ programme budget. Tomorrow's decision on the MFF will not mean a new vision of Europe, but will be important because it will allow material conditions for further development, a fairer sharing of burdens in Europe, that is, without privileges and so on. It will also constitute an important requirement for additional own resources for the European Union. Erasmus+ is one of Europe's most successful programmes, it is of real added value. Thank you, Commissioner, for mentioning this. The potential of this programme is much greater than we are able to finance, so there is still too little money for Erasmus+. The success rate in the youth field is extremely low. Remember that erasmus+ benefits not only from participating, but also universities, local communities, and given that Erasmus is much more competitive in society, including the economy.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the establishment of a new financial framework must be based on the current situation, starting from the existing situation: what happened to Europe, we have more cohesion, we have better connectivity, we have more jobs, we have research, innovation in the global market. That's how I think they're always setting a budget, whether we're talking about family, companionship, country and Europe. However, we must take this framework into account, and I believe that the Council must learn once and for all to take into account the resolution, Parliament's proposal, because, in the end, we represent the citizens. And if the Council does not take into account the proposal that we have made here in this report to increase budgets in these directions that we have listed, we will not reach a united Europe. Europe is at a crossroads and will also depend very much on this multiannual financial framework, how we can do it intelligently to keep Europe together, not to discriminate, not to have second-rate countries, to have no second-rate citizens, to have equal subsidies from farmers and to have all budgets based on social equity.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I’ve listened with real interest to this debate. It’s been a fascinating cross between some people who wish to close down some of the spending, and other people who have a massive wish list of ideas – increased spending, increased government control from this level, and an enormous increase in defence spending, which is extraordinary for an organisation which was supposed to be about trade at one point. This increase in defence spending is incredible and unprecedented, but all of the increases, all of the demands for more – much of it a good-natured and good-hearted effort to try and improve people’s lives – misses the point. At some point you will be losing the money from the UK – at some point when Ms May finally gets around to it – but there’s an ever decreasing cake, and yet there is an ever increasing sense of ambitions, desires and wishes to spend. Surely, for any organisation to succeed, there has to be a rationalisation and understanding that sooner or later you run out of taxpayers’ money.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In short, both the Commission's proposal and Parliament's proposal must be rejected. In total, the Commission intends to spend 217.4 billion more, that is to say, from the Member States. This is slightly more than the annual turnover of the Volkswagen Group in 2016, and it is known to be the largest car manufacturer in the world. We are losing The United Kingdom, a large net contributor, we want to increase and extend the tasks, and then we are so brazen and say that the share of the gross national income of all states in contributions will be reduced. But obviously it is even more audacity when the rapporteurs propose an amount of 431.7 billion – almost twice as much. One could really laugh at it if it were not sad and serious that in the end the net contributors, including my own country, Austria, would have to bear these numbers games.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, firstly, I think it’s absolutely vital that all Member States commit to a higher budget. Many are prepared to do so, but some aren’t. That is the David Cameron line. David Cameron – we saw where he finished up.  I would appeal to all Member States to increase the budget because it’s quite obvious that there is added value at European level in terms of climate change, in terms of research. If you do research at European level you have a higher quality and it saves an awful lot of money that would be spent in 27 Member States trying to do the same research. So, from that point of view, it’s absolutely vital that we have the budget to do what we can do better for citizens than we can at Member State level.  Erasmus+ has been mentioned. That’s one of the best programmes ever introduced. Thousands of students benefit from it. They get a wider perspective on European life, but we need a bigger budget so that more students can take part in it.  We have the same situation in relation to defence – not a huge problem for my country, but for other countries it is. And, of course, for agriculture, CAP, we talked about reductions – it is not sensible.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D).
text: Mr President, the multiannual financial framework concerns the future of the European Union and almost everyone agrees on this. The future of the European Union is its citizens and especially young people. But when, ladies and gentlemen, there are cuts in social benefits and policies and cuts in programmes for young people, we are not convinced that we are really aiming for the convergence of prosperity within the European Union for all citizens. When, for example, it has long sought to set macroeconomic criteria for access to those Member States most in need of the Cohesion Funds, then it is not convergence that we are aiming for, but simply stroking the ears of citizens and pretending. When we talk about the rule of law and Turkey violates the occupation of Cyprus and enjoys European funds, then we are just hypocrites.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I, like the report we will vote on tomorrow, want an ambitious financial framework which will provide the means for the European Union to achieve its objectives and face the important challenges before it, and the Commission, in its proposal, does not provide sufficient means. I, in particular, do not want a change in cohesion policy or the common agricultural and fisheries policies. I know brexit means fewer resources, but I also know that we live in times of populism and a rise of anti-European forces. We cannot weaken cohesion policy or agriculture and fisheries policies and thus give pretexts, arguments, to those who want to attack the Union. I would also like to underline a very specific aspect. The problem of demographic decline, which already affects many regions of Europe, as Commissioner Oettinger knows. Among them, my own land, Galicia, and other regions of Spain. The demographic winter is already a serious European problem, and we need European budgets to help meet this serious challenge.

name: Răzvan Popa (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the European Parliament, as the direct representative of the citizens of the European Union, has an obligation to ensure that the future budget meets the development objectives of the Member States. The Union's financial policy can adapt and must adapt to realities, but it cannot be one that abandons the fundamental objectives of the European Union. Parliament must defend those programmes through which the Union has so far helped to develop the Member States, primarily cohesion policy and the common agricultural policy. We must not, of course, forget the needs for education, defence, research, infrastructure, reducing youth unemployment and support for SMEs. However, we must not be afraid to ask for concrete things, for example, to ask large companies to pay taxes where they produce their profits. Member States are a market for these companies and only properly paying taxes can show that these companies comply with what they are offered. The discussion is not about the States, but about the whole of the European Union, the economic and social consolidation of each of the Member States means the economic and social consolidation of... (The President has withdrawn the speaker's word)

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE).
text: – Mr President! The decision always has its price, most often related to money. The MFF will set out guidelines on the amount and use of European money after 2020, knowing that the European Union is leaving the second largest net contributor.  Europe and the euro must become stronger, and we must strengthen monetary and economic policy. It will be necessary to decide as soon as possible how much the Member States' contribution will be and what will represent the european budget's own resources. The objectives ahead will have to be achieved, so it will be necessary to provide sufficient resources in areas relevant to our future. We must promote research and innovation in order to strengthen the competitiveness of the European economy and jobs, invest in cohesion, in education and in young people, and, in particular, to invest in strengthening security so that we can face terrorist threats and migrant challenges. It is not wise to weaken the foundations of the house, so we must maintain traditional programs.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: Mr President, by prioritising the priorities of the new 2020-2027 budget, I would like to dwell on tackling climate change as our first priority, because it concerns the protection of people. I call today on Commissioner Oettinger and all colleagues here in the European Parliament to support together the proposal to create the Fair Energy Transition Fund with a budget of EUR 4.8 billion. It concerns areas that depend on coal. In my own country, Greece, is the region of Western Macedonia and the region of Megalopolis. Workers depend on lignite deposits. Societies depend on lignite deposits. We must immediately send a very strong signal that gradual de-dependence on coal, in addition to being essential for people's lives, will be done without leaving unemployed people behind and without excluding anyone whose job today depends on coal. It will be done fairly and done with the support of the European Union.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I had the good fortune of chairing most of the debate this morning, and it was fascinating to hear the different views. I have to say, from both the Council and Commission, you didn’t spare us the reality of how difficult this debate is, but I’m going to speak specifically to those who criticise spending on agriculture – those who feel that we have lots of food and no worries. The truth is we have lots of food, and you perhaps have no worries because we have a common agricultural policy and we take food security for granted. There are many fine words spoken in this Chamber about a living countryside and looking after the environment and climate, and you know that will take resources, and therefore I absolutely reject cuts to the agriculture budget, specifically because of those extra challenges but in particular because the Chair of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, Mr Siekierski, made this point: the incomes for our farmers are much lower than the incomes of others. So let’s be careful how we cut and where we cut. Let us have an adequate budget for agriculture.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: - Dear Chairman, we show clearly what we want to achieve in the European Union through the multiannual budgetary framework.  One of the main objectives is to reduce the differences in development, i.e. the underdevelopment of the Member States and to achieve the best possible living conditions for all citizens in the European Union. This is why the European Commission's proposal really contains one paradox: on the one hand, competitiveness programmes are significantly increasing, the most benefiting of which are the most developed and competitive Member States, while cohesion policy is decreasing by as much as 11% and the Agricultural and Rural Development Fund by as much as 28%, in conditions when we are all saying that villages are disappearing and that there is a way to restore life to these regions.   So this position of the European Parliament is very clear, we do not want reductions in these two policies because our goal is the uniform development of all corners of the European Union.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. This week is a budget week. On Friday, we will try to adopt the 2019 budget together with your colleagues from the Committee on Budgets and the Council and the Council Presidents. But the budgetary structure for the next decade is more far-reaching and important. I am grateful that tomorrow's vote, on the basis of today's speeches, will be a broad majority, a very broad majority in favour of your report and therefore of your positions on all the programmes and on all the clusters and all the headings of the Commission's proposal. Parliament is thus in a position to start negotiations at political level with the Council and with the support of the Commission. I am grateful that a few Members have remained stubbornly here. I would like to respond to all the speeches. But it was precisely from this side, where Mr Obermayr accused me of having made a brazen budget proposal – he had hardly separated his speech, that he was gone. I see that you are back: good morning, Mr Obermayr. Otherwise, however, we have only received criticism from colleagues who are no longer present.  What is it all about? We do not want a superstate of Europe. At 1.3%, you cannot finance a superstate. Of the EUR 100 generated by a citizen with handwork, headwork and investment, levies, fees and contributions – an average of EUR 50 in Europe – are taken from him, which is, on average, the national quota in Europe. Of the 50 euros, one euro has come to Europe so far. There are 49 in Paris, Vienna, Berlin, Rome, the regions, the municipalities, the social security systems. One euro out of fifty. The discourse of the next few weeks will be: whether it should be a 1.00 euro or 1.30 euros or 1.114 euros. In fact, it is a manageable dimension in which the capacity to act and the will to unify Europe must prove themselves.  If we do not agree, the winners would be autocrats in Ankara and Moscow and other capital systems such as China. I remind everyone of this. We must reach agreement – you and the Council, all 27 Member States: Foreign Ministers, Finance Ministers, Heads of Government and also national parliaments, which are behind these governments. I therefore deliberately call on you all: let us enter into the discussions with the aim of reaching agreement, with a willingness to be flexible and also to be realistic. I cannot imagine from all the Council meetings in which I have attended that the starting position, 1.3%, will also be the result. As a starting point, I think your report is very effective, very good. But it will not be the result. As the Commission, we are ready to make changes. I am not saying that my proposal will be the result. Optimizing it, simplifying it, changing it is your right and your duty. We are happy to go down this road, together with the Council. We are told that the next budget framework is 30% higher in nominal terms than the current budgetary framework, and that is true: it is up to 30% higher in nominal terms. Why is this the case?  If you compare a 2014 budget framework with the 2021 ff., we have seven years of inflation – automatically increasing 12 to 14% in nominal terms and 0 in real terms. If we compare gross national income in 2014 with that of the next decade, on average, more than 2% increases are added. This means that in our budget framework alone we have a nominal increase of 26%, without one euro being left with us in real terms. Brexit: For some Member States, the elimination of rebates, which I think is logical, and new tasks lead to a 30% increase in nominal terms, very, very marginal in real terms.  Now comes the crucial point: I do not want to combine defence and an army at European level with the budgetary framework. But it turns out that defence research and procurement of equipment can be more efficient in the European team. When it has been said here that the money comes from the Member States – that is true, 70% comes from the Member States; no, it comes from the citizen and the taxpayer, because the Member State collects it 100% from its citizens. We can demonstrate that if defence research is done together at European level, it will be cheaper and cheaper for the taxpayer to procure defence industry together. The taxpayer saves money. We can get the same devices cheaper at European level by means of tenders than 27 national silos ever separated from them. In research, the same case. We have three objectives: 0.7% for development aid, 2% for those who are NATO members, for defence – and 3% for research and innovation. This is why expenditure on Horizon Europe, Erasmus+ or the joint defence research or for Horizon Europe, all expenditure, investment to achieve the 0.7%, 2% and 3% target. This is particularly true in "Neighbourhood and the World" and Africa. In other words, we must make it clear to the citizen that investing at European level does not mean spending more money, it means investing more efficiently and more cost-effectively. I admit one point: anyone who conducts European defence research is changing the structure of competence saver a bit, shifting competence from Paris, Vienna, Rome, Berlin to Brussels. So it could be a question of power. But it would be cheaper for taxpayers to conduct European research, to be European in Africa, and also to make European investments in defence. This has nothing to do with the superstate. One final point. We spend less than 7% on administration, 6% to 7%. My request is that if we want good administration – in Parliament, the Council, the Commission and the other institutions – then we should not continue to cut the lawnmower at heading 7. We need a qualified, good civil service, and we have already, in fact, achieved a high level of efficiency in our services in all the European institutions. I look forward to the discussions in the coming weeks, and I look forward to seeing how and whether the European Council on 14 December will take up Parliament's ball tomorrow and the Commission's proposal of May and June and make this a priority. On the way to the European elections, the Union no longer has many great chances of showing that it is capable of action. Brexit can only reduce the damage. Migration will not be the big solution. A budgetary framework for the next decade could be a bitter but low-hanging fruit as a demonstration of europe's capacity for action, good governance.

name: Karoline Edtstadler
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the House and the Commissioner for their remarks and comments. I would also like to use this opportunity to thank Parliament’s negotiating team and all of you for the work put into preparing the interim report. On our side, we will continue our hard work to advance the file as much as possible before the end of the year. As you may know – and this has already been mentioned – President Tusk has proposed that leaders have a substantial discussion on the MFF at the December European Council. To feed into the discussion, the Presidency will prepare a substantial progress report on the work carried out since the Commission presented its proposal.  This shows – I say to Mr Fernandes, because he addressed his words to me – that the Austrian Presidency has set, and still sets, a lot of actions. I fully second what you and some others said, namely that we need actions, not proclamations. That’s exactly what we are trying to do and what we will continue doing during the next weeks. We hope that the substantial progress report will constitute useful background for the leaders’ debate in December. We are very well aware of the situation: that it is a crucial moment for the future of the European Union and that now is the time to set the course for a prosperous future of the Union. However, to realise that, we need all of you to take action. We need the strong political will of all players. I already mentioned at the beginning it will be a difficult discussion, and there will be the need for difficult compromises in the end. We also hope that the progress we made on programmes, but also on the negotiating boxes will serve as a good basis for our Romanian colleagues when they take over the file in January. Let me conclude by saying that I am convinced that this debate was very valuable. Even so, as the Commissioner mentioned, it won’t be the solution, but it helped to us to understand one another better. I think we can make a lot more progress by the end of the year.

name: Jan Olbrycht
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking mr Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. The debate we have had clearly shows that talking about the MFF, about the multiannual financial perspective, is not really an accounting conversation. This is a discussion on the various policies of the European Union and this discussion will continue in the discussions on legislative texts. This shows that even if there are differences of opinion within parliament, we believe that the MFF is an extremely important course of action in the coming months and years. Secondly, this discussion has also shown that we must be interested not only in what is the task of the European Union, but in what is happening in the European Union. What is important to us at that time is what is happening in the Member States and what money is being spent on individual policies within the Member States, as the Commissioner has said. This needs to be added. It is necessary to add what the Member States are spending, plus what is in the Budget of the European Union. This cannot be separated. The third point – and Here I am turning to the Council – is the fundamental question, which is, even after this debate, whether the budget is intended to reflect a certain political line, or is the political line a reflection of the budget? What are we discussing? Are we discussing what we want to achieve and how much it will cost, or are we discussing how much we will give and what can we make of it? It seems to me that this debate has made it very clear that parliament believes that the budget should be a reflection of political ambitions. Lastly, we have also put some new elements into our proposal, such as money for NGOs, in order to defend European values. The value programme is one of the elements that needs to be developed. There are more such elements, and Parliament will defend this.

name: Isabelle Thomas
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank my colleagues for their support and take this opportunity to thank my co-minister Jan Olbricht for our fruitful and caring collaboration. Ladies and gentlemen, let me address our institutional partners and, above all, the Commission. Certainly, Mrs Gardiazabal Rubial is right, there are parallel worlds. What realism are you talking about, Mr Oettinger, the Council's realism or the real life realism of the people? How can we talk about gifts and Christmas trees, when we are talking about the future of our young people, living conditions, research and suffering too. Therefore, you acknowledge that you have built your budget from the 1% acceptable by the Council, but this is totally contrary - forgive me - to Article 311 of the Treaty. Who is the guardian of the treaty here? Finally, stop playing with the famous 1.14%. No, Mr Oettinger, your proposal, since it includes the development fund, is 1.08 per cent. Secondly, Madam Minister, this Assembly, as you know, is responsible and fully understands that governments refuse to increase their national contributions. That's a good thing, we don't want it. We do not want to increase national contributions. We want clean resources, not additional taxes for our citizens. Moreover, who is constantly increasing the competences of the European Union here? More often the Council than Parliament. So, please! On the other hand, don't hide behind the little finger of unanimity. You, too, have article 312, paragraph 2, in the treaty, which allows you to use the bridge clause to move to the logic of the majority and then even unanimously. Compromise is for that. Finally, I am speaking to both the Commission and the Minister, do you seriously think that a 1.3% multi-year financial framework is unreasonable and unattainable? For my part, I think that is the minimum acceptable.

name: Janusz Lewandowski
text: Rapporteur. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The financial perspective is a vision of the European Union, our common future, dressed in numbers. This arrangement is the most serious test of the political will to be together, because political declarations or the so-called Sonntagsreden are not enough here. We need to find an agreement unanimously and explain it to taxpayers. Whatever happens on the Council's side – and progress here is not very encouraging – it is good that Parliament takes a stand. I hope that this will be a large majority. It is good that it binds the revenue and expenditure side of the European budget. For the first time since the 1980s, there is a real opportunity to reform the revenue side of the budget, which has been heavily criticised, but also fiercely defended in recent years. This was not unthinkable in the era of Prime Minister Cameron, so let us seize this opportunity.

name: Jean Arthuis
text: rapporteur, on behalf of Gérard Deprez. Mr President, Madam Minister, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this morning we had an excellent debate, a serious debate, because we are trying to format a budget for the European Union, covering the years 2021 to 2027. It's a huge challenge. Who knows what we will have to deal with in 2027? Several colleagues intervened, questioning whether it was appropriate for powers to be transferred to the European Union. The real question is whether, today, because of the challenges posed by globalisation, Member States, alone at the national level, still have the power to assume certain prerogatives of sovereignty in the fields of defence, security, digital, migration and climate.  In all these areas, is it not time to pool European means to regain real efficiency, to make the European Union a world power, and to meet the expectations of our fellow citizens who ask us to prepare their future and protect them? This Sunday, November 11, we celebrated the 100th anniversary of the 1918 armistice, we gathered, thinking of the 17 million victims, and we came out of this Great War in such conditions as we were preparing for the Second World War. How many tens of millions of victims has this European tragedy caused? Well! ladies and gentlemen, if we are to be worthy of the memory of all these victims, I think the right answer is to build a Europe that meets our expectations, a Europe that allows us to take back control of our destiny, a Europe at the service of peace, freedom, prosperity and solidarity. I think our budget, as we propose, is moving in that direction. It remains to convince the Council. We want to go fast, but not at any price. What is most important is the excellence of this budget.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 14 November 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – First of all, I would like to stress that we must strive for the implementation of the Social Pillar of Europe and european social rights, namely to increase employment, promote gender equality, the protection of the rights of the child, and combat poverty, especially severe child poverty, and combat income inequalities. And in order to achieve all this, it is necessary to adequately finance social policy measures, because there is certainly not enough funds at present to deal with social issues. I therefore urge the Commission and the Member States to provide for a specific budget for a European guarantee for children in the new long-term budget, so that every child is guaranteed health and childcare, education, decent accommodation and proper nutrition services, including helping parents find work and overcome social exclusion. Secondly, I regret that no further progress has been made in the area of gender equality and that no clear gender equality strategy with specific objectives, objectives and appropriations has been drawn up under the 2014-2020 budget. I therefore call on the Commission and the Council to include a gender perspective as far as possible in all areas when drawing up the new multiannual budget, and to provide sufficient funds to address gender equality issues.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. - Mr President, I would like to thank the European I call on my fellow Members to vote in favour of Parliament's position on the next seven-year EU framework budget. Let us show our voters that the European Parliament stands united in its support for EU policies for the well-being of citizens, in particular cohesion policy and agricultural policy. More than 50% of the EU population lives in rural areas, so it is important to maintain the attractiveness of these areas by ensuring growth and employment, the necessary infrastructure, mobility opportunities and basic services. Therefore, we cannot reduce the budgets of the main EU policies supporting the countryside, such as agricultural policy, cohesion policy and fisheries policy. I am pleased that Parliament is standing by the preservation of the current budget for these policies, and I think it is a success that it is even proposing a 10% increase in the budget of the fisheries policy, which includes aquaculture. I call on the European Commission and the governments of the Member States not to abandon the European countryside and its citizens in the budgetary negotiations, but to fight for the EU funds that support them and to support Parliament's proposal.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The proposal for a Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2021-2027 presented by the European Commission is deeply negative for Portugal and Europe.  By cutting cohesion and the common agricultural policy by increasing the 'security' and 'defence' lines, this proposal will accentuate asymmetries between countries, penalising peripheral economies heavily shaken by the asymmetric impact of the single market, common EU and euro policies and their economic governance instruments.  In addition to the cuts, the MFF proposal contains other unacceptable aspects, among which we highlight a significant increase in national contribution to the implementation of the Structural Funds, a greater predominance of financial instruments, a clear strengthening of macroeconomic conditionality, seeking to link the implementation of the Structural Funds to the European Semester, and the creation of new forms of political conditionality.  We have tabled dozens of amendments to the MFF and the European Parliament's position to strengthen Cohesion, eliminate cap and POSEI cuts and reverse the sharp increase in military spending, including arms development, and ongoing security drift.  The question is not when the MFF will be approved (whether before or after May 2019), but whether or not it will be acceptable to Portugal.

name: ––Емил Радев (PPE)
text: in writing. – The multiannual financial framework is extremely important because it provides financing and support for the development of regions, the founding of thousands of small and medium-sized enterprises, the economic upturn, as well as the security and security of europe's external borders. I therefore welcome the European Parliament's position on increasing funds for cohesion policy, agriculture, road and rail infrastructure, as well as for migration and border protection.  At the same time, I would like to warn against attempts to link the European budget to a rule of law framework, especially if it is extended to include democracy and fundamental rights, if there are no specific criteria for analysing and assessing the link between certain infringements and the spending of European funds. It is essential that what measures are taken in this regard, which must refer to the European founding treaties, do not constitute a sanctioning mechanism on the basis of political bias, and do not stop the provision of European funding to the ordinary people most in need of the funds.  I am of the opinion that the European Commission's proposal to suspend European funds due to breaches of the rule of law should have been better analysed, with a previous study of the possible effect on final beneficiaries and a stronger legal basis.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: in writing. – The Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027 must be adopted before the Elections to the European Parliament in May 2019 if Member States really want to prepare the new European programming period in good condition. The budget increase requested by the European Parliament, from 1.1% to 1.3%, should be accepted by the Member States, so as not to have a budget that does not provide the necessary resources to carry out European policies and programmes. This is the position of the European Parliament that will be put to a vote on Wednesday 14 November 2018.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D)
text: Written. – Our Union faces greater challenges than ever before, such as migration, climate change, disruptive technologies and unstable regions on the Union's borders. The Union must have sufficient clout to cope with it, including in the budgetary field. That is why we are calling for a budget of at least 1.3% of Europe's gross national income and the possibility of collecting at least 60% of the budget through its own income. But it is at least as important to ensure that this money is spent correctly. Important guidelines for this are our commitments arising from the Paris Climate Agreement and from the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). The Social Democrats in Parliament have succeeded in getting the other groups on board to devote 30% of the expenditure specifically to meeting the climate targets. Moreover, in the interim report, we were able to push through the view that the whole of the MFK should be focused on achieving the SDGs. This means that all investments that are not in line with this, or which undermine those objectives, must be stopped. We want a European budget in which all investment contributes to a social and sustainable Europe, which puts citizens first.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the vote. (Results and other details of the vote: see minutes of the meeting)

name: Ruža Tomašić
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I have to tell you that while working on this report, I’ve never seen a Commission working so unethically with a chosen few MEPs. What really saddens me is that the Commission, together with the chosen ones, used manipulation and misleading facts that would make this report – the way they proposed – look good but, unfortunately, on paper only. If the Commission’s plan is an example for the rest of the Mediterranean and they lobby for it the way they lobbied for this report, then I don’t know why we all are here. May I remind you that all the stakeholders are on my side, and I don’t know about you, but I am here to protect the interests of the people and not the Commission.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I congratulate the rapporteurs, and I particularly congratulate Mr Wencie. I have mixed feelings here. The first is joy, because this is a very good report. Secondly, it is a pity, because Mr Wenta was elected president of Kielce, so he will probably leave us. I offer my best wishes to Mr Bogdan on the occasion of the new function.

name: John Howarth (S&D).
text: – Mr President, this is a report that must be supported. The study of psychology sometimes gets a bad press, but it does teach us that the changes we make make human beings uncomfortable. But, if nothing else changes, climate will continue to change and human beings will suffer the consequence. Climate leadership is not about playing to the fear of change. Real leadership is about accelerating those changes that must happen and making them work for people.  Improved energy efficiency can deliver real gains for those struggling with fuel poverty. However, in reality, many in fuel poverty are hard to reach and can be ill—equipped to take advantage of the measures on offer. If energy demand and reduction is to go hand—in—hand with an end to fuel poverty, every Member State will need a clear programme, ensuring that energy companies are better able to develop smart networks and incentivised to meet the social obligations of those suffering fuel poverty.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this report because I really consider it very important for our future. Indeed, energy efficiency is a key requirement for our common future. It is not possible to waste resources, by which I mean the need to be gentle in our daily lives, to be resource-friendly, of course, to people, to the landscape and undoubtedly to natural resources in the position of energy sources. Of course, if we do not use our existing resources effectively enough, we will need more and more resources.  The fight against climate change simply cannot be managed without our restrictive approach to ourselves. Innovation must be encouraged and, with regard to the objectives that are set, I think that the outcome of the trilogue, that is, an increase in the indicative non-binding EU efficiency target to 32.5% and an increase in the real energy savings rate to 0.8%, is real, not dramatically ambitious and, moreover, some national flexibility is allowed there, see the possibility for the State to exempt the transport sector from these objectives. I needed to stress all this, the importance of supporting it.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I strongly welcome the agreement that was reached on this extremely important directive, which will now require that we meet a 32.5% energy efficiency target at EU level by 2030. Member States would be obliged to increase their energy savings by 0.8% each year from 2021 to 2030. This could bring significant benefits, including encouraging the improvement of energy efficiency in our buildings. In the EU our buildings are our largest user, accounting for 40% of our final energy consumption and 38% of emissions. Additionally, buildings account for 68% of total gas consumption in Europe and 35% of our gas imports. Therefore, improving the efficiency of our buildings will not only bring cost savings to energy users but will also make emissions reductions and increase our energy security for reducing import dependency. This legislation goes hand in hand with the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive to increased the efficiency of our building stock, 75% of which is highly inefficient in the EU. Improving energy efficiency is a win-win situation for us all. Well done to Markus Pieper and all involved.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I consider it very important to promote energy efficiency. It is clear that by using energy efficiently and responsibly, we contribute to many goals. We reduce its impact on the environment and prevent energy poverty. However, it is important that we try to achieve energy efficiency at all stages of energy flow, while the understanding of increasing energy efficiency only as a reduction in energy use is wrong.  I believe that this approach is inappropriate, which is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Mr President, today we adopted concrete measures that will not only tackle climate change but also energy poverty that affects 50 million people in Europe. Energy savings and efficiency deliver a triple win: lower emissions, more jobs and cheaper bills, and as with all negotiations, we didn’t get everything, but we did get real progress. We will now have mandatory energy saving targets in place in all countries, and for the first time an obligation for Member States to specifically help vulnerable consumers, creating more jobs, better housing and solidarity for those who struggle to pay their energy bills. This isn’t the end of the story, but it’s a step in the right direction to creating the right conditions for the just transition that our planet and people urgently need.

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, this Clean Energy Package with its 33% renewables target by 2030 is too little, too late. However, it does at least encourage the necessary transition away from fossil fuels. I particularly welcome the new right UK citizens will gain to store and sell electricity they have generated at a fair price. This is a great boon for the Community Renewables Project I have championed across South—West England. On biofuels, the news is less good. Using food crops for fuel causes environmental damage and threatens food security, though agreement to end the scandal of wiping out rainforests to grow palm oil to put in our cars is at least a step in the right direction. In the UK, Brexit threatens even this unambitious progress, since it was driven by a coalition of elite interests including those who oppose action on climate change. This is why Extinction Rebellion, a civic movement demanding urgent action on climate breakdown, is so vital, and we must ensure that the UK continues to match EU sustainable energy targets in the future UK trade deal.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I also supported this report. In my opinion, it is precisely in the field of the Energy Union that the European Union has one of the biggest debts and it is already the second report or opinion that we are discussing in this regard. I must stress that, for example, for the Czech Republic, access to energy resources and good governance of the Energy Union as such is crucial for our future. We don't have much of our own energy resources. That is why I am glad that we have moved on in this debate. Indeed, today was quite forceful about energy savings, about lower emissions, about the responsibility of the Union, but also on the responsibility of the Member States to help the vulnerable, including, for example, states, not just businesses, households and individual citizens. So I really welcome this report and I am glad that we are moving forward. Perhaps our progress should be faster, but I firmly believe that we will see the end of our mandate, or the next mandate of a full Energy Union, as a means of protecting even vulnerable states.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I am voting in favour of this report, and I welcome the scope the regulation gives to the Commission to ensure that the targets are met and that Europe is collectively on track to meet them. As EPP rapporteur on the Renewable Energy Directive, I welcome that Member States will be required to set out detailed climate and energy plans outlining how they plan to reach the targets. While our renewable energy target is not binding at national level, it is binding collectively, and the Commission will be legally required to ensure that it is met. The system we are putting in place in this regard is positive. The Commission will assess the draft plans and issue specific recommendations in the event that the plans are not up to scratch. Member States will now be legally bound to take due account of these recommendations, and if they do not address the recommendations, they must make the reason public. If the Commission concludes that the contributions included in the final plans are not sufficient for the EU to meet the overall targets, the Commission will issue recommendations to the relevant Member States to increase their ambition. If they do not, the format that we agreed in the Renewable Energy Directive kicks in. I would thank my colleagues, especially Ms Delahaye, Mr Hökmark and Mr Turmes, who has now left after doing much good work.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Decarbonisation is one of the main pillars of the Energy Union. Betting on decarbonisation risks permanently losing the competitiveness of industry and enormous social costs, especially for economies with a high share of coal in the energy mix, such as Poland. Decarbonisation takes the mountain over energy solidarity and a just transition. It hits mining regions such as Silesia hard. I am a Polish woman, chosen by Poles to serve Poland well, which is why I cannot vote in favour of such a report.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the Energy Union of the European Union must, first of all, create a situation that does not exacerbate social and economic disparities within the Union itself. From then on, there is certainly a need for a common framework for action. Common principles are needed. However, all this must be done in respect of the competences of the Member States, because as we see, through the governance of the Energy Union the Commission and Brussels are essentially seeking to take up competences belonging to the Member States. This is unacceptable and, of course, contrary to the Treaty itself. The powers of the Member States in the field of energy should therefore be maintained. To have unity in diversity. Coordination, flexibility, a common strategy and, above all, respect for the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: Mr President, today we need more than ever a directive to promote the use of renewable energy sources. The use of renewable energy sources will contribute to the development of the energy independence of the European Union and our countries. It will increase security and make us less vulnerable to foreign and external suppliers. The binding target to increase energy consumption from renewable energy sources to 30% by 2030 is also necessary. However, in order to do this, it is necessary to enable Member States to exhaust all available tools. In Greece we need a broad liberalisation of the energy market, a regulatory framework for linking RES to existing water infrastructures, so that they can be used as storage facilities, and we also need synergies with local communities, so that RES is ultimately the main source of energy, especially on the islands. The European Union needs an integrated approach by national, regional and local authorities that will boost clean energy and jobs, which are so necessary in all Member States.

name: John Howarth (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I am delighted to support this report today. Only those who would deny the overwhelming evidence would doubt the urgency of the transition to renewable energy. It is a massive change that is needed, and we need real political leadership to make it happen. One of the first things that Member State governments can do is make sure that they don’t make things worse by allowing shale gas extraction through fracking. In my South East constituency with chalk aquifer geology, not only is shale gas fracking a backward step, it is a reckless gamble with unproven side effects. Fracking has been talked of as a bridge to a low-carbon future, but the evidence suggests anything but that. But, if we are to lead, we also need to recognise our responsibility to ensure that those who work in conventional energy should be part of the transition to renewables and not its casualties. That is why we need to secure, as a start, the EUR 4.8 billion just energy transition fund in tomorrow’s interim report on the seven—year budget framework.

name: Rosa D'Amato
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the promotion of the use of energy from renewable sources is a matter close to our hearts and should be important for all Members and the Commission. We have had to fight on various fronts, and we have achieved some gains, but the cross-party barrage of various parties and party interests has not allowed us to revolutionise the sector as we would have liked. State incentives for the production of renewable energy remain optional. Therefore, in order to make ends meet under the strict conditions of austerity, under the conditions imposed by Europe on the budget, many States will be unable to apply them. Another negative aspect is the drive towards the use of wood as a renewable fuel, without any limit to the use of forest wood. We risk a race to deforestation, an increase in particulate pollution, with a negative impact on the environment and the climate. An effort has been made in the directive to increase the Eu ropean Union's overall target by reaching at least 32 % of renewables and, given the pressures from fossil fuel sectors, it was by no mean a foregone conclusion. Above all, however, we have achieved an historic victory, we have recognised the right and allowed citizens to become prosumers – producers and consumers – on an individual or collective level, of renewable energy, putting unconsumed energy on the net and obtaining at least equal to the market share, without charges and taxes until 2026. Households and communities can become autonomous from large corporations, and the renewable energy produced in this way can accelerate a real transition process. The directive is better than it is at present. I therefore voted in favour, in the hope that the next Parliament – it is almost a certainty – will have more strength to stop lobbies and interests that persist in jeopardising our future.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I see many positive aspects in the Regulation on the promotion of renewable energy sources. The rules on biomass, biofuels and the inclusion of RES in network heating have been designed in a very balanced way and I consider them to be a good example of a compromise between what is desirable and what is possible. It is important that the integration of RES into energy systems is gradual and respects the competences of states and the investments made so far. My concern, on the other hand, is that the overall objective is too high. Germany's example shows that a massive transformation towards RES leads to very high costs. This model is not worth duplicating, so I could not support this report, but I abstained because of the good detailed solutions that I have spoken about before.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, renewable energy sources can indeed contribute to the protection of the environment. From then on, however, it is necessary to comply with the standards. I have repeatedly denounced the environmental crime taking place in South Karystia, on Mount Rachi, where 42 wind farms with a total capacity of 700 MW will be installed. You realize that this is a huge intervention in the environment. An area that has been integrated into the Natura Network and in which these wind farms are now built in a much larger proportion than in other parts of Greece. This is because South Karystia is essentially next to Athens and so it is easy to transport the electricity produced. However, this environmental disaster cannot continue. I have raised this issue on several occasions. We are waiting to see when, at last, the Commission will refer Greece to the European Court of Justice, because the Commission itself has stated, since November 2017, that Greece will be indicted for violating environmental conditions.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I wanted to show my vote in favour of this report.  This multiannual plan for small pelagics in the Adriatic is the third of the management plans presented by the European Commission under the new CFP and, as has happened or is going through the demersal plan in the western Mediterranean, the Commission has taken too long to present the proposals for these management plans. Hence his difficulties right now.  Scientists agree that the specificity of Mediterranean fisheries, with a clear multispecific component and predominance of small-scale fisheries, make TACs and quotas not an option to restore fishing opportunities throughout the Mediterranean. It is preferable to use other management methods based on technical measures and stress reductions by adapting the current management plans or the one that can be established at European Union level.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Dear Chairman, this is an opportunity to stress that I have supported this report by the Rapporteur and all those who have worked on the Fisheries Committee on this topic. This topic is very important for the Adriatic Sea, especially for my country, Croatia. In my view, this Regulation, this Directive will substantially improve relations in small blue fisheries. Catching a small blue fish is very important and it also depends on the catch of tuna in the Republic of Croatia, which is a large part of our fisheries. If by any chance we had adopted a biomass escapement strategy, we would have lost about 10,000 jobs, which is by no means the right solution at the moment.  In any case, this regulation also has socioeconomic significance. It is important to keep the skills that our people have in the rural and coastal area. These skills are passed down from generation to generation and it is very important to have this intangible value, which exists along the Adriatic coast, and therefore I have supported this regulation with all my heart.

name: Renate Weber (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I voted against the resolution because it is superficial and deeply unfair.
