In Romania, the independence of some magistrates was seriously affected by the prosecutors general, Laura Kövesi and Augustin Lazar, who in 2009 and 2016 signed secret protocols with the Intelligence Service, forcing prosecutors to become its subordinates and to report developments in criminal investigations, a unique situation in the European Union, and I regret that many of my colleagues in the European Parliament are not interested in the reality in Romania. With the revelations of the interference of the secret service in the act of justice and in political life it is clear that in the shadow of the mechanism of verification and cooperation in Romania a monster was created, and the European Commission should take responsibility for tolerating this. Today's resolution also wants to whiten the European Commission and those Member States which in recent years have criticised only what it has agreed to, including with today's CVM report, thus perverting the very foundation of the rule of law.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I did not vote for the resolution because this is a resolution of hypocrisy. It is not a resolution on the rule of law in Romania. Why does the European Parliament want, why do certain MEPs want it, why does the Commission want my country to be cornered? Because he doesn't want to accept being a second-rate country, because we want you to give us recipes that you don't apply in your country. Why don't you export what you put in resolution to your home? Why are you going into subsidiarity? In which country has the European Union interfered with the change of a head of institution? Why do we have to report when a head of institution, be he and the Attorney General, change constitutionally? A crisis was created, a country of prosecutors was created. Leave us alone! We want to defend our citizens, we want the Treaty to be respected. We, Romania, have not violated the Treaty, but the European Union is violating the Treaty and the Schengen Regulation. Don't leave us in the Schengen area even though we don't have fences, we don't have murdered journalists. Corruption - romania is not in the group of nine countries where it is now the largest corruption in the history of the European Union. Why doesn't the same unit of measure apply? I am outraged and consider it an injustice for my country and for my citizens.

name: Mirosław Piotrowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Our group of European Conservatives and Reformists did not support this resolution, because many of us, including myself, believe that many of the issues raised in it do not belong to the competence of the European Union, but to the Member States, in this case Romania. This applies both to the reform of the justice system, as mentioned in point two, and to the organisation of the media, point seven, among others. This resolution is largely ideological in nature, as highlighted in recital M, where the authors deplore discrimination against sexual minorities in Romania, citing a review of the situation of the European branch of the International Lesbian and Gay Association.  That is why I and many of my colleagues voted against this resolution.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, in Romania we are killing democracy by killing the press. Investigative journalists at the RISE Project document a case concerning the fraud of European funds by politicians at the top of power in Romania, including Liviu Dragnea, president of the ruling Socialist Party of Romania. The RISE Project and the Journalistic Consortium investigating organised crime and corruption are convinced that the Romanian Government's use of the GDPR to stop and destroy journalistic information through serious abuse of the GDPR by politicians to abuse themselves, protect itself against its own abuses and against journalistic investigations. For example, four days ago, the National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing asked journalists to communicate to them the journalistic sources, electronic and physical media on which they stored information, documents and photos published on Facebook. If it does not communicate within ten days, the RISE Project risks fines of up to 20 million euros. This is not democracy, this is the killing of the press.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Romanians are also European citizens, and I believe that no European citizen can vote in favour of hypocrisy, the double standard and hegemony that some political formulas are trying to impose on some Eastern states. , but come here and always make resolutions in favour of human rights. Double standard for accusing us of not letting the President appoint prosecutors, but in Poland you are reproached for letting the President appoint prosecutors. Hegemony because they are political formulas that have no correspondent in reality. Ignore the double standard in justice, ignore selective justice, ignore the influence of the intelligence services, and tell us that this is the way to do it. Perhaps this European Union has done so for ten years, tolerating this situation of things in Romania which is, yes, contrary to the rule of law and undemocratic.

name: Mircea Diaconu (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, if my explanation were to bear a title, it would be 'small political games which risk destroying all the construction' - in Romanian to say 'sandramaua'. This resolution has at least two very good and necessary points, I mean a serious criterion, a serious rule of law standard applicable to all countries - it is true - and the continuation of the assessment of the study and the level of corruption in all Member States, interrupted in 2014 without any explanation. Romania in no way can be the first in this standard of corruption, but in half, as the one in 2014 said. The term "concern" is often used. Worried, too, but not why you think. I am concerned about the following: that in all the major European democracies, extremism, xenophobia, nationalism have reached Parliament and very close, it is breathing down the back of the head of the major European parties. During which time there is a big problem and concern with Romania. I'm afraid there must be another concern, because we risk the "sandramau" falling apart.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this resolution with my vote because I believe that we must reject the legalisation of corruption, the reform of the judiciary, which distort the division of labour, the use of violence against peaceful protests by citizens, the suppression of civil society and the pressure on the free media. In this spirit, I also appeared in a debate with the Prime Minister.  However, the European Parliament should not question the right of citizens to express their views in a referendum. Likewise, I do not agree with the establishment of a mechanism consisting of regular mandatory monitoring of respect for the principles of democracy and the rule of law. That is why I believe that we should adopt resolutions such as this resolution, in which the European Union responds to threats to democracy and violations of the rule of law. So that we do not have to do unnecessary bureaucracy, we draw the attention of the Government of Romania to such a challenge, that it must listen to its people.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I have given great thought to how to vote on this matter. I think that the European Parliament should be restrained, it should not put too much into its vision of democratic governance of the state. On the other hand, we have clear rules, both in the Treaties and in specific provisions that simply speak of the rule of law. This is simply a value that should not be discussed in the form of denying its basic principles. And when we have seen a truly disproportionate crackdown by the police forces and the reaction of the Romanian Government, it raises very serious questions, and it is not just about the demonstrations, it is really about the interference in the media, in the rule of law. When we read that forty-eight prosecutors have been dismissed, that the Minister of Justice is demanding the dismissal of the Chief Prosecutor, these are indeed matters that raise questions from the point of view of respect for the rule of law. And I was therefore obliged to vote in favour of the draft resolution on this matter, because it is proportionate and wants to know the answers from the Romanian Government. We haven't received those yet.

name: Siegfried Mureşan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I voted today in favour of the resolution on the rule of law in Romania. The resolution is good for Romania, it is good for the Romanian people, the resolution defends honest people by politicians in Romania who want to weaken justice, to stop the fight against corruption, politicians who want weak institutions at their beck and call. Liviu Dragnea, Viorica Dăncilă, Minister of Justice Tudorel Toader, all of whom failed. Today, the European Parliament voted by a large majority with the support of all the great European families, of all the pro-European families, voted by a large majority for this resolution, and the signal is this: the European Parliament stands with the Romanians, stands with the Romanian people in their struggle for good governance, for justice, for European values. The PSD-ALDE's attempt to convince Europe that 500,000 people who went out to protest were wrong and Liviu Dragnea would be right failed. Today's vote, overwhelmingly, makes it very clear that the PSD-ALDE are isolated in Europe and can achieve nothing for Romania in Europe.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE).
text: – I supported the report because the European Union is a mosaic of cultures, languages, religions and traditions that form the diverse community of citizens united by our core values. As the report points out, approximately 8% of Union citizens belong to minorities and approximately 10% speak a regional or minority language. International agreements provide a framework for the rights of minorities, but can significantly improve the way in which the protection of minority rights is carried out in practice, taking into account evidence of systemic and institutional discrimination.  Measures are needed to ensure the effective implementation of minority rights and this report is a step in this direction, in particular through the call on the Commission to draw up a common framework of European Union minimum standards for the protection of minorities containing measurable targets, regular monitoring and sanctions.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Unity in diversity is the strength of the Community, that is the strength of the European Union. Sixty years of building this unity in diversity are behind us, and we have great, great successes in this regard, but somewhere on the horizon you can hear the voices of the storm. We are seeing increasing tensions in the Member States, we are seeing an increase in the strength of nationalist, chauvinistic movements. All this means that we should look even further at the norms that apply to the protection of those who are weaker, those who are in the minority. Without going into the document now, because there is little time, I want to say that one thing I am missing there, that is, a great emphasis on raising public awareness and education. Not only by legislation, not just by directives, not just by paragraphs, but also by sanctions, but also by sanctions, by penalties, we can bring about the state we expect, and above all by education and public awareness.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, in the EU 8% of citizens belong to national minorities and 10% speak a regional or a minority language. If this House were to fully represent the ethnic diversity of the EU, every 10th Member here would belong to a national minority, that is to say to a vulnerable group. If you try to imagine being this 10th Member then the whole picture changes. I supported the report of Mr Nagy with my vote and I had the honour of contributing to it personally. My claim is that the Commission needs to explore the legal instruments so that minorities can be better represented at EU level. The Commission cannot always hide behind the lack of competence to address the minorities issue. In the EU, we are witnessing odious practices that go against human rights. The new school reform in Latvia deprives our children of the right to study in their own language. I am extremely worried about oppressive linguistic policies, and I say that we must fight against such illiberal practices.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, while the European Parliament is debating and voting on a report on the protection of minority rights, at the same time it rejects my proposal and the ECR's proposal to hold a debate yesterday on the murder of Konstantinos Katsifas by the Albanian police and on the rights of the Greek ethnic minority in northern Epirus. The European Parliament has therefore missed a huge opportunity to send a message of support to the Greek minority in the North Continent. He missed the opportunity to send a message to Rama: to come together and stop oppressing the Greek ethnic minority of the North Continent. He missed the opportunity for the European Parliament to "cut the cough" of Rama and the Albanian authorities, to ask them to comply with their obligations and to send the message that if they continue to violate the rights of the Greek ethnic minority in the North Continent, then the road to Europe is closed.

name: Alex Mayer (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the Raspberry Pi was developed in my constituency to get youngsters coding, but the phenomenally successful single-board computer could make a huge difference in the field of development because it’s cheap, robust and low power. Take the need to keep vaccines at the correct temperature, as 150 million vaccines in developing countries are wasted due to poor refrigeration. German researchers found a Raspberry Pi, in combination with sensor networking, provides a cost-effective solution.  Six hundred and sixty million people lack access to water that’s safe to drink. Photocatalysis with a Raspberry Pi has removed the need for large, expensive equipment to drive a safe drinking water experiment at a Welsh university. And in the field in Nicaragua, using a ‘Pi’ as a local server means medical texts are now readily available to communities which don’t have access to the Internet.  Development is never as easy as pie, but with this technology, it can provide a great slice of help.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by One could say that humanity has never had as much of an opportunity to promote democracy and prosperity as it does now. This is served by the continued peace in the world, but also by international cooperation. There is a third element, something that we have not looked at in this regard before, namely the development of technologies, especially the development of digital technologies. This is an absolute breakthrough in the dissemination of what we are talking about, that is, the well-being and universal interaction of people around the world. The development of technologies, especially digital ones, is also an instrument that not only serves entire states or societies as a whole, but can even serve individuals.  That is why our priority today should be to reduce digital exclusion. This is a way of achieving objectives that are very important for us, for Europeans.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I hereby close the vote.

name: President. –
text: Dear Chancellor, thank you for being here in Strasbourg, in the European Parliament, for this very important debate with the Members of the European Parliament on the future of the European Union. For us, it is very important to know the German position on the most important issues on the future of our Union. We know the position of the European Parliament, we know the position of the Commission, but for paving the way for a better Europe we need to change Europe, but it would be a big mistake to destroy Europe. We want to be European in the coming years as well. The European Parliament wants more power. (Applause) We are the only European institution that is directly elected by the citizens. On the budget, we want to decide before the European elections. We want to increase the budget from 1.1 to 1.3, we want own resources. On immigration, the other important issue, we want to cooperate with the Council; we want to achieve a good solution to the Dublin reform. It is possible to achieve an agreement before the end of this year. And also if we want to achieve a good solution on immigration we need to invest more in Africa. We need a plan for Africa. We need more money in Africa to combat climate change ... (Applause) ... against terrorism, against poverty, in favour of growth. Not a new colonisation, but a new modern cooperation between Europe and Africa. For this we need also a European foreign policy with a European defence. This is very important for us, it is very important for the future of the European Union. Thank you, Chancellor for being here. You have the floor. (Applause)

name: Angela Merkel
text: Federal Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany. Mr President of the European Parliament, Mr Antonio Tajani, Mr President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioners for their excellent work and for their excellent work. Almost fifty years ago, former German Commission President Walter Hallstein called European unification an "unprecedented audacity." That was in 1969, ten years before the first direct election to the European Parliament. At that time, the European Community was still in its infancy. Many of our greatest achievements – Schengen, the single market, a common currency – were still visionary projects. But the foundation stone was laid, and with it, after centuries of wars and dictatorships, the citizens of Europe had for the first time the prospect of a lasting peaceful and stable future. And today I stand in front of the largest democratic parliament in the world with joy, but also with gratitude.  (Applause) They, the 751 members from 28 countries, together represent more than 500 million people; that is almost seven percent of the world's population. We feel the heartbeat of European democracy in your House. This is demonstrated by the debates held in 24 languages. And that shows something that makes Europe, that is diversity. But it is precisely one of the great strengths of us Europeans that we have repeatedly , despite all the diversity – been guided by the will to reach agreement, by the will to compromise, and that, despite different origins, despite different attitudes, we have always come to a result for the good of the Community. It is now more than eleven years since I spoke to this House for the first time. Germany had assumed the EU presidency at the time, in 2007. I spoke at the time about the diversity that divides us and does not share us, about freedom, which must be defended again and which Europe, like human beings, needs the air to breathe. At the time, I spoke of a fundamental value that distinguishes Europe, of a value that combines freedom and diversity in Europe. I have spoken of tolerance. I have spoken of the fact that the tolerance, the soul of Europe and therefore an indispensable fundamental value of the European idea. Over the past eleven years, however, we have also seen how much the world has changed and how, with it, the soul of Europe has been strained, if you like. Global political, economic and technological challenges have been evolving faster and deeper. We have been through a major sovereign debt crisis, international terrorism has not stopped before the European Union, wars and armed conflicts are taking place just a few hours from here on our doorstep, global movements of refugees and migrants are also affecting us Europeans in a very concrete way, and digital progress is changing our way of life at a breathtaking pace. We are feeling the consequences of climate change, old allies are questioning tried and tested alliances, with the United Kingdom, for the first time a country will leave the European Union, how deep this cut will be, we feel more than ever in these days of intense negotiations, and I would like to thank Michel Barnier most warmly for his work. (Applause) Dear Members of this House, why am I saying this? We all feel that it has become more difficult to predict developments. But we feel something else: it is becoming less and less promising to assert the interests that one has on the global stage alone. Conversely, it is becoming increasingly important for us Europeans to stand together. For this, we need, more than ever, respect for others and their interests within the European Union. More than ever, we need an understanding that tolerance is the soul of Europe, that it is an essential part of what makes us Europeans, and that it is only with it that we can develop a willingness to understand each other's interests and needs as our own needs. That is the prerequisite for meeting. (Applause) This brings us to the heart of European solidarity, without which successful action is inconceivable. This solidarity is based on tolerance, and it makes up our strength, which is nowhere else, as Europeans, for three reasons: firstly, solidarity is a universal value. Working for each other is a prerequisite for any functioning community. This applies to the family, to the village community, to the sports club and to a community like the European Union. Solidarity is an integral part of the European Treaties, it is a central part of our canon of values. Solidarity is part of European DNA. We support countries and regions in their economic development or in the fight against youth unemployment, we help each other in the event of natural disasters, we stand by each other in the event of terrorist attacks or reactor accidents, we have put in place so-called bailouts in the European sovereign debt crisis to help affected countries solve their economic and financial problems. These few examples alone show that the individual Member States of the European Union, and with them the citizens of the European Union, are not alone in difficult times and emergencies. On the other hand, these few examples also show that individual national decisions always have an impact on the whole Community. Secondly, solidarity always goes with responsibility for the community of all. In concrete terms, this means that anyone who undermines the rule of law in his country, who curtails the rights of the opposition and civil society, who restricts freedom of the press, not only jeopardises the rule of law in his own country, but also jeopardises the rule of law of all of us throughout Europe. (Applause) Europe can, of course, only function as a community governed by the rule of law if the law is applied equally and respected everywhere. Anyone who bets on solving problems through new debt alone and disregards commitments made calls into question the foundations of the strength and stability of the euro area. Our common currency can only work if every single member fulfils their responsibility for sound finances at home.  (Applause) Anyone who questions Europe's unity with third parties, for example on agreed sanctions or on human rights policy, undermines the credibility of the whole of European foreign policy. For Europe can only make its voice heard in the world if it is united. (Applause) This means that solidarity always means overcoming national egoisms. I am well aware that Germany, too, has not always behaved impeccably or behaved impeccably in the eyes of some. For example, in the years before 2015, it took us far too long to accept the refugee issue as an issue for all the Member States of the European Union for us as Germany ... (Applause) ... and to understand that it is a pan-European task. Thirdly, solidarity for the benefit of all also means acting in the well-understood interests of one's own. Respect and support for others and the representation of one's own interests are not contradictory – quite the contrary! An example of this is our cooperation with African countries of origin of refugees and migration – as the President has just pointed out. This cooperation helps Europe because it organises, controls and reduces flight and migration to Europe, and it also serves the people on the ground by improving their lives and by saving them from embarking on an often life-threatening journey to Europe. Another example is the European commitment to global climate protection, which is absolutely necessary, both ecologically and economically and socially, for the protection of natural resources and thus for us. It is good for Europe if developed and emerging countries as a whole produce fewer greenhouse gases and our economies become greener overall. It also benefits all Europeans if the eurozone also develops free of faults and becomes a haven of strength and stability. It is good for all Europeans if everyone participates in European civil protection. It is good for all Europeans to help those who are particularly affected by flight and migration. Tolerance requires respect for the fact that the issue of the reception of refugees in different Member States provokes different reactions on the basis of their own history, their demographic development. Solidarity requires us to make every effort at the same time to find a common path on which we can overcome these challenges, as well as all other challenges as a community. So that is what makes Europe: solidarity as a universal fundamental value, solidarity as a responsibility for the community and solidarity as a well-understood self-interest. Ladies and gentlemen! Unity and unity are essential for Europe's success. I would therefore like to highlight three areas which, in my view, will be particularly important. Firstly, foreign and security policy: as Europeans, we are already realising that we have a great deal of our interests everywhere. better defend where we perform together. Only united is Europe strong enough to be heard on the global stage and to defend its values and interests. The days when we could rely unreservedly on others are just over. This means that if we want to survive as a community, we Europeans must take our destiny more into our own hands. (Applause and boos) And that means that Europe must become more capable of action in foreign policy in the long term. That is why we must be prepared to reconsider our decision-making channels and to refrain from unanimity where the Treaties make this possible and wherever possible. (Applause) I have proposed that we set up a European Security Council with changing rotating staffing levels of the Member States, in which important decisions can be prepared more quickly. And we must create a European intervention force with which Europe can also act at the scene. We have made great progress in structured cooperation in the military field. That is a good thing and is being supported as much as possible here. But we should work – and I say this very deliberately from the development of recent years – on the vision of one day also creating a genuine European army. (Applause and heckling)

name: Presidente. –
text: (in response to some comments from the chamber) I didn't know there were wolves in this House.

name: Angela Merkel
text: Federal Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany. – For Jean-Claude Juncker said four years ago that a common European army would show the world that there will never again be war between European countries. And this is not an army against NATO – I ask you – but it can be a good complement to NATO. No one wants to question classic connections, but in a ... (Strong applause) But, ladies and gentlemen, it would be much easier to work with us if we now have over 160 defence systems, weapons systems and the United States of America only 50 or 60. If we need independent administration, care and training for everything, then we are not an efficient partner, and if we want to use our money efficiently and yet fight for the same goals, then we can stand together in NATO with a European army. There is no contradiction at all. (Loud applause and heckling) And that closes, of course ... (Interjections) Look, I'm looking forward to it. I am not irritated. I also come from a Parliament. So! (Loud applause) This also includes the joint development of weapons systems within Europe. This also means – and this is a difficult task, including for the Federal Republic of Germany – that we develop a common arms export policy, because otherwise we cannot act uniformly in the world. Secondly, ladies and gentlemen, the economic success of Europe is important. It is the basis of our strength and a prerequisite for us being heard in the world at all. If we are not economically strong, we will not be politically influential either. I am very pleased that the programme of Jean-Claude Juncker, the Investment Fund, has had a significant impact in recent years and that we have already launched EUR 350 or 340 billion of the EUR 500 billion of investment by 2020 – a good programme for more investment. I know how many times the demand for more investment has come from your House, and that is now on the way. However, we should also talk about this, because EUR 340 billion is not a cardboard stick, but a real contribution to greater prosperity in Europe. And, of course, a stable prosperous Europe also includes a stable economic and monetary union. We want to develop the European stability mechanism further, we are working on the banking union, we are working on a eurozone budget – Germany and France have spoken out in favour of it; I believe that this should be closely linked to the medium-term financial perspective – and we are in favour of liability and control being shared. In other words, the banking union and, later, a European deposit guarantee scheme, require that risks in the nation states were also reduced beforehand. This goes together, European solidarity and personal responsibility are always two sides of the same coin. But here, as the European Council – at least Germany is in favour, together with France – we will certainly present visible successes by December. We will also make progress on an issue that is being discussed very intensively these days, in which you are also very involved, namely digital taxation.  Germany does not have the question of whether we need to carry out digital taxation – this is a matter of course in the age of digitalisation – but we have the question of how exactly we do this. I believe that one of the democratic habits is that we should take note of the Commission's proposals, but that something can also be added. We believe that the best thing would be to find an international solution in an international context. We are relying on minimum taxation. If that does not work, however, we cannot wait until St. Neverleins Day, but then we must act at European level, and Germany is committed to this.  (Applause) If we are honest and look to the future and think about our prosperity, then we have to accept that today it is no longer the case that the major innovations – as was the case 100 years ago and 130 years ago – always or mostly come from Europe, but it is the case today that very many of the fundamental innovations from Asia come from Europe. , come from the United States of America. That is why the question is, of course, whether we, as the continent in which the car was once invented, will also determine the mobility of the future? It makes me uneasy that we can't produce battery cells, for example. It is okay for Chinese companies to invest in Germany now. But I think we should make a great effort to also in Europe to be able to master the drive technology of the future and to make battery cell production possible again here.  (Applause) We have the European instruments for this. We have it all in our hands, as we are doing with the chips today. We need to be at the forefront of quantum computers, we need to develop a common strategy for artificial intelligence. All this is still possible because we have a strong industrial base in Europe. We can build on that, and we must take advantage of that now. In this respect, research and innovation are key points for our future prosperity. The third area, ladies and gentlemen, which I would like to call on is the issue of refugees and migration. In the euro crisis, we have already had many hurdles to overcome in order to reach a common solution. But we have succeeded. But on the issue of flight and migration, Europe is not yet as united as I would like it to be. And since this is a central issue in terms of our relationship with our neighbourhood, we must find common ground here. And we have made progress on this. We all agree on the need for a common European border management. In retrospect, it was certainly a little frivolous, I say, that a Schengen area of free movement has been created, but is only now working to obtain a register of entry and exit to know who is with us and who is leaving us. However, it is right that we do so now. It is right that we develop Frontex. I think the Commission's proposals are good. Here, too, it is a question of this: if everyone wants to retain their national competence and if none of the European border guards wants to give any powers, then it can be so great and as good as it is, then it will not be able to carry out its work. Here, too, we must give up national competences to a little extent and act together. (Applause) We must then also consider: how can we share the work of development aid, development cooperation and Africa's economic development? There are now excellent results – none of this would have been possible two or three years ago – where we work with individual Member States with the Commission in individual African states, thereby achieving greater added value than if we all appeared there individually. We can learn a lot more here, but I think we are on the right track. Then it is also a question of developing a common European asylum procedure. If everyone makes their decisions differently, then one need not be surprised that people from a particular country know this immediately and then secondary migration takes place naturally in the area of freedom of movement. We must make the effort, just as we are developing a common level playing field for the internal market, to develop common standards on such sensitive issues as those of the right of asylum and humanitarian responsibility. Otherwise, we will not be able to cope with the abandonment of refugees and migration.  (Applause and boos) Ladies and gentlemen! These were now three examples from many, and the fact that I have hit the core is shown by the protest. This is beautiful and honorable. (Applause) I believe that people want Europe to tackle the very problems that are burning on their nails. People want a Europe that provides answers to the questions that depress us. This does not mean that Europe must be everywhere. It remains the case that not every problem in Europe is a problem for Europe. Solidarity does not mean ubiquity. But solidarity means that Europe acts where it is needed, and that it can then act strongly and decisively and effectively.  I am convinced that Europe is our best chance for lasting peace, for lasting prosperity, for a secure future. Our meeting in Paris, at the invitation of the French President, to commemorate the horrors of the First World War a hundred years ago, should have made us aware once again of what happens when nations have no respect for each other and what happens when communities such as the League of Nations, which was founded as a result of the First World War, fail. There was even greater horror. (Applause) That is why we must not squande this European opportunity. We owe it to ourselves, we owe it to the past generation, and we owe it to future generations. This means that nationalism and selfishness must never again have a chance in Europe. (Applause) But tolerance and solidarity are our common future. Ladies and gentlemen, it is worth it to make an effort!

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the European Commission. Mr President, Chancellor, Angela Merkel, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mrs Merkel, for the work she has done on this report. I fully agree with what you have said here. I am only surprised that two thirds of this House is not here when the Maltese, Latvian and Lithuanian Prime Ministers speak here and say exactly the same thing as you have said here. Standing ovations for the Chancellor are simple.  I am missing those when others speak and say the very same things, so thanks to this House for having discovered the same dignity of equal nations in Europe. (Applause)

name: Le Président. –
text: Mr President, there are also many more Commissioners today than usual.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: président de la Commission. Monsieur le Président, ils ne résistent pas au plaisir de faire comme le Parlement.  I very much liked what you said here when it came to the plea for multilateralism. Multilateralism is part of the DNA of the European Union. What you have said about migration is at the very heart of what the European Commission proposed here years ago. Incidentally, the applause today was greater than the support of many when I said that Angela Merkel – As I said in October 2015 – is someone moving towards future history. History will tell you right. Not everyone in this House has always seen it that way. But you were right that you did not close the borders. (Applause) The CSU applause could be less sparse than it was today. (Laughter) When it comes to Brexit, we are swimming in the same channel. I repeat: we do not want punitive action against The United Kingdom. Great Britain, United Kingdom, has in free (interjections) But I'm not swimming in your direction – I'm swimming in exactly the opposition direction! But we have to respect the vote of the British people.  It's our duty to make the best of it, in the interest of Britain, in the interest of the European Union. We are not in an aggressive mood when it comes to the future relationship with Britain. The European Union, the continent, has to recognise that Britain, starting in 1939, was playing a major role when it came to freedom and the freedom of this continent. We are grateful for that ... (Applause) but this is not a reason to leave the great history between the islands and the European Union. In fact, I think that leaving is a tragedy, an historical error, a mistake, and we have to make the best of it and the Commission, together with Michel Barnier, is moving in that direction. (Applause) So, all in all, Chancellor, dear Angela, what you have said here is at the heart of what we are doing. Perhaps you are a little more supportive of all the Commission's virtuous initiatives on migration, on Africa and on euro reform. If you do more than you've already done, you'll get even bigger, and that's a performance. (Applause and boos)

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam Chancellor, President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to start with a quote: 'The unity of Europe was a dream of a few. It became a hope for many, and it is now a necessity for all of us." It was Konrad Adenauer, the first Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany, who coined this sentence. Madam Chancellor, I would like to thank the Chancellor for her With you in the office is a big picture of Konrad Adenauer, and you stand in this tradition of the German chancellors, who, knowing the history of the Federal Republic of Germany and Germany as a whole, always know that Germany can only do well if it is connected in friendship and partnership with its neighbours. Thanks to this pro-European attitude of the German chancellors – from Adenauer to Brandt, Schmidt, Kohl, Merkel, and many others – the unthinkable has been made possible in recent decades, because the largest country has made a significant contribution to this Europe. I am allowed to say today that I am 46 years old and That I am part of the first generation on this continent to say that she can live in peace and freedom throughout Europe. They belong to a generation that was also allowed to live in peace, but which was imprisoned behind the Iron Curtain for much of their lives. My grandfather was still part of the war generation. Unthinkable has been achieved, also because of the German contribution, also because of your contribution, Chancellor. That is why I would like to begin by expressing my sincere thanks for your clear pro-European stance. (Applause) But what does this work mean today? I would like to say thank you because you have emphasised that, first of all, pro-European means seeing the other, seeing the other's problem. For example, in the euro crisis, you sat down in Germany and explained to the Germans what the internal market means and demanded solidarity with other states, and it is the case that on the question of Ukraine, when Russia has again shifted borders militarily on this continent – for the first time since the Second World War – you have said that we Europeans must stand together and give a united answer. , that breach of international law will not be tolerated. And here it is that last summer – Jean-Claude, I made it clear in my speech manuscript inside – that borders cannot be closed unilaterally unilaterally, but can only be solved by dialogue with the neighbours. I would like to say thank you for this commitment, for this way of making politics, of overcoming selfishness, of seeking partnership. In addition, of course, we are in challenging times. Today, I would like to argue primarily methodically, not about the content, because we are discussing a lot, but are arguing methodically. The first is that we need a new will in Europe to take responsibility. We have discussed this here on several occasions. There is agreement in the Council, ministers regularly agree with 95%, 90% approval rates, especially in the Councils of Ministers, and when they are at home they know nothing more about it, even vote against it, even protesting. We have to end this Black Peter game. I would like to give a positive example today: it was Spain, for example, which knows no anti-European force. Why does Spain not know an anti-European force? Because politicians like Mariano Rajoy did not blame Brussels or attack it for the mistakes during the crisis, but Mariano Rajoy said: we Spaniards have a responsibility for the country, we must take over and do our homework. So, let us stop shifting the responsibility to Brussels! Then Europe will be much better off. (Applause) We must give Europe success. Only then will we reach the hearts of the people. There were many speakers at the lectern who spoke about their country's successes in economic policy. Overall, Europe is well on its way. That is why we can also underline that the initiatives of the European Commission, by Jean-Claude Juncker, have also led us to be economically strong. We will only win people if we also give Europe success. The third thing I would like to say about this methodical thing is that, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work she has done. Brexit has shown us that the "I want to have my sovereignty back" argument works, that it falls on fertile ground. That is why we need a new approach to build the bridge between the people and the European decision-making process. In my view, this does not require a new german-French axis, but a genuine European parliamentary democracy. This Parliament is the political map of Europe. Here sits your party, the CDU, here sits Syriza from Greece, here sits the National Front from France, liberals from Belgium, here all the political forces of this continent are united. And if decisions are taken here, when discussions take place here in the place of European democracy, then there must also be consequences. For example, a few months ago, this House decided to freeze the talks on Turkey's accession to the European Union for the time being, because the talks are difficult at this stage. I believe that this must have consequences in everyday life if this Chamber comes to such decisions in such bipartisan unity. And I would like to make one thing clear: Parliament is already a strong chamber, but it lacks a right, namely the right of initiative that every Parliament knows. We know that it is a great task to amend the Lisbon Treaty. That is why I would like to make it clear – as you know, I was nominated last week as the leading candidate of the European People's Party: if I become President of the Commission, I would like to promise that legislative initiatives of this European Parliament will also be presented by the Commission in the future, an indirect right of initiative of the European Commission's commitment that this Parliament will have the right of initiative that it then needs. (Strong applause) Last but not least, Europe needs ambition. I grew up politically in the 1990s. There was Helmut Kohl's chancellor, who told the Germans: we are abolishing the Deutschmark and introducing the euro – a not popular topic in the Federal Republic of Germany at the time. He did it because he believed in the future, because he thought over the decades. That is why I have sat in my seat today gratefully, because you have underlined the ambition for foreign and security policy. If we go in the direction of the European army, if we go towards 'unanimity, towards the principle of majority', then this European Union can not only become an economic giant that we already are today, but it can also turn this European Union into a political giant that can impose our values, our interests, globally. That is what we hope for, and that is why we would like to see good luck in your term of office of implementing these political objectives together! (Applause)

name: Udo Bullmann
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Chancellor, a warm welcome also from the Socialist Group here in the European Parliament, in the House of European Democracy! I would ask colleagues to understand when the German Chancellor speaks to us here that I want to talk about Germany for a moment before we continue to talk about Europe. Yes, it has been very impressive to see in the last few days how much dignity was thought of of the dead of the First World War – in Germany, in France, in Great Britain, in Belgium, everywhere where people have seen the traces of this global catastrophe, the trigger for the Second World War.  I would like to add: Yes, in Germany we also commemorate and have thought – the courageous men and women from Kiel who refused an order a hundred years ago. The sailors' uprising, the uprising of soldiers and sailors who refused to go into the oh so – thought the generals – decisive naval battle and thus set a fanatic for the end of the First World War. One of these important democratic moments in German history, of which we are proud and which we perhaps do not care enough about: the 1918 revolution, the speech by Otto Wels in 1933, with which the entire Social Democratic Group opposed Hitler's Empowerment Act from the fascists, 17 June 1953 in the GDR and, yes, the peaceful revolution of 1989, which was also a milestone in your personal experience and personal career. What I want to say is that we Germans must be aware of how closely the fate of our nation is linked to our homeland, with Europe, and that we must never forget this, and that it affects all peoples, but one thing in particular is that we cannot afford failure. And that we Germans, let me say this as a German Social Democrat, have no right to fail when it comes to Europe – much less than anyone else, with the background to our history and with the mandate for our future. This also means that any hesitation, every pettiness, is already leading us on the wrong track. I want to create a picture so that it becomes clear what I want to say, Chancellor; no one here in this room doubts your pro-European attitude. But I fear that the expectation is deeper, that Europe's expectation of us Germans is deeper: please bring in your strength to give Europe strength. That is the expectation of Europeans in Germany. This applies economically, it applies politically, and this also applies to the political debate, to the intellectual debate on Europe. Let me recall a picture from the recent past: it was Commission President Barroso from your party family who, in the face of the financial crisis, proposed that we pursue a Community policy, launch a Community initiative. What has come out – under pressure from Mr Schäuble, including your pressure – is, yes, an intergovernmental action, ending in the troika. We have had many debates here about why the results were not good in many respects, because they were not democratically controlled, because it did not control the European Parliament, because in many respects it was the policy of bureaucrats. We need to change that. I am in favour of us drawing two conclusions as soon as possible, and I would ask you to support this. Firstly, the Community method must be made strong. Only if the European House of Democracy is in charge will we be able to succeed in the future. (Applause) And secondly: yes, of course, we Social Democrats went into a coalition agreement in Berlin because we wanted to make Europe strong. The European part of the coalition agreement must be fully implemented as quickly as possible. This applies to the European Monetary Fund, to the deepening of economic and monetary union, to the fact that Germany must take the lead in climate protection, and this also applies to the fact that we are making progress in social policy – for example, in the framework directive on reliable working conditions – that the mandate is not blocked by the European People's Party, but that we can make it clear to precarious workers that we are able to make clear to precarious workers. where Europe stands and that it helps them. Unfortunately, these days, we no longer know enough what the European People's Party stands for. We no longer know for sure: is it the European People's Party of President Juncker? Is it – and this will also be a problem for Manfred Weber – is it the European People's Party of your European policy speech? Or is it the European People's Party of Mr Kurz, the President-in-Office of the Council, who is currently in the process of taking part in the United Nations Migration Pact. Turning our backs on what I find disgraceful and what will be a major step backwards, including for Europe, that makes heavy war equipment come up on the border with Slovenia? Or is it even the European People's Party of Mr Orban that is equating the media, driving the European university out of his country and railing against refugees? (Applause) What does this great party of Konrad Adenauer and Robert Schuman stand for? What is it worth, and where is it in political discourse?  I would like to point out that we must all invest courage and all our strength in advancing Europe – the sustainable, the solidarity, the just Europe, in which everyone finds their chance and their opportunity. I would like to say that for the men and women of my group, Europe is not a stain on the map. For us, Europe is a state of mind, it is a commitment to freedom and democracy and tolerance. I thank you and I wish you luck and success at work. There is still much to be done.  (Strong applause)

name: Ryszard Antoni Legutko
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would like to say to Madam Chancellor that it is a privilege for us to have her here. Madam Chancellor, you are certainly one of those politicians who has had a decisive influence on what has been going on in Europe, not only as a leader of a very important nation, but also as a remarkable personality. But, precisely because of your exceptional status I’m taking the liberty of sharing with you some of the concerns that I have about the European Union. You are a very powerful person. You make the basic decisions in Europe. You anoint people for top positions within the EU. Even here in the European Parliament, when you want to do something that your government does not like – like stopping Nord Stream or curbing Jugendamt – there are always innumerable obstacles popping up and, in the end it turns out to be extremely difficult to do anything about it. Even if we can do something about it, then it is ignored by your government because your government can afford to ignore it. This power spills over. When I talk to some of my German colleagues here, I usually hear them sermonising. That’s very common here in this Chamber. I would say I hear them pontificating from the position of heavyweight moral champions, which they consider themselves to be. All this is true but, in real terms, I think your political family is playing second fiddle in European politics. Interesting as your speech was, I cannot resist the feeling that 95% of what you said could have been said by Martin Schulz, a politician now largely forgotten, but he was once a big man here. He was pushing this Chamber to left, being seconded by the European People’s Party. The truth is, Madam Chancellor, that the European Union has been hijacked by the left, which has imposed on it its ideology, its political agenda and even its language. To personalise it somewhat, we have just heard Mr Bullmann of the Socialists and Mr Weber of the PPE Group. If you cut out two or three sentences from what Mr Bullmann said, they could have exchanged speeches and nobody would have seen the difference. I can say more. I can imagine Mr Bullmann being the chairman of the EPP and Mr Weber being the chairman of the Socialists, and it wouldn’t make the slightest difference either. I would say more: I can imagine Mr Verhofstadt taking both positions. (Laughter) It wouldn’t make a difference. Perhaps the only difference would be that there would be more insults flying around. So much for diversity. The immigration crisis, which cost you so dearly, Madam Chancellor, is just the tip of the iceberg. I will not be telling you about the tradition of German Christian democracy – you know more about it than I do – but what happened to it? Where has it evaporated to? The portrait of Konrad Adenauer in your office is not enough. Where is your Christian democratic vision of what Europe should be like? Why is it that you and your political family passively observe while the EU has been turning into a political bulldozer of social engineering? This creeping centralisation, these so—called harmonisations through the back door, and the more and more obscure power structure. The bigger the institution you make, the more power structures become obscure. That is an elementary truth about politics. Everybody knows about it. The abysmal arrogance of the EU officials, the awful ideology oozing from almost every document written in a horrible newspeak, new strange institutions, chronic violation of the treaties, all this supposedly leading us to a radiant future of Europe. But this radiant future is a left-wing fantasy, and I do not want to live in a left-wing fantasy. I am sure, Madam Chancellor, that you do not want to live there either even if it is ruled by heavyweight moral champions.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Mr Legutko criticised us because we– Mr Bullmann, Mr Weber and myself – have from time to time the same pro-European opinion. Well, I’m proud of this pro-European majority that exists in this House, Mr Legutko. I am proud of that, to be part of it. You have spoken for six minutes and I don’t even know what your position is in the meanwhile, in those six minutes; the only thing I know is that you are against Europe, but that was not new, that’s every time when you interfere. Chancellor, the last time that a university was closed in Europe happened 75 years ago. That was in November 1943 and it happened in Norway, where the University of Oslo was closed, officially because a part of the building was burnt. But the reality was that the occupying Nazi authorities were determined to suppress the continuous calls for autonomy and for academic freedom by the authorities of the university. That happened 75 years ago.  I am telling you this story, Ms Merkel, because in two weeks’ time from now, and that will be on 1 December, the same risks happening in our own European Union again; this time not in Oslo, but in Budapest, in Hungary, where a reputed university, the Central European University, the CEU, will be forced to close its doors and everybody knows why: because this is part of a personal crusade, even full of coded anti-Semitism, of a man, Mr Orbán, against another man, the founder of the university, namely Mr Soros. I have a question for you. My question is: when will you and your colleagues in the Council finally put an end to such shameful and scandalous behaviour in a value of the European Union?  (Applause) And I do not ask you this question to make it difficult for you, but I ask you this question because I firmly believe that more than migration – and that’s an important issue – more than the next financial crisis, more even than Putin, I think, that this threat from within undermines today the European Union. And we already had a fatal division in the past between north and south during the euro crisis. We already had this wound of Brexit, that still is a wound, and now we risk an even more devastating split between the east and the west, going back in fact a little bit to the Iron Curtain and to the Berlin Wall. Allow me to say – because I want now to come to the role of Germany in the European Union, because it’s about the future of the European Union that we are talking – that since the fall of the Berlin Wall and the reunification of Germany we have made progress: the euro, for example, but not so much more. Because since the reunification of Germany, it is true that Germany has become the most powerful Member State of the Union: most powerful in population, most powerful in the economic realm, but, naturally, with more economic power, more political power comes also more responsibility, and certainly European responsibility. Precisely there I think that since 1990 Germany hasn’t always assumed fully this big responsibility, if I may say so. In a certain way I understand too what happened, as the country was preoccupied with something so historical and so emotional as the reunification of the country. The integration of a bankrupt communist state into the Bundesrepublik – and that was an enormous endeavour – and by doing so all the energy, all the efforts went to this new gigantic task. But by doing so – and that’s my message that I want to give, Chancellor – by doing so, the more traditional, the more – how shall I put it – post—war German ambition so typical for Adenauer, so typical for Genscher, so typical for Kohl, to build always an ever closer union on this continent, lost traction and also energy. The debate in Germany on Europe, if I may say so, and it is not a criticism, it’s a fact, narrowed far too much down to a discussion about what? About Kompetenzabgrenzung, I remember many of the discussions with your predecessor, Mr Schroeder, or about Steuern; that was the debate in Germany, Steuern – taxes blasting in. So two weeks ago, Chancellor, you announced that after this mandate you will quit politics. But let me encourage you to use, nevertheless, the period and the coming months and the coming years. Why? Well to put Germany back on track, I think, towards this ever closer union. And I think your intervention of today is certainly a step in that direction. We need a leap forward again with Europe. We need the re—launch of the project so that we can face the challenges of the world of tomorrow. It will be a world in which, in a certain way, we will be on our own: facing the Chinese, facing the Indians, facing the Russians and sometimes facing the Americans when it concerns trade, for example, in their war. So, Ms Merkel – and this will be my conclusion – you can do that. We know your strength. We know your courage. We have seen that courage during the migration crisis. You have a unique chance to achieve it now, to make this leap forward in Europe. Why unique? Because there is a President of the French Republic – Emmanuel Macron – who is also a convinced European, not in the traditional French approach. You know what the traditional French approach is: “Vive l’Europe, pourvu qu’elle soit française”. Not in that way. He outlined a European project in his Sorbonne speech and my message to you, to both of you in fact, is: embrace this vision, join forces, revive the European dream as mirrored in that emotional image of both of you three or four days ago in Compiègne, holding each other in a tender but powerful embrace. You showed there, Ms Merkel, the whole world how immensely beautiful also this common European project is and I wish you a lot of success in this. (Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: Please keep to the timetable allocated to you because they are quotas for the groups. If the group leaders talk more, the members of the group talk less.

name: Ska Keller
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Chancellor, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work she has Thank you and thank you for coming to Strasbourg to participate in our discussion on the future of the European Union. I must go back to Mr Verhofstadt – and I am happy to do so – because I too would like to remind you of what a great gesture of reconciliation you have sent in recent days. You reminded – together with Macron – that we had the 1918 ceasefire, that this ceasefire ended one of the greatest disasters, and that the European Union is the greatest peace project in the world. Together in the European Union, we have broken down walls and united the countries of Europe. We have fought for freedom and democracy and overcome national blinkered thinking. Europe is very close to our hearts for us, but it is important for us. We want a strong and a united Europe, a Europe in which we all fight together and constructively for our future. We want a Europe that protects human rights and defends the rule of law with all the necessary consistency. Europe must be strong against the enemies of democracy, against the resurgence of right-wing nationalists. We want a Europe that promotes social cohesion and offers people jobs and prospects. We also want a Europe that taxes large digital corporations at least as much as the baker around the corner. We want a Europe that is committed to peace in the world and stops exporting arms to Saudi Arabia. We want a Europe that puts itself at the forefront of climate protection and protects our livelihoods.  This future of the European Union, Chancellor, is also in your hands. Unfortunately, however, the Federal Government, your Federal Government, is consistently on the brakes when it comes to Europe. For example, the climate crisis – one of the greatest challenges of our time, if not the greatest one. We are destroying the planet on which we live, and the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has just written this into our family book. In a few weeks' time, the EU will have a duty in Katowice to move forward, because this is the last decade in which we can still change course. But the objectives to date are far from sufficient. Two things that we urgently need to address now: this includes a minimum price for CO2. Some Member States are already considering whether they can move forward together. I ask: will Germany, will the Federal Government participate? This means that car manufacturers urgently need to reduce the CO2 emissions of their fleet. Unfortunately, however, Germany has ensured in the Council that the Council burys an ambitious target. Does this look like the German contribution to climate protection? Because the climate cannot be saved with vague declarations of intent and glacier photos. We need concrete, ambitious targets for Europe and rapid implementation. Instead, the Federal Government has simply buried the climate targets it has set itself and is the brake on European climate policy. This is a real disaster for Europe, for the coasts and for the island states, for the whole planet. To be sure, Germany is not the only country in the EU with a climate reality problem. But it is the greatest, with the greatest responsibility, and that weighs heavily. The fact that Germany is constantly violating European environmental protection laws, such as clean water and clean air, underlines the problem.  Climate protection and renewable energies also help to become energy-independent. A natural gas pipeline from Russia to Germany, on the other hand, cements dependence on fossil fuels and harms the interests of Poland and Ukraine. No one needs this pipeline – except perhaps Gerhard Schroeder and Vladimir Putin.  (Applause) Another example: the eurozone. We have known for eight years that the eurozone is not as stable as it should be. What has happened since then? Half a banking union, little stability pact and, sorry, a relatively small investment fund. He can still grow. That is simply not enough. In any case, with social cuts, they will not stabilise the currency area, but will only divide Europe. The European Parliament has said what to do. The President of the Commission has made proposals, and so has the French President. You don't have to like them all, okay. But to bury your head in the sand and hope that this somehow settles itself is apolitical, and that is irresponsible. The next crisis is already pre-programmed. Why not finally sit down with Macron and the other colleagues and put forward a reform proposal for the eurozone? Why is the federal government dumb? This is about the future of our entire Union.  And still such a Example: Tax justice. Here, too, the federal government is blocking. Together with the governments of the last tax havens in the EU, such as the Netherlands, Luxembourg and Austria, you are ensuring that the urgent transparency in the tax system does not come. They ensure that corporations can continue to exploit tax loopholes and that Member States lose EUR 17 billion in revenue each year. We must finally put an end to this obstructionist attitude. Move forward for real climate protection, for a stable eurozone and for an end to tax fraud. If the largest Member State is on the brakes, then we are not making any progress. We need a new start for Europe.  You said that it is worth working for Europe. If you are serious about this, then act! Right now, otherwise you will not live up to your speech. Europe needs impulses and people to move forward – large and small, symbolic and practical, courageous and determined. (Applause)

name: Gabriele Zimmer
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Chancellor, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work she has One hundred years after the end of the First World War and more than sixty years after the signing of the Treaty of Rome – last year – the process of European integration should actually have progressed further, at least to the point that, as you said, national selfishness, self-aggrandism in Europe are excluded. And I would like to add: another bloodshed. I am not sure that this will be an automatic way. When we talk today about the need to revive the European dream, I say: yes, but please so that the European dream does not turn into a nightmare. That is why I would like to say a few other points on some of the points that I would also like to criticise here on behalf of my group, because the reality is different from what you have just described here. You know the line, Chancellor, 'Resurrected from ruins and facing the future'. As a lesson from both world wars of the last century, the deaths of millions of people, war must never again start from German or European soil. "Creating peace with fewer and fewer weapons", "swords to ploughshares" – did these demands not relate to any kind of arms race at any time? In your 13 years as Chancellor of Germany – I am sorry to ask you this – what have you really done in order to stop German and European arms exports to crisis and conflict zones? In case of doubt, the interests of the arms companies always take a stand above values such as human rights and also democracy. And I would also like to contradict you in the following and to say clearly: please do not follow Macron on the way to a European army, to a military union! Keep in mind that many other EU states are more relaxed than Germany can ever be allowed to. For Germany, the parliamentary reservation applies, and that is a good thing. The fact that it could be used again and again and became an effective instrument is thanks to the peace movement in Germany, in Europe, but also to the Greens, the Left and the Social Democrats and many others, and this is not automatically transferable to the EU. We call on you to do much more politically and diplomatically to preserve and extend existing disarmament agreements between the superpowers. It is up to you to stop German arms exports and to reach EU agreements so that weapons are not supplied from EU Member States to military conflict zones. We call on you to finally allow social union. It is just wrong, as you said a few years ago, that social policy is exclusively national policy. If we do not manage to create a social union instead of a military union, then we may also have further consequences, and then Brexit will not remain. Personally, I do not want that. Mrs Merkel, you have taken up the post as climate chancellor. We are talking about minimum ecological standards. We call on you to break the deadlock in the Council! This applies to everything that has been mentioned so far. I would also like to point out that we expect the Federal Government to play a different role in country-by-country reporting. The point here is that we finally oppose tax avoidance, tax fraud by large corporations, and that we free up money for the tasks that are actually necessary. They have replaced the Community method, which includes Parliament, with the so-called intergovernmental method. It has been essentially your share. We call on you to undo this. Make sure that the European Parliament is co-answering for these tasks, that it does not simply depend on what agreement can be concluded between two states, one of which may be dependent on the other. This does not strengthen democracy, it does not strengthen confidence. There is no excuse for dealing with Greece, Mrs Merkel. And even if Wolfgang Schäuble took on the role of Mephisto, they let themselves be distracted from the right path and watched life in Greece be destroyed. Austerity policies and austerity dictates have been Mephisto's magic potion. The blackmail of sovereign Member States and massive interference with fundamental democratic social rights have put people in existential need. This has led to a massive loss of confidence in recent years. And I would like to point this out to you: correct this! We need a halt to all forms of austerity. And with a view of Italy, I can only recommend: Yes, it made a proposal from the Bundesbank to issue compulsory bonds of the rich in Italy so that they can pay the debt there. A great proposal – redistribution, but please in all the Member States of the European Union! Then we no longer need to talk about whether the Maastricht Treaty or the fiscal compact will be respected, then we really will have a basis for freeing up money for education, for social issues, for much more that we need. Finally, on the refugees, you have gained a great deal of recognition worldwide by not closing the borders. But why, then, do you turn a blind eye today to dying in the Mediterranean? This can't be! You must work precisely to ensure that we have legal channels, that solidarity is actually provided in all the Member States, that we, as the European Union, really comply with the values that we have proclaimed, that we live them on a daily basis.

name: Nigel Farage
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I would like to say to you, Ms Merkel, that many of my Eurosceptic colleagues had been booing you this morning, but they shouldn’t be in a way because the British should be cheering you. Without you, we’d never have made it over the line with Brexit – and I want to thank you very much for that. And of course many of these Eurosceptic groups on the right, the centre and the left will come back here after the next European elections in huge numbers directly as a result of your immigration and asylum policy. Your ‘we can cope’ led to a huge migrant tide – indeed, a stampede – that came across the Mediterranean: young men coming from very different cultures, who were not going to integrate. Young men, none of whom would have qualified as being genuine refugees, and I think in many ways we looked at it in the referendum and we said that we don’t want to be part of an increasingly German-dominated European Union, and we certainly don’t want to pay the price for Ms Merkel’s errors. And I believe – having heard you today, and listening to senior French politicians over the last couple of days – that for us leaving the European Union is now indeed a liberation. It’s a European Union that we’re told is now to become an empire, a militarised European Union, an undemocratic European Union, a European Union that seeks to continually expand to the east. A European Union that has launched a new Cold War against the United States of America. A European Union that tries to rewrite history. And I think, a hundred years on from the Armistice, we should be genuinely worried. The idea that this new militarised Union is somehow a recipe for peace – I suggest you will sit back and think a little bit more carefully. Maybe you should all reread history: the European project was set up to stop German domination. What you’ve seen today is a naked takeover bid. (Applause in some quarters) So I think Brexit becomes a necessity after this. And for the rest of the countries: Ms Merkel, you’ve had a long, successful career, but your political decision to open up the doors unconditionally is the worst decision we’ve seen in post-war politics in Europe. Is it not time for you at last to admit that you were wrong? Is it not time for you to say to German communities and many others ‘I’m sorry for what I’ve done to you and the problems I have inflicted upon you for many decades to come’? (Mixed reactions)

name: Marcus Pretzell
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Madam Chancellor, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work she has done on this We have so much in place in Europe, and yet almost everything seems to divide us at the moment. Europe is the home of all our Christian-cultural homelands - the home of our families. Europe is home to a unique scientific society, the most successful economic model in the world.  Chancellor, you are a European past, and today and here you are saying Adieu. It is appropriate to tell you something about the future, because our aim is not a European empire, but a Europe of the fatherlands. German government policy has shaped the euro and economic union – in breaking stability criteria, such as the ECB's misuse of government financing, bank financing, and intervention in the budgets of sovereign states. In doing so, they have set a childishly naive morality of solidarity against economic reason and the principle of responsibility.  German government policy has shaped energy and transport policy. Whether you were trying to get out of nuclear and coal power at the same time, or now in the fight against diesel. In doing so, they have set childishly naive morality of resource conservation against science and the principle of moderate state governance. German government policy has eroded the foundation of Christian Europe, the family, through the invention of countless gender identities, through the application of the concept of marriage to any sexual communities, through the decoupling of children from their biological parents, by the state sovereignty over the classical parental task, moral education and many other acts of shame. In doing so, they have set the childishly naive morality and arbitrariness against the natural law and the Christian principle of the family. (Interjections) German government policy has tolerated, promoted and triggered the most powerful migration movement in recent history. It began with humanly understandable emotion. This was followed by a loss of control and overburden – the loss of control of state institutions, the loss of control of the education system, the security bodies, the social systems and the overburdening of the population. In doing so, they have set childishly naive morality of charity against social cohesion and the principle of preserving European cultures. Mrs Merkel, every single German, every European acts morally when he personally supports Greeks. Many have done so. Every German, every European acts morally when he conserving resources. Many do. Every German, every European acts morally without alternatives when he exercises tolerance for coexistence outside classical families. Almost everyone does. Every German, every European acts deeply morally when he protects people in need from persecution. Many do.  But, Chancellor, a state that saves states, a state that is responsible for fluttering and combats private transport, a state that declares all forms of human coexistence to be a family, a state that believes that it can help every human being in the world at any time, such a state suffers from megalomania. He overestimates his abilities, he supposedly protects everything and ultimately nothing at all. If, according to you, Europe is not to fall apart once and for all, but to become a model of success again, then economic and monetary policy must be shaped in the sense of a professor and not planned in offices, energy and transport policy must be thought of in Aeuropean europe and not longed for in metropolitan latte-macchiato kitchens, the Christian family image must be brought to the fore, instead of being felt by quota gender professors, external border identity and Christian culture are re-emerging. , instead of fantasising about cultural destruction.  Our Europe of foundations is built on responsibility, identity, Christian culture and science. Their heritage is shaped by destroyed institutions. Two Unions – and you can now listen well, ladies and gentlemen of the CDU – and two Unions leave you in a serious state – the European and the Christian Democratic. Others need to restore.
