My promise will not reassure them, but we are doing it. Europe will once again become free and conservative.

name: Martin Sonneborn (NI).
text: Mr President, Chancellor, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work she has I have to apologise, I have not prepared a speech at all. I only requested the speaking time, because otherwise it would have fallen to Udo Voigt of the NPD , ... (Applause) ... Moment, let me excuse it! I despise rogue small parties below 1%.  In this respect, I do not want to say much. We saw each other here for the last time at the farewell of Helmut Kohl. Now we see you at your farewell. I would like to give you the go: the more I see people who will follow you in the CDU in the coming months and years, the more sympathetic you become.  I would ask you if you go: hand over our country clean, that would be nice. And now you can go. (Interjections)

name: Angela Merkel
text: Federal Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany. Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, I would like to thank my fellow Members for their contributions to my speech and, with regard to Jean-Claude Juncker and Manfred Weber, who have once again mentioned the subject of the United Kingdom, I believe that it is extremely important in what spirit we accept and shape the departure of the United Kingdom. I regret the decision of the British citizens, but it must be respected. I have therefore thanked Michel Barnier and I can also thank Jean-Claude Juncker, because I believe that the spirit in which we do this will decide for decades to come how we can have a partnership. And Britain has made it clear through Theresa May that they remain part of Europe. There will be a variety of opportunities for cooperation in which we can work together. And that is exactly what we want to do. In any case, I say this for the German Federal Government. I would then like to briefly address a number of issues that have been raised. The one issue that is perhaps also one that is related to, Mr Legutko, is that Germany is a country with 80 million inhabitants and an economically strong country, that we may have to be more cautious than others when we represent our interests. But we also have interests. And we do not always agree with everyone, and they do not always agree with us. I would just like to point out that Germany – this is not a boastful piece – has about 90 cases before the European Court of Justice, and we have accepted all the judgments, even if we did not like them. We know that, of course, we also have differences of opinion. I know that even my friends in the GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats are far from in agreement on Nord Stream. Personally, I believe that we will use more gas to shape climate change, especially in a country like Germany, which will no longer have any nuclear energy in a few years' time and which, with its strongest energy pillar, renewable energies, is already making a considerable contribution to climate protection. But if we want to get out of coal, we will have to use more gas for a bridge time. And that means that this gas import should also be diversified. But we will not exclude Russia as a source. I am very much in favour of Ukraine not leaving as a transit country. But whether the gas we need more comes via Nord Stream, comes through Ukraine, comes through Turk Stream – it's always Russian gas molecules. Europe will not be able to become independent of Russian gas, but it can diversify its sources. That is why I can tell you that Germany will also build an LNG terminal in order to respond to other possibilities of gas importation when other sources dry up. But if we say that we can phase out nuclear energy, we should phase out coal, we are building natural renewable energies, then we also need a part, and that will be gas for quite some time. Secondly, there is a subject that has been raised here time and again: the Community method and the intergovernmental method. I would like to say that the Community method has been strengthened time and again by Germany and is being further strengthened. At the moment, however, we in the European Council are in a situation where it has been almost stated that the European Treaties can never be changed again. Let me tell you quite frankly that if we take this position, Europe will become, so to speak, a fossilised entity. A Community that needs to respond to new challenges must also be able to adapt its treaties to the realities of the world.  (Applause) That is why I cannot see that we are taking the view that we are not changing the Treaties. However, if we want to act at European level and the Treaties do not yet give competence, I have always advocated that the ESM be entered in the euro area protocol of the Lisbon Treaty. It does not depend on Germany, we can do that tomorrow. However, it is not easy to get a majority in the European Council for this. If we cannot do that, however, then we must also act as a precursor to community action. It would have been worse if we had done nothing at all about monetary union. And that is why one does not exclude the other. I strongly advocate that we do not take treaty changes as an end in themselves, but that we do not simply exclude them. Because if we were to do this at home and say, "We will never change our Basic Law again," then we would also be able to do so. nation-state that does not fulfil its responsibilities. This brings me to the point that you mentioned that whole groups seem to be interchangeable here. I think you know as well as I do that they are anything but interchangeable. But I do not know of any nation-state that is not based on a common platform such as a constitution or, in our case, a basic law that was adopted by a two-thirds majority or more, and which nevertheless argues about any legislative project within that common platform. And when it comes to the foundations of the European Union, fortunately there is a large group in this Parliament that agrees on the basics. That is the foundation of the cohesion of a community. There can then be an intense dispute about the design of the basic principles. Fortunately, whenever we talk about the basic principles here, there is still a majority. (Applause) Then on the subject: What role should Germany play? Look, you want two things at once. They want us to be the first, so to speak, visionary, with France, for example, but also, of course, to guarantee that the visions will also be a reality, so that the European Council will finally accept all of this unanimously by 28 votes, and soon 27 votes. And this area of tension between the vision and the feasibility among the Member States must not, so to speak, ever grow, but at some point it must also be realized what one is prepared to do. I may sometimes be a little reluctant to formulate objectives. I stand by this, however, because people in our home want what we say to be implemented in the end. When it comes to respect for the individual Member States, I must include in my thinking what is thought in these Member States and which is deemed possible by the respective political majority. Otherwise, vision and my own idea – I can imagine many other things, I have just talked about treaty changes – and what we then really deliver, fall apart. And that must be kept together. I would say that Germany has always played a role in this and will continue to play it, both to formulate ambitious goals and also to see that there is respect for others who do not always pursue the same things. This is also part of the European Union. And then there is a word about migration, because I also have a limited speaking time: we are all proud of our values, and that is what Europe is founded on. Article 1 of our Basic Law in Germany states: "The dignity of man is inviolable." Now there is a terrible civil war and a huge challenge on our doorstep by ISIS, by Islamist terror. Mrs Zimmer, just by one example of the Yazidis, I would like to tell you what the Federal Government was thinking when we were thinking: do we support the Peshmerga with weapons to prevent the destruction of a people, or do we not support them? We have decided, we support it, and I believe that was the right decision, even if it was not easy for us. (Applause) I would like to say to you further: we have now established a very close migration partnership with Niger. This is one of the poorest countries in the world. That is where the terrorists come from Mali, well equipped with weapons because of the failure of the international community in Libya, and then the terrorists of Boko Haram come from Nigeria. And I say to this president from Niger. You know, we could still imagine giving shoes to your soldiers. We could still imagine training them a little bit, but when it comes to arming their soldiers so that they can fight the terrorists, Germany is unfortunately not there. The World Bank is not there. We and everyone, including European development aid, have sometimes put their heads in the sand. So we don't get respect. I still think it is better that we support African soldiers who are prepared to fight their terrorists, but that cannot end with shoe equipment. That is what I am saying. (Applause) Or we say: this is what our French friends do. That is not honest. And now even more on migration. So we've had a civil war and we still have it in Syria. We have a terrorist Islam and we have six million refugees outside Syria and Iraq. These six million, or perhaps even seven million people, are being taken in by Lebanon, Jordan and Turkey. We have – and I said this in Germany at the beginning of this parliamentary term, also as my mistake, my Misjudgment, my failure , did not pay sufficient attention to whether these people in their refugee camps had at least one dollar for food and some form of education. And so the refugees came to us because they fought for their lives. And now the whole of Europe – 500 million people – has, in the end, of the six million Syrians and probably one or two million Iraqis – and I do not have that in my mind at this point – we have taken in one to 1.5 million people and helped them in a dramatic situation where many Europeans have been helped in other times. Do you really think that this is something that can, so to speak, lead us into inability to act? (Applause) We must, of course, ensure that we have died out of illegal migration, where people have given all their money to the smugglers, and that we get out of there. That is why I have concluded the EU-Turkey agreement and have been criticised a great deal for converting illegal migration into legal migration, in order to be told by the UNHCR which people we should help. That is our common objective. But we were not sufficiently prepared for it, and now we have to learn it. And that is why we set up Frontex, that is why we have the Sophia mission to save people, that is why we have a partnership with Africa, that is why we are building the coast guard from Libya, that is why there is a Libya conference in Palermo today. I only want the Europeans to develop a uniform Libya policy so that the poor do not constantly hear two different things. That is part of it. But it is clear that where we have not engaged ourselves enough, we cannot simply get off the field. I think that we should also say with our heads high: we have learned from our mistakes, we will do it differently in the future. And that includes the partnership with Africa. Now the last part with climate protection. I have already said something about the gas. We stand by our climate targets, we have made very ambitious plans for 2020. We will try to achieve as much as possible and really achieve our 2030 climate goals through a climate change law. Mrs Keller knows this too. Finally, perhaps I would like to conclude by saying that it was Wolfgang Schäuble in the G20 presidency who ensured that these tax avoidance matters were far restricted by an international agreement of the BEPS. This is currently being implemented. That is why I believe that Germany has made a very good contribution to this. (Applause)

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE).
text: Mrs Chancellor, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the excellent work she has done on this Thank you for keeping the European Union together with us for many years. I think that today's debate has already made it clear how necessary this is. In the run-up to today's sitting, we have seen how the Socialists partly blame you on Twitter for the fact that in many Member States the consequences of the euro crisis have not yet been overcome, which, above all, has caused the debt policies of many left-wing governments in the first place. We are grateful to you that, thanks to Christian Democrat policy on the one hand and solidarity on the other, the situation in Spain, Portugal and Ireland is once again much, much better, that the people there are doing well again. I would be grateful if we could also thank you together for the great role that your Federal Government has also played in these last few years.  Secondly, Guy Verhofstadt. He has raised many issues. We remember that he was the Liberal's front-runner in the backroom in 2004. He then became the front-runner in the top-of-the-line process in 2014, and now he wants to stop the top-of-the-line process. We are grateful to you for your clear commitment to Manfred Weber and we are grateful that we, together with you, bring more democracy and more parliamentarianism to the European Union and that the citizens have a choice here. (Applause)

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D).
text: Mr President, Chancellor, you have linked your name to the management of two crises that have destabilised the European edifice: the economic crisis in the euro area and the migration crisis. In both cases you preferred unilateral decisions and transnational solutions with a move away from the European acquis. We will not, Chancellor, have a common hope if we do not unite our fears. However, during your time the fears have multiplied, with the result that the only beneficiaries are the far right and the anti-Europeans. I would like to ask you, as a Greek, if you regret your management of the economic crisis in my country. My generation is well aware of the responsibilities of the domestic political system. However, you too are responsible for the fact that half a million Greek young people have left Greece because they cannot find work, because our country has very large demographic problems and because even today, after many years of memoranda and commitments, we have not seen the Greek economy really change in a more positive direction.

name: David Campbell Bannerman (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Chancellor for coming to the European Parliament. It feels a bit like being in the Bundestag today. French President Macron wants a real EU army – in his words – ‘to take on the USA’, and, as he says, Russia and China too. The French Finance Minister, Mr Le Maire, believes the EU must be an ‘empire’, in his words. So do you believe, as German Chancellor, in a new single European federal superstate or an EU empire?

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Chancellor Angela Merkel: trust and European values are really the key message in your speech, and for that I thank you. The cases of Lampedusa, of Aquarius, clearly show that what we need in Europe today is a common European asylum system based on humanity, on European values and on solidarity. The Dublin file is still blocked in Council, and I would like to ask you, what can you do during the days to come to unblock and enable us to deliver on a common European asylum system before the elections so that trust and solidarity – and even reconciliation – can remain a core message of the European institutions? I wish you all the best for your future, and I thank you for everything that you have done for this Union. (Applause)

name: Bernard Monot (EFDD).
text: Mr President, Madam Chancellor, your thirteen years in power in Germany have led the European Union to its economic, social and cultural dislocation. What history will really remember from your action is your unconscious and unilateral decision to open Germany to migrants, a decision supported slavishly by Mr Juncker. Since 2015, the European Union has taken in a total of 4 million young migrants, supposedly in the name of the right to asylum. In the Schengen area, in the absence of national borders, this wave of migratory submersion has spread throughout Europe and especially in France. Worse, soon will follow an exodus of tens of millions of so-called "climatic" refugees! This crazy Franco-German immigrationist obsession is disastrous for the security of Europeans, as in Cologne and at the Bataclan in Paris. This hegemony is also reflected in the economy. Your obsession with budgetary rigour translates into external trade surpluses on the backs of your eurozone partners, especially France and Italy. It has perverse effects: rising unemployment and falling purchasing power for European employees and pensioners, including in Germany. Mrs Merkel, after such a record, how dare you, with Emmanuel Macron, to give lessons in Europeanism and federalism to the patriots of all countries? Europeans don't like your politics. Also, if you try to be the next President of the European Commission, the patriots will block it!

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the vast majority of Italians, faced with the arrogance and harshness of the rules imposed by this German-led European Union, have the impression that they are in the same situation as those Italian military internees whose cause I had had the honour of pleading with you directly. I would like to ask you whether you do not think that the time has come to change the register and extend a hand to this Italy that stands up, that asks nothing of anyone, that only wants to solve its problems on its own, helping those who suffer, implementing not in words, as you do, but concretely solidarity with 5 million, perhaps 6, of poor Italians who have forced the rules of your authority to look for bread in the garbage. Thank you, Madam Chancellor.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: Mr President, Mrs Merkel, with your political journey so far and your actions as Chancellor of Germany, you have proved that you are one of the pioneers of so-called globalisation and have contributed greatly to the great suffering that is currently afflicting Europeans. No one can forget your statements in which you have invited millions of illegal immigrants and so-called refugees to enter Europe without a fight. No one forgets that you have been the leader of the attack on the traditional values of our societies and, above all, against the very concept of nation. You have consciously tried to replace the nation states with a multitude of supranational organisations, which in essence serve the interests of only large multinational corporations, which you yourself have served and continue to serve faithfully. No one can forget how you fought the Greek people during the economic crisis, for which you are also largely responsible. On the contrary, everyone sees that you are trying to take away almost all of the Greek public property, for the benefit of lenders and banks. Fortunately, however, your season is fast approaching its end. Soon, new political forces will repair the damage you have caused and undo your harmful policies. You, again, will see this change as a mere citizen and I hope then, in the end, that you will reconsider.

name: Lívia Járóka (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Chancellor for her speech and for the work she has been doing in the last few years.  Madam Chancellor, what I always wanted to highlight when your policies are discussed is that just before the European elections it is extremely important that we send the message out to the European pool – one fifth, every fifth citizen of ours – that this is not a two—speed Europe. In Eastern Europe, poverty has to be stopped to make sure that we will be a strong enough Europe to help those who you wish to see on your labour market. But there are so many Europeans waiting to work on your labour market, so please assist the Member States to use the money which is in their budget for poverty in the next eight months, because about 50% of the poverty money has still not been used. For the next MFF, please try to make sure that there is no budget line working on poverty inside Europe, and then we can turn to African poverty. We have very good insertion and integration models throughout Eastern Europe, but also in the Balkans and in your countries. I have been visiting a lot of refugee projects with Syrians, and I would like to ask you to speed up their employment, because they have been going crazy sitting at home for two years waiting to get jobs. On those who you are going to send back to Africa, please make sure that they get the same educational projects that we get in Europe. Also, because you are a very big border opener and we very often see you at Sopron, the European picnic: please make sure that, before you open up the big borders, you open up the small ones. Just to next to Austria, Hungarian workers have been standing at the border waiting to go to work every morning for the last three weeks. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Presidente. –
text: Please keep to the timetable allocated to you because you take them away from members of your group. Mrs Járóka, you are Vice-President and you spoke for two minutes instead of one.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Chancellor, I give you two italian references. Italy, still convinced today that it is a proud founder of the European Union, believes that it is even better to believe that we can grow together, that we can grow again together with Europe and not against Europe. Italy is much more than its current bad financial manoeuvre. Italy believes in great works, believes in major investments such as TAV and TAP and believes in the peace generated by this Europe. Of course, he believes that the foundation of this continent is the production capacity that it has always represented, to put it simply. The heart of Europe is certainly much more Bavaria and Lombardy than the port of Rotterdam, although it is important. We are a country of producers, before we trade, and the Commission must remember this. Well, for all these reasons, I would like to join in the words of Mr Bullmann, who said: 'Germany cannot afford the luxury of losing and failing over Europe'. Well, Italy cannot fail on Europe either and can play with the peace that Europe has generated.

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to the Chancellor that we are now celebrating 70 years of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, and I noticed that she herself had expressed doubts about whether such a declaration could be adopted today in the atmosphere we have. Madam Chancellor, to quote you, you said: ‘I fear not’, and I would like to ask you how to deal with the autocrats that are surrounding the European Union who don’t care about this declaration; how to deal with the threats within it (that has been mentioned many times in this discussion); and I wish you had said something about your own political family that seems to tolerate illiberalism and populism and nationalism. Is it not something that we should address, because if we don’t start at home, how can we defend universal human rights in the world?

name: Jo Leinen (S&D).
text: Madam Chancellor, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the We both come from the same country. We know the mood and the debate in Germany. Ever since I have been making European policy, I have always heard that Germany is a paymaster in the European Union. We know that this word can be very poisonous. It also shows reflexes that we are more defensive against new ideas and always say: how much does this cost us? What, you would say, must we also tell the Germans that we are the winners of European unification? I would think that, especially before the European elections, we need to go on an offensive again in order to convince the citizens that we really benefit. Others too, but we in particular. I see that against many proposals, such as deposit guarantee funds, bank resolution funds, unemployment reinsurance – no matter what ideas come – the Pavlovian dog is coming immediately: this costs money, this is a transfer union, we do not participate. You have called for solidarity. We must then also go along and not always refuse. (Applause)

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to the Chancellor that I listened carefully to her speech. Madam Chancellor, you said ‘tolerance’15 times. That’s very good. You said ‘solidarity’ ten times. That’s very good. But you never said one word, ‘austerity’. You know that austerity policies are undermining democracy in Europe. They are provoking anger, frustration and insecurity. This is why the extreme left is rising. Your policies are, unfortunately, creating a Frankenstein. We need Europe. We need more Europe, but we need more social Europe and we need more justice in Europe. That is how we will have democracy.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I would like to address the Chancellor.  Madam Chancellor, the German people have been very unfortunate in their leaders. Twice already in the last hundred years, they have plunged Europe into disaster. German militarism caused the First World War, destroyed the nations of Europe and ushered in Communism. The Second World War brought levels of depravity never seen before in Europe. Now you’re bringing about disaster for a third time. European political and economic integration is disastrous but, worse than that, you have opened up Europe’s borders to untold millions of migrants. Your decision to open Europe’s borders to indiscriminately import millions of people will do untold damage to European societies for generations to come. The never—ending process of European integration will destroy democratic nation states. If Britain had a Prime Minister with any guts or backbone, we would have left long ago. Exit cannot come fast enough.  (Applause in some quarters)

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: Mr President, I pressed the button after my neighbour, Mr Voigt. Would you not rather give Mr. Voigt the floor?

name: Presidente. –
text: I decide who should speak. So if you want to talk, intervene.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: Mr President, I regret this because everything has been done so that my colleague can speak. I'll be very brief. Madam Chancellor, you talked about human rights. There are hundreds, if not thousands, of people in your country who have been prosecuted and convicted of crimes of opinion, of whom I do not necessarily share the convictions. Recently, because she does not believe in the dogmas that were imposed after the Second World War, a 90-year-old woman was incarcerated. This is Mrs Ursula Haverbeck. Today, a man with gangrene in both legs is dying in prison.  This is lawyer Horst Mahler. Do you not believe, Madam Chancellor, that these two examples unfortunately refer us to the darkest hours of your history, to those dictatorships that are claimed to be fought with these excessive condemnations?

name: Herbert Dorfmann (PPE).
text: Mr President, Chancellor, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work she has I can underline everything you have said today.  I am South Tyrolean. You know the country. You know how important the Schengen Treaty is to us. You know how important it was for us that the Brenner border, which was closed 100 years ago, was reopened by Europe.  That is why I am appealing: your country has been controlling its southern border for years. If people are stuck in traffic jams every day because they have to wait for them to be controlled, they will no longer believe in Europe. If, after 25 years of being used to free borders, people who want to go over to shop or work are suddenly stuck in traffic jams again, they will not believe in Europe. So we do these little things.  Let me just ask you to be courageous, stop this farce. You know full well that this is of no use for security. Most border points are open. Illegal smugglers will not drive over the few that are checked. I think it really is time to bring border controls between the Federal Republic of Germany and Austria back to the past. (Applause)

name: Dennis Radtke (PPE).
text: Mr President, Chancellor, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work she has done on this Thank you very much for your really valuable speech and for your clear words. Your speech will actually be even more valuable in the light of the scope of the debate that we have had to experience here – let me be clear. Here, former SED cadres talk about the GDR national anthem, here adulterers talk about morality for five minutes, and Mr Farage made it clear again this morning that he is always the first at the bar in the morning, but the last when it comes to bringing Europe forward. That is why I can only say that your words were all the more valuable. I would like to see only one thing – in addition to the important issues for the future that you have raised here today: please also focus on the issue of the European social market economy. The developments that we are seeing on the labour market, not only at home in Germany, but in the European Union as a whole, are really worrying in many places, and I would be very pleased if you would also use your remaining term of office to bring this important issue forward once again.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to the Chancellor that I was really impressed with her recent statement at the Kristallnacht commemoration, and I join in with your warning, Madam Chancellor, that political violence and extremism must be stopped at the roots, at the first sign of anti-democratic action and hate speech, before they get a chance to destroy our democracies or lives.  Regarding today’s dangers overshadowing the EU’s future however, I must say that you and your wider political family, the PPE, have failed in this by missing the chance to stop Fidesz and halt Orbán’s anti-European and anti-democratic illiberal political course based on corruption and inhuman government. I am a Hungarian Socialist; I know our duties, but it is my urgent plea to you, Madam Chancellor, to use your full political weight in the European Council and your important leverage within your political family to help clear this picture by distantiating your party from Fidesz and condemning, and hopefully ending, Orbán’s illiberal political search in Europe.

name: David Coburn (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I would like to ask you, Ms Merkel, if you think that it is a good way to thank our American friends after liberating Europe, liberating France and helping Britain and liberating Germany? Do you think it is a good way to thank them by insisting on a European army, and remarks by President Macron, which were both unhelpful, that were taken awry by the American President? Is this the way we should be treating them? And do you think that Mr Putin will take any European army that does not include the Americans or the British remotely seriously?

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Mr President, Chancellor, you have referred to the future of Europe and I am trying to identify what Europe you are talking about. For the one you have destroyed - every day the results show - at your enormous responsibility? I will not refer to what you have committed, because everyone knows it. I will confine myself to what you did in my country, Greece. Wanting to take away Greece's wealth, you destroyed the economy and impoverished the Greek people. The ancient Greeks, Mrs. Chancellor, when they wanted to refer to someone who found that he had made a mistake and wanted to make amends, they said the phrase "the eater and heal" (the one who hurt and wounded you, he and will heal you). If you really feel the crime you have committed against Greece and want to cure it, you will have to reduce our country's onerous debt by taking into account the funds from the occupation loan and the war reparations. If you do not do this, you will often remember, because of the determination and reaction of the Greek people, the poem entitled "Damn Greek", which some people say - without being certain - that it has been composed by your great compatriot, the poet Friedrich Schiller.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE).
text: Mr President, Madam Chancellor, thank you for being with us. I will talk about the taxation of the digital giants, which you alluded to. I believe that this is a measure of fiscal justice that is highly anticipated by our fellow citizens who do not understand this feeling of impunity for the most powerful, this feeling of double standards, two measures that fuels the resentment that populists feed on.  This is a real power challenge for Europe. It is a question of showing our fellow citizens and the rest of the world that Europe is not naïve and that it knows how to impose its rules. It is a demonstration of unity, but Germany blocks, hesitates, procrastinates. You yourself, Madam Chancellor, have told us that you are waiting for an international solution. That means nothing will happen. This is a huge responsibility, because the taxation of GAFA, even symbolic, would be one of the measures that would silence the critics of a powerless Europe. Madam Chancellor, do you not have another solution?

name: Paul Rübig (PPE).
text: Mr President, Chancellor, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work she has I am proud of my EPP family. We signed the Roaming Directive here in the European Parliament on 27.6.2007 during the German Presidency. At that time, we signed roaming with Reding, Niebler, Pöttering and Barroso. I have to say that we had a price of 0.49 cents per minute at the time, but today we have 0.19 cents in discussions from our Member States to others. I have to say that the first complaint came in 2006 under Wolfgang Schüssel and that the Roaming Directive was the shortest directive of the European Union, that within seven months it succeeded from the Reding proposal to its implementation in all Member States. That is why it is important that we now help shape the digital global market. I think it's important that we're at the forefront of 5G, artificial intelligence and fiber – Invest EU, COSME. and the Connecting Europe Facility with Horizon 2000. Please help us to set corresponding goals in the multiannual framework program here.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: Willyou, Madam Chancellor, I would like to welcome you to this debate on the future of Europe. To debate the future of Europe is to respond to the wishes of 500 million citizens, but it is also to defend the planet, the future of the planet, its sustainability, the fight against inequalities, less poverty, better trade agreements. I have often been at odds with you, but I know that you are a convinced Europeanist and a profound advocate of European values. I know that you know that the European Union, in order to be strong in the world, must be cohesive and convergent internally. To do this, we need, Madam Chancellor, to be ambitious and make the euro zone a balanced and resource-owning monetary area.  I said here: tolerance is the soul of Europe, but if tolerance is the soul of Europe, convergence is its body.  What are you going to do, Chancellor, to help reform the eurozone and strengthen the European budget?

name: Esther de Lange (PPE).
text: – Thank you, Mr President, and before I ask my question to the Chancellor, I have to get something off my chest and it regards our colleague in seat number 20: Mr Farage. I would say to our guests, don’t take his grandstanding too seriously. This is a man who actually led his country, led his party, to a Brexit vote, only the next day to admit that he lied and tricked and jumped ship to leave his party. This is not leadership. It’s a circus. Secondly – I’m glad you’re here Mr Farage – he says he doesn’t want to be part of a German European Union, yet he has made sure that two of his children have German passports. This man wouldn’t know hypocrisy if it stared him straight in the face! Mevrouw de kanselier, u heeft gesproken over een Europees leger. Kunt u de mensen in Nederland geruststellen dat het dan niet gaat over een Europees leger, maar over een leger van Europeanen? Dat het een nationaal besluit blijft om mensen uit te zenden, maar dat we inderdaad veel verdergaand moeten samenwerken?

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Chancellor Merkel, you come here to visit us in the European Parliament, at a very important moment in your political career and at a critical time for Europe.  Now that he has announced that he will begin to leave his responsibilities at the helm of his political party and then, at the head of Germany's chancellery, it is time to take stock of his mandate, which is also to take stock of the last decade in Europe.  And it's true that there are different ways to see what will leave your legacy, right? Moral, stoic leadership, a pillar of stability for Europe, or the last responsible for a negligent economic management of the sovereign debt crisis, and a wall in the face of the reforms that have been needed.  And his legacy, how will it go to history? It will depend on what you do in the time you are in charge over the next few years, whether you will be able to lead the reforms in the euro area on migration and on foreign and security policy to integrate and force a united and strong and just voice of Europe in the world.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Chancellor, I have always appreciated your commitment and have always achieved very, very strong and very important leadership in you. I believe that this is what is not the case in Europe. In my opinion, Europe cannot be two or three speeds. I believe that the Europe of the peoples must be transformed from a bureaucrat into politics, and I believe that the European Parliament's initiative, the role of the European Parliament, must have its own capacity to transfer an effective message.  I have heard of immigration, I have heard of the environment, I have heard of the army and common defence. I agree with everything. As far as immigration is concerned, I believe that Parliament has indicated a way out, but we are still in a stalemate. But since I am involved in international trade policies, I believe that the best response from Europe, for a People's Europe, both towards our company and towards our small and medium-sized enterprise, which very often fails to understand the mechanisms, language, strategy and objectives. I believe that, on the basis of our undertaking, there would be an extraordinary rapprochement in order to give concrete answers to employment.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it is very useful for you to come to the European Parliament, because that is why we do not have to tell you that the Trojan horse of the European Union is here too, in this House. And that is precisely why we demand from the European leaders a little more firmness, a little more conviction, a little more strength for us to drive European construction and not to be the ones to drive the destruction of Europe. And that is why what many of my colleagues have told you is very, very urgent. You have to unblock in the Council many of the measures that this Parliament , and in some cases also the Commission , has asked of you.  European leadership today is at issue precisely because there are absolutely powerful forces that have come to break what we have had so long to build. And you, Germany , you have already seen how many German spokesmen have spoken in this House - you have a special responsibility and we hope that you will do your job, in this historical case.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to address the Chancellor. Madam Chancellor, thank you for being with us and thank you for your leadership. We appreciate very much your efforts to bring a stronger Europe. In your speech, you focused on the need to have a common foreign policy here in Europe, and I very much share your views. In this context, I would like to ask you: what should we do, and how should our policy be shaped against Russia? We still have a situation where people are dying in eastern Ukraine. We are now in the fifth year of negotiating with Russia to implement the so-called ‘Minsk Agreements’. What is the recipe for making Russia more accommodative and more willing to take into account our expectations? What is your recipe to confront a more and more aggressive Russia here in Europe, and simply bring peace to Ukraine?

name: Angela Merkel
text: Federal Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which is I think the German Parliament would be very grateful if it could ask me more often in this length. We have now had over 30 questions, and it is, of course, quite impossible for me to deal with these 30 questions now, especially since I had also told the President that I had to leave the House at half past six. That is why I would just like to say very briefly: firstly, I am, of course, very pleased – and I expressed my indirect delight by mr Hallstein's quote – that Manfred Weber has been chosen as the leading candidate of the European People's Party and has also presented himself wonderfully there. I would just like to say this again, as a member of the party family, so to speak. (Applause) Secondly, I would like to point out that, for me, the word that Mr Leinen used, and which I do not want to put into my own mouth, is not a view of European monetary union and of our common budgetary policy. We Germans benefit from the fact that we have a Europe and, above all, we have a Europe that also grows closer together. That is why we are committed to cohesion funds, to structural funds. Nobody – I could say now, nobody knows better, but I do not want to say so – but I am deeply convinced, and we now see it in our own German history, through the merging of East and West, how important it is that we have cohesion and convergence. If we do not have them, people will also lose their enjoyment of Europe. The only question now is: how do we achieve this? Of course, political ideas are mixed up and divergent. I am very much in favour of the European social market economy. But the social market economy also says: I have to generate what I then distribute. If this balance breaks down, then no force in the world will be able to restore social security to people. If such a thing is out of balance, then countries must also take ownership. I know how difficult it was in Greece, how difficult it was in Portugal. But I believe that today we are all growing again, that we have put in place a major programme against youth unemployment, that the european employment agencies are now working together, that we in Germany have also provided vocational training for Greek young people and others, that we want to continue this aid. That must be the spirit. If we do not create really sustainable jobs, then we will have no chance of really building a good Europe. This also applies to Italy. We want to reach out to Italy. I say this explicitly. Italy is a founding member. But Italy has also adopted many rules, which we all have together as a legal basis. We cannot simply say that we are not interested in that now. That is why I am not going to say anything at all, but the Commission has an important task to do here. I hope that solutions will be found in discussions with the Italian Government, that is my fere hope, and that is what I said to Prime Minister Conte.  I would like to say something about the Hungarian criticism. Look, when there were very, very many refugees in Hungary, Viktor Orban asked the then Austrian Chancellor Werner Faymann, and he again asked me on a given day whether we were prepared to help Hungary and take in refugees. We should not forget this when presenting the history of migration. Should we leave Greece alone in an extremely difficult economic situation? Should we leave the countries of the Western Balkans, which have a European perspective, alone in their difficulty? Or, in such a situation, we should say: we must protect our external border – what we then did with the EU-Turkey agreement, but in between we must all bear the burden on each other!  That is why it must be said quite honestly that Hungary has not yet been able to protect its external border in 2015. I have never opposed Hungary's responsibility to protect external borders, never. I just found that Hungary couldn't, and because Hungary couldn't, others jumped in.  But now to be insulted every day for the fact that a request from Hungary to Austria and Austria to Germany is now also presented as if we had done something that was not right, I find that funny, and that is what we have to look at when it comes to presenting history. (Applause) Then there is a point on the subject of a two-speed Europe. I feel that many countries, especially from Central and Eastern Europe, are very concerned about this Have. The two-speed Europe is also a Europe in which Member States can decide whether or not to cooperate on a particular cause. The Schengen area is not shared by all the Member States of the European Union. That is the decision. Some cooperation in internal security is not shared by everyone. Not everyone has introduced the euro to date. We cannot now say to Hungary and Poland: you must now adopt the euro if you do not want it yet. That is why there is already a Europe of different speeds. What is important? There must be no closed shop. There must never be an initiative in which Germany and France and three others say that no other Member State should participate in this, but must always be open to all. And then it's okay, but then we already have a two-speed Europe today. Finally, with regard to Mrs Valenciano, I would just like to say briefly: look, we have, by and large, two approaches. One believes that together we can solve many problems – not all, but many problems – better. Not all problems have to go to the European Parliament, but many problems. And there is another group here in this Parliament that does not believe that. She actually sits here every day to make it clear that the nation states can do better on their own. Now it is a matter of not saying: you have to do this, and then I say again: you have to do that. But all those who are convinced that the multilateral project of Europe – European unification – is basically the right response to the lessons of history and the right response to the challenges of the future, all of whom must stand together in this basic conviction and fight with each other fairly and respectfully for the right solutions. That is our task, and I will continue to work for that. Thank you very much. (Sustained applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. – Dear Chancellor, first, I would like to welcome your long-term commitment towards EU and its values, especially towards European Integration and Cohesion. Your oftentimes proven diplomacy, reliability, and consensus-oriented pragmatism will be missed not only in Europe, but also around the world. Now that illiberal democracies, polarisation and policies of fear and exclusion threaten seriously our common project, it is time to address with courage directly what divides us. Europe needs ambitious reforms, including a strong reinforcement of the cohesion policy, as you have well advocated, that only a homogenous Europe could successfully compete with global powers such as China, Russia or the United States. I stress that Europe can easily come closer to its citizens by focusing more on policies where EU competences are limited but expectations are high, as health and education. In this way, we could provide practical responses to our citizens’ current concerns as well as eradicate populist and Eurosceptic propaganda within our territories.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. Chancellor Merkel, on 11 November 100 years ago, the signing of an armistice ended the Great War with its 18 million dead, the main causes of which were tensions between states, caused by economic reasons and exacerbated by widespread nationalist sentiment. After more than 70 years of peace, the "European project" born after 1945 is threatened by the rise of nationalism and populism. Regurgitated nazi fascism is manifested both in my country and in yours, as in the rest of Europe. The next elections will therefore be decisive for the history of Europe. European values and social solidarity are at the heart of the battle, but pro-European forces cannot continue to defend this Europe. Our citizens are calling for a Europe that can respond to their concerns. Many sensitive issues are on the table: from the reform of the asylum system to job creation, from the reform of the euro to the adoption of a uniform fiscal policy. You recently said that you would no longer run for chancellor again. My question is very simple: if not now, when?

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. – Chancellor, you have presented what Europe should be like. You spoke of solidarity, responsibility, respect for each other's rights, tolerance, the right to apply everywhere the same. Who could disagree with these things? You have a long political career, now you have declared that you are withdrawing, that is why I appeal to your sincerity. Do you think everything you said has been applied and applied? You are the main leader in the European Council and you know how many unfair decisions have been taken that violate exactly what you said! How can you explain the fact that there are two Europes, even though we have only one treaty? Why is the Schengen Regulation being violated with regard to Romania and Bulgaria? Do you not think that exactly the differential treatment, the arrogance of larger and older Member States -such as Germany, led to Euroscepticism? You were talking about migration and the need for a common asylum procedure, but don't you think this had to be thought of before it was allowed access without any control to migrants? I hope, Madam Chancellor, that at least now at the end of your mandate, you will propose solutions that will keep Europe united, not break it up. Loss of confidence recovers hard and sometimes, never.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. – It is of great importance when the leader of the largest, strongest and most populous state has identified solidarity as a fundamental value of the European Union. Very strong words for Angela Merkel towards a stronger and more united Union. She even proposed new procedures that would exclude veto power; security council as a new institution within the EU; to change the Treaties and the legal basis.  And what stood out most vividly, in keeping with Macron, was that it was time to truly think about the creation of our own European armed forces and European army. An extremely pro-European speech, with a very clear vision of a united Europe. A speech that, of course, was applauded for a long time, but I watched carefully whether any of the Greek politicians from Syriza would get on their feet. Yes, even they applauded Angela Merkel. This is a very strong finish and is very indicative of the evolution of some political forces in recent years.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: in writing. – Chancellor, you have mentioned the challenges before the Union and stressed that only together will we be able to overcome them. Economic development, job creation, defence, security and migration policies can only be implemented through the joint effort of the Member States. For this, for a strong Europe, we need an appropriate European budget. The European Parliament is voting tomorrow on the budget proposal for 2021-2027, with absolutely necessary allocations for all horizontal policies. The European Parliament is ready to work for this budget. There is, of course, a need for a decision in the European Council. That is why, please, Chancellor, to support a decision on the European budget in the European Council before the European elections.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: Writing. Chancellor, you have appealed to European solidarity. But for a successful future, Europe needs more than a German chancellor who has so far committed herself to austerity. We urgently need more European solidarity. Europe must invest in the future, in youth employment, research and education. Despite all the political differences, however, I appreciate your factual view of things and that you are a true European – even at second glance. Here I would like the Austrian pig thrower chancellor to learn a little more from you.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – In her presentation, German Chancellor Merkel was as lucid as usual but failed to clarify the basis of her priorities for Europe’s future. Among the three areas she listed wherein to develop greater European unity, came military defence and security. But which military threats are now looming over Europe? And if they exist, why did she during her terms in office, allow German military spending to remain well below the levels of her European partners? Indeed, is there uncontested support among European citizens for a military coalition that would be funded through EU budgetary resources? And is building a so-called European defence capability the right way to forge unity in Europe and combat a fading enthusiasm for the European project? I doubt it. Would it not be preferable for the EU to concentrate on coordinating security measures within the Union to cover terrorism, immigration and surveillance over organised crime? Mme Merkel also mentioned as another priority area the problems of immigration. But were not these aggravated on a European level by the decisions she singlehandedly and without consultation took to open borders in 2015? Unfortunately, the Chancellor failed to contest the growing perception that too many decisions in the EU have come to depend on German say-so.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. - In her opening speech, the Chancellor said that it was difficult to predict the future of the EU. She went on to say that individual, national decisions have an impact on the whole Community. In this context, I had questions for the Chancellor, but I did not get speaking time. My question would be: Mrs Merkel, you are a fierce supporter of sanctions against Russia. Therefore, how can you explain Germany's decision to cooperate with Nord Stream 2, where Germany in particular will have an advantage in this project? What position would you take if a similar project with Russia were negotiated by another Member State? In this context, how do you want to help Ukraine on its path to the EU? Do you not think that double standards are still applied in the common EU to the old and the new Member States? As an example, I would also cite the location of the medicines agency, where you made a decision in favour of the Netherlands, despite the unfulfilled conditions known in advance. I could give more examples like this. How to answer these questions to voters in next year's EP elections?

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. – For me, you are a symbol of a strong politician who has greatly influenced the stability and prosperity of the EU. Let me stop at the migration crisis, because it is not over, we will bear the consequences for a long time to come. You've commented on it, but I have to say, not enough for me. I think we need to call things by their real names, and that the EU has failed to stem the flow of illegal immigrants. Nearly 2 million immigrants in 3.5 years pose a security risk. People are afraid of illegal migration, for example, citizens and politicians in the Czech Republic refuse to show any solidarity with refugees, even a large part refuses to accept unaccompanied children. You yourself said today that Schengen is not possible without the protection of the EU's external border. Precisely because I respect you, it was very disappointing for me that you did not understand the need to combine solidarity and security. It wasn't until 2016 that priorities turned around, and so did you, who put security at the forefront. You have very rightly pushed for the EU-Turkey statement, which is ongoing but will need additional financial demands. We want people fleeing violent Islam, the Taliban and dictatorial regimes to adapt to our tradition of humanism, human rights, and the obligations that apply to all citizens. Freedom and solidarity cannot be without responsibility and security.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. – The power of European construction lies in THE UNIT and SOLIDARITY. Unfortunately, we are increasingly witnessing actions to discriminate against some Member States which will have the direct consequence of dividing the EU. European construction has been increasingly sought in recent years with challenges such as Brexit, terrorist attacks, immigration waves and populist trends gaining more and more ground. In addition, the double language that exists at European level, visions such as a multi-speed Europe, the sanctioning of Member States through unfair resolutions, the support of policies to make the granting of European funds a rule of law conditional, policies that affect the European states and regions that need this funding most, only increase the gap between Eastern and Western Europe. In view of all this, I ask you, Chancellor, what is your position on where the EU is going and whether such selfish actions by European leaders do not affect the future of the EU? As a Romanian MEP, I ask you if it is not time for Romania to be a full part of the Schengen area, and I ask you as an important EU leader to support this in the European Council.

name: Președintele. –
text: The next item is the joint debate on: - the report by Mr Andrejs Mamikins, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the implementation of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement (2017/2282(INI)) (A8-0320/2018) and - The report by Mr Petras Auštrevičius, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the implementation of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement (2017/2281(INI)) (A8-0322/2018).

name: Andrejs Mamikins
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, since the signature of the report in 2014 Georgia has undertaken substantial reforms for the successful implementation of an association agreement (AA). Its European path is now even enshrined in the constitution of Georgia and enjoys cross—party support. Unlike here in the EU, in Georgia there are no serious anti—European movements. Georgia has shown a good absorption capacity and between 2017 and 2020 the association programme has been supported with funds of between EUR 371 and 453 million. It is reflected in the report that the EU takes very seriously the oversight of this financial spending. I believe that Georgia is making enough communication efforts to guarantee that its citizens know about the projects realised with the help of the European Union. The AA has a very positive effect on EU—Georgia relations. It has allowed us to extend our political relations under the security dialogue so that now Georgia is even taking part in our CSDP missions. Georgia provides an example that the EU’s structural foreign policy really works.  Even if the EU is still silent on the concrete membership process, the Georgian side is really putting a lot of energy into it. Many say that Georgia has gone much further than other association countries in its ambitions and performance, and has made a series of ministerial reforms to achieve the objectives of the AA. That is why Georgia needs more highly—qualified personnel from the EU. They need our expertise in energy, in the environment, in safety standards and other fields. If you want our engagement in Georgia to be sustainable, we need to boost it with knowledge, not only with money. Georgia has achieved huge progress on many democratic issues, including free media and journalism. In the last five years the number of TV channels with nationwide coverage rose from 3 to 13. This is important considering that TV is still the major source of information for the people. In its judiciary reform, Georgia can already claim many achievements. Among them one can mention accessibility for the media, the removal of politicians from the High Council of Justice, the reform of the High School of Justice, and so on. The parliament is now working on further reforms of the judiciary to address disciplinary proceedings, caseload and other issues.  Recent constitutional reforms transform Georgia into a truly parliamentary democracy with strong powers in the hands of the parliament, particularly as far as its oversight over the executive is concerned. Georgia expects a transition to a fully—proportionate parliamentary election system in 2024. This will make political life even more vibrant, and the active engagement of civil society in Georgian policymaking is a good precursor of this new trend.  The report also reflects major improvements in human rights standards, and freedom of expression, freedom of assembly and of association are now protected much better than before in Georgia. Some challenges need to be tackled however. Let’s say that our current association agenda has to take account of the legacy of the previous government Georgia had since its independence in 1991. Therefore this report does not only contain an assessment of achievements but also provides concrete recommendations for further work. On a separate note, I would like also to underline that this report gives support to Georgia in its pursuit of peaceful conflict resolution and reconciliation. The report welcomes Georgia’s efforts to maintain constructive dialogue with Russia and supports its committed participation in the Geneva international discussions. My report proposes a decision to draw up such implementation reports on Georgia on an annual basis, and considering the recent positive dynamics I think that the next report will reflect even more achievements.  (Applause)

name: Petras Auštrevičius
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I wish to start by highlighting the importance of the very fact that this House has decided to evaluate and deliver its reports on the implementation of the association agreements with the associate partners of the European Union. These are Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. The deliberations and today’s and tomorrow’s vote on this report must be viewed as additional confirmation of the EU’s strong political commitment vis—à—vis best performance in the Eastern neighbourhood. In my capacity as standing rapporteur on Moldova, I hereby wish to dwell on the main findings and conclusions of my report. I will do so in all frankness and sincerity as a true friend of European Moldova. The EU—Moldova partnership is not abstract. The EU and Moldova are bound by a very solid and comprehensive association agreement document which contains a set of legal and political obligations. It is a partnership based on common values, and respect for democratic principles and fundamental freedoms.  This is exactly what worries me the most: a continuous and even deliberate back—sliding in relation to democratic standards in Moldova over the last couple of years. To begin with, I do regret that the Moldovan authorities choose to confront or even disregard the joint opinion and recommendations of respected European institutions – the Venice Commission and the ODIHR – as regards the recent changes in national electoral legislation. This House, as well as other European institutions, has been doing its utmost to explain to Chișinău that electoral legislation must not be tailor—made and changed a year before elections, bypassing civil society and other political actors in Moldova. I am very upset that the advice of the European bodies has not been taken into account. I must also say that the Moldovan authorities’ actions that led to invalidation of Chișinău’s mayoral elections earlier this year were very disturbing. Equally disappointing was – and continues to be – the lack of real progress and transparency in the investigation of a USD 1 billion bank fraud case. I wish to repeat our call in the report, namely that the findings and recommendations of the two independent Kroll reports must be published in full, and those responsible for the fraud must face real justice.  To continue, I wish to stress that the so—called fiscal reform package is giving us grounds for another serious concern. Our report states that this tax amnesty scheme is substantially doubtful, insufficient and lacks transparency – and sometimes even logic. For all the reasons mentioned above, I must say – and I am saying this with regret – that the  EU was left with no other choice in deciding to put on hold the macro—financial assistance and budget support programmes foreseen for Moldova. Moldova seems to be the first country, at least in recent years, that has had to face such strict conditionality measures from the EU side, resulting in the suspension of EU assistance. I am sure you will agree that this is a fact that speaks for itself.  Colleagues, in sending this message we continue to extend our hand of cooperation to the Moldovan authorities and civil society at large, in order to stay in close touch. In exchange, I believe we will reach our goal. Moldovans will understand that the only way forward is Europeanisation – meaning a comprehensive package of political and economic reforms.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I wish to start by thanking Parliament for its continued support for our eastern partners and helping associated countries to progress in implementing the reforms set out in the Association Agreements.  Before I enter into the specificities of the two countries, let me mention one very important element, a crucial part of our relations with these countries: our engagement with civil societies. The situation is different in the two countries, but they would like to thank the civil society partners that are monitoring the implementation of their Association Agreements. Their contribution is highly valued. I welcome the draft reports prepared by the Committee on Foreign Affairs and would like to thank in particular the rapporteurs Mr Mamikins and Mr Auštrevičius for their remarkable work.  Turning first to Georgia. The report demonstrates the achievements in progress made in particular regarding reforms related to the implementation of the Association Agreement and the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement. It also notes the positive trends in terms of closer links with the European Union, which is Georgia’s largest trade partner, representing almost one third of its total trade, as well as the most significant donor and the largest source of foreign direct investments. Relations between the European Union and Georgia are close today. As a tangible sign we will be hosting a high-level meeting between Members of the European Commission and of the Georgian Government in Brussels on 21 November, chaired by President Juncker and Prime Minister Bakhtadze. This meeting will provide a unique opportunity to discuss areas of future cooperation and driving the political association of economic integration process forward. On the EU side we will highlight the importance of working on the implementation and sustainability of reforms and increasing reform efforts in the area of law enforcement and justice. We will continue to focus our support on key areas for sustained growth in jobs with our programmes, and matching skills with the labour market and economic and business development. It is rightly pointed out in the report that some key structural reforms are still needed for a transparent and competitive economy that ultimately provides more jobs and economic perspectives for citizens. For instance, ensuring proper functioning of the labour market, an efficient social protection mechanism, strengthening economic governance and public financial management, and further improving the business environment and financial infrastructure.  These efforts will also be supported through our macro-financial assistance of EUR 45 million. Payment of the first tranche is still foreseen for this year if the Georgian Parliament ratifies the Memorandum of Understanding in time. Another area which requires further improvement is the system of checks and balances. Against this background, we have been working with the Georgian Parliament to strengthen its oversight function. For instance, we are supporting the Budget and Finance Committee on public finance policy reform and will continue to do so through a programme on governance and fiscal accountability which we are currently putting in place. Additional support for parliamentary oversight of the security sector is planned as part of an overarching programme on security and the rule of law. This innovative programme on security will address many of the key issues identified as crucial in the report such as, for instance, supporting the fight against corruption, organised crime and money laundering; strengthening the capacity of state institutions to prevent and fight crime; and enhancing integrated border management.  The actions foreseen also respond to the recommendations under the visa suspension mechanism. Very closely linked to this is the need for further reform in the justice sector, as also clearly highlighted in the report. We will focus our support on commercial justice, which is one of the few areas where Georgia still needs to undertake reforms. At the same time, effective implementation of human rights protection and anti-discrimination measures remain a challenge.  We are also fully committed to a policy of non-recognition and engagement with Georgia’s breakaway regions. Our approach is to include these territories in our sector support programmes in Georgia, where possible, as we are doing in the area of agriculture, rural development, for civil society, and for vocational education and training.  Furthermore, improving transport links and infrastructure, boosting energy resilience through strengthening energy interconnections, energy efficiency and the use of renewable energy is a main priority for our work with Georgia and the other partner countries.  As you know, Georgia is keen to enhance its participation in EU programmes and agencies. To respond to this, as well as to the great success of Erasmus+, in Georgia we have included a top-up of EUR six million in this year’s assistance package, which will provide more young people, youth workers, students and academic staff from Georgia with the opportunity to engage in more exchanges. Thanks to this, we will be supporting some 700 additional mobility opportunities for academic staff and students.  Investment in youth is crucial. In early September I had the pleasure and privilege to open the first European School outside the European Union in Tbilisi for students from all six Eastern Partnership countries. This represents a very important milestone not only for Georgia, but for the whole Eastern Partnership and the young.  All of this demonstrates our very close relationship with Georgia and you, the European Parliament, have a key role to play in this. The Georgian Parliament and Government are very closely following your work and they have paid considerable attention to this report. It’s also in your hands to ensure that Georgia will wholeheartedly continue its reform efforts in all sectors. Moving now to Moldova, let me start by thanking this Parliament for the continuous attention paid to the Republic of Moldova and for the ongoing work at political level and with civil society in particular. This is vital for our relations. I agree with the report’s finding that Moldova has made some progress in economic reforms, fiscal consolidation and bank restructuring following the banking fraud exposed in 2014. The EU, together with other international institutions, provided substantial assistance to the signing and implementing of these reforms for the benefit of Moldovan citizens.  I also take positive note of the constant increase in bilateral trade between the EU and Moldova. Let me thank in particular, as you also do in your report, the people who continue to work hard for positive change in the country. They have a fundamental role to play in driving political and economic reforms. I reiterate our expectation that the Government of Moldova will provide them with an enabling environment to pursue their activities.  At the same time, this report touches upon all of the key concerns of the European Union: respect for the rule of law, ensuring free and fair elections, and the independence of media and civil society. As you know, the Council shares these concerns, as clearly stated in the Council Conclusions on Moldova adopted at the end of February. Since then, there has been a worrying deterioration in the rule of law following in particular the invalidation of mayoral elections in Chişinău. On this, the High Representative and I immediately expressed strong concerns and called to take appropriate measures to ensure that the results of the elections reflect the will of the voters.  The resolution adopted in this House on 5 July echoed our concerns. Furthermore, and in line with the principle of strict conditionality, the Commission put on hold payments under the macro-financial assistance and EU budget support programmes. I would like to assure you that in all our contacts with the authorities we consistently underline the need for the continuation of implementation of reforms for the benefit of Moldovan citizens. In this respect, we expect immediate and urgent actions to be taken in the area of the prosecution of the banking fraud, the independence of the judicial system, the fight against high-level corruption, and the need to ensure that the next parliamentary elections are conducted in a free and fair manner. Unfortunately, we haven’t seen progress on the Moldovan side in addressing our main concerns.  The EU remains committed to the implementation of the Association Agreement with the Republic of Moldova, and it expects the same level of commitment from the Moldovan authorities.  The EU is also committed to continuing to provide substantial assistance to Moldovan citizens – I stress Moldovan citizens. However, considering the lack of commitment of Moldova to implementing agreed reform objectives, we proposed to reduce overall EU support to focus only on what will bring direct benefits to citizens and supporting agents of change, including civil society, independent media, reform-minded local authorities and SMEs. While this recalibration is being planned we are ready to come back to the level of assistance as initially planned, should the authorities deliver on their commitments taken within the Association Agreement.  Finally, we are all aware of the risks posed by the changes in electoral law on the multi-party system introduced by the Moldovan Parliament in spite of the recommendations of the Venice Commission and the recent invalidation of a mayoral election. Let me stress that we expect the parliamentary elections, which are now scheduled for 24 February next year, to be free, fair and in line with international standards.  We also expect that the banding recommendations will be addressed, in particular when it comes to non-biased coverage of candidates in the media, the registration of opposition candidates and respecting transparent rules for campaign financing. It will therefore be crucial to monitor the situation in the run-up to the elections and to continue passing coordinated messages concerning our expectations.

name: Jaromír Štětina
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, as shadow rapporteur for the Group of the European People's Party, I would like to stress that Georgia has great human, cultural and economic potential. Despite the geographers who run the border along the main ridge of the High Caucasus, I consider Georgia to be a European country. Its membership of the European Union is natural. Its membership in Atlantic structures such as NATO is also natural. In our report, we point to a number of achievements made in implementing the Association Agreement. If our report is critical on some points, such as the parts relating to the judiciary or media freedom, our comments stem from the pursuit of a better future for Georgia. In my opinion, selective justice cases need to be fought consistently. I am glad that the Group of the European People's Party has actively advocated the consistent use of the terms occupied territories of Abkhasia and the Tskhinvali region and refuses to use euphemisms. The Russian Federation violates international law by occupying Georgian territories.

name: Victor Boştinaru
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, we believe that Georgia and Moldova are key countries for the EU and they have both made – in particular Georgia – incredible progress. Think, for example, of the stability and democracy level reached by Georgia as shown also in the very smooth presidential elections – even though we think that a former Russian ambassador such as Mr Vashadze, the UNM candidate, wouldn’t be a suitable Georgian president. Or think of the stability and growth of Moldova after many years of instability, political crisis, continuous changes of government and the USD 1 billion theft. The vote on the two reports would have been better postponed to avoid interference with the current and forthcoming elections in the two countries. Moreover, in the case of Moldova, the content has been heavily influenced by the Conservatives on the basis of their political interests rather than based on the real situation on the ground. We don’t want – and we cannot associate as a group to – this game. We agreed that many of the shortcomings that still need to be addressed in Moldova will have to be addressed, but we cannot offer Moldova and the golden plate to Russia, completely forgetting the European interests and our strategic needs and closing all channels of communication. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr Colleague, you mentioned that we should not meddle in the presidential elections, and yet you clearly condemned one of the presidential canditates a moment ago. Do you think this is in line with the mission of members of the European Parliament?

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Štětina, it’s hard for me to accept lessons when launched by the EPP, because usually the EPP is doing every day and on every case exactly the same.
