But still, as a Romanian and a pro-European, it’s hard for me to believe that a former Russian ambassador is the best choice for any country, be it Georgia or any other.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I strongly support the EU Association Agreement and the DCFTA with Georgia. It’s clear that there’s more work to do, particularly in the areas of judicial reform and fighting high-level corruption, but overall the picture is one of progress. I also welcome the efforts made to realise the visa liberalisation regime with the European Union Schengen area, as well as the passing of electoral reform, which will see Georgia’s Parliament moved to a fully PR system by 2024. As Georgia prepares for the second round of its last direct presidential elections, the fallout from the street protests earlier this year is still clearly dominating the political and social landscape in Tbilisi, particularly following the release of the alleged Subeliani audio recordings last month, and I call for a full and transparent investigation into all the controversial claims that have been made.  I also welcome the reference in the report to the EaP+ model, as proposed by the Parliament, and believe that this level of ambitious closeness between Georgia and the European Union is fully justified for the future.

name: Norica Nicolai
text: on behalf of the ALDE group. – Mr President, Commissioner, I also undoubtedly support the Association Agreements with Georgia and Moldova. I hope, Commissioner, that possible political accidents do not interrupt the European course of these countries and that we will also have to deal in the future with a coherent and very sustained discourse to support the Eastern Partnership and not to ignore it at the expense of other policies or for the benefit of other policies. Mr Štětina is right, the Russian Federation violates the integrity of the two countries and I believe that we constantly ignore this geopolitical reality in our speeches. I wish, fellow members, that the next elections would bring to power in Georgia and Moldova political forces that would continue to follow the European course and that, one day, would not turn their backs on the European Union, would go to Moscow and we would run out of work in such debates. There is no doubt that, as far as Moldova is concerned, a number of progresses have been made. I can also understand the Commission's concerns, but we will never support a state with political discourse and reproach of this kind.

name: Rebecca Harms
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the The agreements we are discussing today are, in my opinion, part of the great process in which, together on the continent, as citizens and politicians of the EU, we want to achieve democracy and thus also lasting peace. I believe that it is all part of this process of reunification on the continent, which was recently made possible by the collapse of the Soviet Union, and that is difficult. Not only the legacy of the Soviet system, but also 20 years of oligarchization demand a price. If I am to judge Moldova today, I am much more concerned about this than I am about the second country under discussion, Georgia. Moldova – the one billion fraud unresolved, Russian money laundering on a very large scale, non-recognition of elections, a right to vote tailored to those in power – so, there is really reason to continue to wrestle with our colleagues in the Moldovan Parliament, but also with civil society, for better development. In Georgia, the situation is much better today. Systematic implementation of the Association Agreement promises real success. If the Security Service and the judiciary were to be reformed just as systematically and minority rights were to be written up, that would all be great. Both countries are under incredible pressure from Turkey. While Turkish teachers were kidnapped in Moldova, Georgia prevented it from being allowed, and Turkish schools and the Turkish university can continue to work – only to make a difference today.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The structure of relations with the association countries is based on the mutually accepted rules of the European Union.  For the first time since these agreements were signed, this House is now looking specifically at the reality of these countries. There is broad agreement in the European Parliament that the situation is worrying. For, despite gradual differences between Moldova and Georgia, we are a long way from achieving the objectives of stability, security, economic and social prosperity or the modernisation of these countries in terms of their policies, economies and society.  What is real is that opponents are still being locked away today, freedom of expression is restricted, the elites are plundering their countries, stealing, exploiting, personally enriching themselves, and flouting internationally recognized rights and norms, be they those of trade unions or minorities. The gap between rich and poor widens again. Many are looking for a future outside their borders. Such a reality brings neither stability, security, prosperity, nor modernity.  It is good that our Parliament is now calling this by its name, clearly communicating its expectations and starting to take political responsibility for the Eastern Neighbourhood.  The populations of these countries have high hopes for the EU: support for social, political and economic transformations. However, they will remain disappointed as long as the EU does not free itself from interdependence. The Plahotniucs need the EU for their own selfish personal enrichment, which thrives best in an increasingly autocratic system. EU politicians still believe that they need the oligarchs – as a geostrategic bulwark against the East.  (The chairman cut off the speaker)

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, four years after the signing of the association agreements, we are beginning to see some results. Georgia has shown significant commitment, Moldova has shown a lot more difficulties. But these agreements and the latest visa liberalisation are just a good starting point for a long journey, nothing more. In view of some progress, there are clear limits on which work is needed.  I was recently in Georgia, just as an observer for the last direct presidential elections, which is why they are even more symbolic and crucial to the future of that country. Even in a positive electoral context, I have seen more than questionable pressure on civil society from the top of politics. Not to mention questionable attacks on organisations engaged in the valuable task of election observation, defined as accomplices of fascism only for trying to play their part. Harsh words, especially considering that Georgia is a member of the Human Rights Council and the Council of Europe. Respect for the independence of civil society is a sine qua non for building a more constructive partnership. We reiterate this and will reiterate it to our friends in Chişinău and Tbilisi.

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I would point out that Moldova has received a recommendation from us from its government not to obey the law, so that, contrary to a final judgment of the Supreme Court, it should recognise the results of the elections for mayor of Chisinau. If, dear Moldovans, any of you are watching this and you are happy with the rule of law in which it is recommended to break the law, then we invite you, you will get even more of it. I asked Mrs Mogherini about this unfortunate ruling, she replied to me on the principle that well, that's how we called on the government to do this and let the government do that, and what about that, we're not going to be concerned about the rule of law there. If someone there in Moldova loves the rule of law and the law and wants it to be legied in a decent way, then he should think again about whether Moldova has definitely chosen the right way. Watch the votes from our Parliament and their parliamentarians – future MEPs – practice their reflexes for the vote today, because reflexes are a fundamental requirement for parliamentarians here.

name: Andrey Kovatchev (PPE).
text: – Mr President, when it comes to choosing between East and West, no country is currently more divided than Moldova. The invalidation of the mayoral elections in Chișinău of June 2018 and the controversial elections reform from 2017 are only two of the more striking symptoms of the erosion of the democratic principles that has taken place in the country lately. The use of selective justice and a tool to intimidate opposition members along with the judiciary intervention in the electoral and political process also serve to illustrate the undermining of the rule of law. Media freedom is deteriorating, and there are attacks to discredit representatives of civil society, while there is still no transparency on the USD 1 billion bank fraud. The Moldovan Government has been very good at assuring us of its positive intention to improve the situation in the country. Still, for a successful continuation of the dialogue between the EU and Moldova – and most importantly to improve the lives of the Moldovan citizens – it is time for the Moldovan Government to take actions instead of speaking. And in Georgia I welcomed the competitive atmosphere and the absence of violence in the first round of the presidential elections and, for sure, the European Parliament has condemned the occupation of Abkhazia and South Ossetia.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, (beginning of the inaudible intervention - microphone off) pass the democratic path and Euro-Atlantic integration despite the many challenges, the oligarchic influence to the Russian occupation and another difficult neighbourhood. It demonstrated this in the peaceful and competitive way in which the first round of the presidential elections took place at the end of October, which I had the honour of observing for this Parliament. The campaign environment has, however, become tense, with an escalation of polarized attacks. It is essential that everyone, authorities, candidates and the media, take on their responsibilities so as not to aggravate polarisation and not to exacerbate hatred. Attacks on the patriotism of one and the other and sexist abuse towards the female candidate are unacceptable in a democratic society and certainly do not serve the people of Georgia. As for Moldova, I am accompanying the rapporteur Auštrevičius in the very concerned and gloomy assessment. The level of capture is alarming. Moldova is used to launder dirty money and foment corruption and crime. The European Union cannot continue to whistle to the side, appealing to restraint, but without doing anything.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, in the last two years, the Union has become the most important trading partner of the Republic of Moldova. At the same time, however, Plahotniuc and Moscow's oligarchs destroy the rule of law and independent justice. Moldova is the poorest country in Europe, but Plahotniuc and his cronies live in luxury. Invalidating the election of Andrei Nastase as mayor of Chisinau, pressure against magistrates, violation of human rights are reasons why European funding given to the government must cease. Money has to go to people, and when people take to the streets and demand justice, they need to know that we are with them.

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Mamikins for his report on Georgia, and Commissioner Hahn for his excellent work on the Eastern Partnership. If we put Georgia on a map we can see that in certain international rankings Georgia does better than many EU Member States. In the Transparency International Corruption Perceptions Index 2017 Georgia is No 46, whereas, for instance, Romania is No 59, so we see that Georgia is steadily making progress and we have to encourage Georgia to do even more.  We have seen lately that Georgia is working on the association agenda – for instance on labour law inspections, protection of the labour force – which is very important in order to be at such a high place in the international rankings as ninth best business environment, but it definitely needs labour protection. Let me mention that we just had the seventh Parliamentary Association Committee meeting recently and we raised a new topic – environment. We hope that Georgia is doing a very important job on improving environmental protection in the fight against climate change.

name: Siegfried Mureşan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, through this debate, we are sending a very clear message to the citizens of the Republic of Moldova and the citizens of Georgia that we are with them during their Journey of European Integration. We have these association agreements that need to be implemented. These association agreements were negotiated on an equal basis between the authorities of Georgia and the authorities of the Republic of Moldova, on the one hand, and the European Union, on the other. We want to help the citizens of the Republic of Moldova and the citizens of Georgia but unfortunately we see that the chisinau authorities, the Government of the Republic of Moldova, is currently an obstacle to the European Union's desire to help the citizens of the Republic of Moldova. If the government, if the Chisinau authorities do not recognize free democratic elections for chisinau city hall, it means that it is acting against the people. If it does not ensure the functioning of independent justice, it means that it acts against people. If they do not allow diaspora citizens to vote freely, they are acting against people. We will continue to have concrete benefits with the citizens of the Republic of Moldova.

name: Clare Moody (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Mamikins, for his work on this report. It really is an important report: its job is to reflect on what has been achieved since the association agreement came into force in 2016, and – as it says – we welcome the sustained reform and progress that has been made. We also welcome the cross-party and popular support that there is in Georgia for its continuing European orientation. We must ensure that we build on this support, and to that end, keep our focus on how the agreement is delivering benefits for the people of Georgia. Of course, this report also includes our support for Georgia’s territorial integrity, and we must always be crystal clear on this. Georgia is a front-runner in the region. It is a star in the region for its commitment to European values, underlining that Georgia’s future is European.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking mr Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. An important debate today, because today we can once again tell the citizens of Georgia and Moldova that they are Europeans, that their European path, their European choice is important to us. That's what you have to tell them. I would caution against bullying this debate. That is, each of our backgrounds, from our political families, has friendly parties in Moldova, and especially in Georgia. But let us not say that, as the party working with us is in opposition, we are offended by the government of the state. I warn against this because it seems to me that this is unfair to citizens, for example, Georgia, Moldova or other countries. I think it is very important to support and say unequivocally – because that is the case, dear country – that this is a political match between East and West. And we need to support those who are on the west side, on the bright side of power.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Moldova and Georgia are like good and evil. It is good that there is still a European ambition in Chisinau and in Tbilisi, it is bad that politics is seized in both countries by oligarchs. It is good that elections are being held in Georgia and Moldova, but it is bad that citizens' right to information is neglected, as politicians influence the media more than the media influence politicians. It is good that there is trade with the European Union, but it is bad that justice is politicized and corruption enormous. It is good that there are association agreements with the European Union in both countries, but it is bad that both Moldova and Georgia are neighbours, not accession candidate countries. To take this extra step requires more than ambition.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as President of the European Parliament's delegation to the Republic of Moldova, I say it clearly and loudly, to understand everyone: the stability of the Republic of Moldova and its maintenance in European orbit are key elements. Now, the citizens of the Republic of Moldova expect from us a balanced, objective institutional report that will consider the implementation of the Association Agreement signed in 2014. In other words, a common message from the political groups in the European Parliament. Unfortunately, some of our colleagues in the "chorus of mourners" offer them a politicized text, a political press release, part of a communication strategy of the opposition in Chisinau for the legislative elections. What was supposed to be an institutional message became a press release, in which some political groups in the European Parliament express their positions towards the parties in Chisinau. I will not support this. My political group knows that things are not rosy in the Republic of Moldova. There are things that we will discuss, but we will never take prisoner the citizens of the Republic of Moldova for narrow political interests.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ECR).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I want to say from the outset that, overall, I agree with the recommendations proposed for the two agreements. I would now like to refer to the agreement on the Republic of Moldova. I believe that in the Republic of Moldova a red line was crossed with the invalidation of the elections for Chisinau city hall. An action that has not received a satisfactory explanation to this day. The European Parliament cannot overlook these things or other "oddities" of Moldovan democracy. There is a broad consensus on the political turmoil in Chisinau. There is, however, much less understanding of the realities on the ground and of the geopolitical arguments considered by the rapporteur to be unconvincing. The report uses the phrase "state captured by a group of oligarchs". In my opinion, it's much worse. It is not only about the state itself, it is also about citizens, who are captive and remain captive. For many citizens of the Republic of Moldova, freedom came only through the abolition of visas for European Union states. The question is: how can we sanction oligarchs without sacrificing citizens?

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE).
text: – It is not possible to talk in one minute about the two countries that are important to us, Georgia and Moldova, with which we are linked by association agreements. Therefore, only telegraphically.  28 October In Georgia, there were presidential elections, their first round. I chaired the European Parliament's election observation delegation. The date of the second round, although more than two weeks have already passed since the first one, is still unknown. Our delegation was concerned and questioned about the funding of the candidates' election campaign, a very negative election campaign. Some top public officials have been subjected to verbal attacks against civil society organisations that have watched the election. Two Georgian territories, Abkhazia and Cchinval, or South Ossetia, are torn apart from Georgia and controlled by the Kremlin's puppet regimes. Georgian citizens living there were unable to vote, the South Ossetia de facto government closed all administrative line crossing points on election day. These elections are an examination of the readiness of the Georgian authorities and the state as a whole for the further integration of Euro. I hope and wish Georgia to pass this exam successfully.

name: Boris Zala (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the geopolitical importance of Georgia and Moldova is huge for the European Union. However, the EU is still aware of very few geopolitical aspects. And a shift in mood. Until a few years ago, there was a very pro-American atmosphere in Georgia. Today, it is the EU's model and desire for Georgia. I therefore welcome the concern of both the European Parliament and the European Commission about the implementation of the agreements. But let us not forget that geopolitical interests are in both Moldova and Georgia, russia and Turkey. By assessing implementation, let us try to attract both countries more to the EU than to get involved in their internal political and intra-party struggles. Let us try to give both countries clearer guarantees, both security and economic. If we can do that, then we can also be critical in the implementation of association agreements.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I will speak on Moldova. The Association Agreement and DCFTA entered into force two years ago, yet the EU needs to remind political leaders in Moldova that these are binding agreements with a clear commitment for major reform processes and with an obligation to respect core democratic values. The developments in 2016 have given us a mixed picture. On the one hand, Moldova has acted in reforms relating to financial sector and has high alignment to the CFSP and cooperation CSDP missions. Positive advances were also noted in regards to relations with Tiraspol. These positive steps were overshadowed, unfortunately, by a general decline in the rule of law and fundamental freedoms. The most obvious problems concern the electoral reforms adopted against the recommendation of the Venice Commission, and the 28 June invalidation of the local elections in Chișinău. While I support the call for the creation of an EU support group for Moldova, I would also like to recall the contents of Articles 2 and 455 of the Association Agreement.

name: David McAllister (PPE).
text: –  Mr President, the situation in Moldova is obviously deeply worrying. Economic and political powers are increasingly concentrated in the hands of a select group of people, and basic democratic standards in the country are deteriorating.  Let me make three points. Firstly, I call on the Moldovan Government to ensure the principle of judicial independence and to renounce the anti-democratic practice of politicising the judiciary for political ends. Secondly, political pluralism needs to be guaranteed – the harassment and the intimidation of the opposition must stop. Thirdly, the authorities in Chișinău have to ensure the fundamental principle of democratic representation and must respect the will of voters as expressed in the 2018 Chișinău mayoral election. This is extremely important in view of the upcoming parliamentary elections in the country.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I was elected an MEP in a country where a totalitarian regime managed from Moscow has been in power for 40 years. I therefore understand very well the situation of Georgia. Its strategic position is an important prey for the Russian Federation, and I therefore fully support the close partnership between Georgia and the European Union.  These days I have had the opportunity to meet in person with members of the Georgian Parliament. It was clear that they were concerned that the European Union would not relent in its support for Georgia, including the financial support they urgently need for the reforms they need to implement, including the fight against corruption. Today's presidential elections show that Georgia is on track, and we want a pro-European president to be elected. For all the shortcomings we find in Georgia, I want the European Union to stand by Georgia's side.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the European Union is the largest investor and the main trading partner of the Republic of Moldova and the citizens of the Republic of Moldova are looking with hope at the European Union. However, it is extremely worrying to annul democratic elections, to control the judiciary, to monopolize the media, to constantly put political opponents, civil society, journalists and independent judges under pressure. It is unacceptable to cancel the elections for Chisinau city hall and to adopt electoral legislation despite the recommendations of the Venice Commission, the persecution of local leaders of the "DA" and PAS platform, the failure to investigate the theft of that billion and other things totally wrong with regard to the finances of the Republic of Moldova. Unfortunately, all this cancels out the progress made in recent years by the Republic of Moldova and jeopardises what has unfortunately been achieved so far in relation to the European Union and, perhaps most importantly, the liberalised visa regime.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it is important to support the European course of the two countries, but I would like to refer first of all to the Republic of Moldova. Commissioner Hahn, I currently consider it a big error, a strategic error the current position of the European Commission on stopping financial support for the Republic of Moldova - the two tranches for justice reform in 2017, the first tranche of macro-financial assistance for 2018 - because this situation is already being used by the pro-Russian and anti-European parties in the Republic of Moldova. It is important to support the pro-European parties in the Republic of Moldova now, before the elections, and not after, as the report and policy of the European Commission provide. It'll be too late! Then, if the Socialist party wins, together with Mr. Dodon they will take the Republic of Moldova to the Eurasian Union. It is time to now support the citizens of the Republic of Moldova in their journey towards freedom, towards democracy, towards the European Union.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to point out that my position with regard to Moldova is completely negative, and that is because Moldova has recognised Skopje as so-called 'Macedonia'. Therefore, it would be good for moldovans to go and get support from Skopje if they want to have a European path. It is certain that the Greek people do not want their European course, simply because they recognise Skopje as so-called 'Macedonia', which means the name of our Macedonia and our history. This, from a principled point of view, will apply to any country that recognises Skopje as so-called 'Macedonia'.  With regard to Georgia, this country does not even have relations with Skopje, which I consider to be particularly positive. Of course, other parameters need to be considered, such as what needs to be done in the internal situation and what changes need to be made. The issue of Greek property in Georgia must also be settled.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Union's policy towards its eastern border is schizophrenic and tainted by double standards. We congratulate Georgia because it is pro-European, but Moldova is condemned because it reaches out to Moscow. My colleague Mamikins' report presents Georgia as an economic success story through the Association Agreement, but its poverty rate is three to sixteen times higher, according to calculations, than Moldova, whose report by Mr Austrevicius says is the poorest country in Europe. Our policy does not build bridges for continental unity, but walls against Russia. I am extremely opposed to this policy of Drang nach Osten (March to the East). It led to war, it will lead back to war. It is contrary to the interests of Europe and only benefits the powers outside Europe who want to cut continental Europe of civilization and culture in half.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Today we have an assessment of two very different countries, one joint debate and two different evaluations. Different policy assessments of European support for these countries, support often consistent, but sometimes without certain consequences. It is worth paying attention to these differences, the most serious differences. Georgia can de facto be assessed as part of a positive policy, positive support in as many as three elements. Firstly, the implementation of the Association Agreement, secondly, the three-year plan for achieving the objectives in line with the positive assessment of the Venetian Commission, but also the effective implementation of the visa-free system. In the case of Moldova, we cannot note any positive element in this long-standing process of supporting moldova. I note this with sadness, with final consistency, but also in order to strengthen Commissioner Hahn's decision on the conclusions.

name: Maria Gabriela Zoană (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Hahn, I want to give a very clear message: I support the Agreement between the European Union and Moldova. Some of the Moldovan citizens are Romanian citizens. Nothing should interrupt the European journey of Moldovan citizens and the Republic of Moldova. The eastern countries are not privileged, and we saw this clearly today, while we discussed the resolution on Romania and how our colleagues in the European Parliament understood to cast their vote. But the eastern bloc should be encouraged. Moldova, and we must not forget this, Moldova is the border with Russia, Mr President, and the European Union must pay attention to this. Europe must help Moldova escape the influences of other countries. The European Union is Moldova's most important trading partner. Not everything is perfect in Moldova, clearly, but we must admit that progress has been made in this regard. I support Moldovan citizens who do not have to suffer because of a busy political agenda of others.

name: Sajjad Karim (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I’m obliged. If one was to cast their mind back 10 years from where we are today, it would have been very difficult for anybody to predict that we would have an Association Agreement, a Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area (DCFTA), visa liberalisation, a resolution passed by this Parliament on 10 years of occupation, a European school, etc. These are tremendous challenges that have been faced and achievements made by Georgia. May I thank my colleague, Andrejs Mamikins, for this very balanced report that he has put before this Parliament today. But we have been able to achieve it because of Georgia’s chosen European path. So much progress they have made – particularly in areas of judicial reforms. Today, we have that deep and comprehensive relationship that is reflected in this report. Occupation of Abkhazia and South Ossetia – it is this Parliament that has taken the lead, and we hope, Commissioner, that your institution will follow and the empty benches of the Council will follow as well. Attempts to pick apart incorrectly this report inadvertently serves the agenda to pick apart EU—Georgia relations, and I hope the people of Georgia will see those attempts for what they are.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, first and foremost, I would like to thank this House for giving the Commission the opportunity to express our views on your reports. We will continue following the implementation of the Association Agreement very closely, as well as the political developments in Georgia and, of course, in Moldova. Let me reiterate that we are fully committed to supporting Georgia’s reform efforts on its path to prosperity. A key focus will, of course, be sustaining growth. Georgia’s GDP is growing by a remarkable 5% per year and, of course, it’s about jobs. This will be done by actively providing support in the areas which require most attention and ensuring proper implementation through our continuous policy dialogue. May I say that in Georgia in particular, we are concentrating on, I think, three specific regional areas where we are trying to invest more in order to see and make a difference and to understand what it means to get support from the European Union. As for Moldova, the European Union remains committed to the implementation of the Association Agreement but it expects the same level of commitment from Moldova. I have listened very carefully to some statements concerning the fact that we have for the moment suspended financial support. But may I say, sometimes I have the feeling that people pretend to be pro—European, pro—Western, but in terms of how they act I can’t see the European values, the European commitment.  So in a way we have to take decisions if all our recommendations and advice, almost all of which comes not only from the European Union – the Commission, this Parliament – but also from the Venice Commission, have not been respected. Almost always quite the opposite was done and, in that respect, we have to take consequences, otherwise it’s about our own credibility.  But, once again, not to be misunderstood, we are also committed to continuing to provide substantial assistance to improve the lives of Moldovan citizens and we are ready to re—engage also with financial means, provided that the situation is changing.  First and foremost, our intention concerns ordinary citizens. They should not suffer from these developments, so be reassured that we will do everything to serve the interests of Moldovan citizens. It’s not about backing a specific political party or a specific government. No, it’s about taking care of ordinary citizens and improving their living conditions, which is, I think, the most important issue. So, when it comes to the next elections we will have a very close eye on the run-up to these elections because again, these elections must be free and fair, and the will of the voters has to be respected. I count on the further support of honourable Members to strengthen the relations with Georgia and Moldova, boosting cooperation as well as keeping up the momentum for reforms. Once again, these are two countries with an Association Agreement, a DCFTA, so there’s a clear commitment on both sides to further deepen the relationship, but this can only be based on the respect of mutual agreements, conditions, incentives, however you might call it.

name: Andrejs Mamikins
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank everyone for supporting this first implementation report on Georgia and for their comments. I know that the Georgians have been impatiently waiting for it, because it provides an assessment of what has been done for the last two years or even four years. But this is not only the assessment of the Georgian establishment. This is also the assessment of the European capacity to promote democracy, the rule of law and good governance. The concrete example of Georgia confirms that the EU is a good model for imitation, and the European perspective – no matter how near or far it can be – still exerts an important attraction. But let’s not make Georgia the hostage of its own success. As I have said before, Georgia still needs to solve many problems, and it needs to keep in mind the social dimension of policy change.  I would like to thank also those Members who brought substantial contributions to the report with the amendments on the implementation of the Association Agreement between the EU and Georgia, and I want to thank them for sticking to the scope of the report. Unfortunately, some other colleagues felt the need to introduce amendments on some very negative aspects, and I sincerely regret that the spirit of confrontation of some colleagues still overrides the logic of cooperation and dialogue. And then, in addition, Georgia is now in a politically delicate moment. Now is the period between two presidential election rounds, with the second round on 2 December, and as you well know this is the last time the President of Georgia is elected directly. Even though I understand the colleagues who tabled the amendment of the first round of elections, I personally cannot support it, because I think this House cannot allow itself to interfere with the electoral process and try to influence the balance of forces within Georgia.

name: Petras Auštrevičius
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I wish to thank everybody taking part in the debate on Moldova and Georgia today in this House. I don’t think our position should be defined by political sides or the political groups we belong to. I don’t think our reports are politicised. I reject that suggestion from the very beginning. The key words we are trying to send and are using to assess the situation are bilateral commitment, partnership and merit—based assessment. These were, and will be, the key principles for the EU—Moldova relationship in the future. The European Union wishes for nothing more, but nothing less. We wish to give a chance to the irreversibility of democratic transformation in Moldova. We wish to see an independent judiciary, fair elections and free media working in Moldova. Presently there is still far too big a deficit of Europe in Moldova.  I wish to conclude by emphasising that the coming parliamentary elections are of defining importance for years to come for Moldova, as well as for its relations with the European Union. I hope that the Moldovan authorities will act in accordance with primary principles: in democracy, it is not about who wins, it is about how they win. I hope those principles will be obeyed, and we will see the elections we expect. Commissioner, thank you for your clear message. It is indeed in line with this report. I hope in our joint efforts we will build a different future for Moldova – a Moldova where people will freely be European.

name: Președintele. –
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 14 November 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The report we are debating today concerns an agreement with a country which, as one of the three, has ratified and implemented the Association Agreement with the European Union, the most advanced type of partnership we have to offer in addition to membership.  The report presents a rather pessimistic picture with regard to the political situation in Moldova, but we must remember that the current authorities have taken a decidedly pro-European course, and deserve our support, for example. Perhaps we should take a closer look at the Moldovan scene and reach out to the new political parties, devoid of the ballast of the old communist system, which could lead to a real change in the quality of Moldovan politics, fully respecting the principles of the democratic state and the principles of the free market economy, while maintaining social sensitivity to the needs of people from the poor strata of society.  One thing is certain. Turning away from Moldova and strongly punishing the lack of progress, we will achieve only one thing: we will push the country towards Russia. We should therefore act prudently, rewarding positive developments, perhaps by looking for new partners for talks, but by showing the current authorities that, by respecting democratic standards, they will gain much more in the long term, being in the EU family and, perhaps, in NATO. Sacrificing these values for ad hoc political gain will certainly not pay off for them in the end.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. - The Association Agreements with Georgia and Moldova need to be reviewed on a regular basis. I am pleased to recognise progress in Georgia on democracy, economic and social reforms, which must certainly continue. Visa liberalisation with Georgia is also a positive step, creating an opportunity to further promote people-to-people contacts. At the same time, part of Georgia's territory remains occupied, so the continued coherence of the EU on supporting Georgia and the EU's common foreign policy towards Russia are important.  Moldova has made some progress, for example in the financial sector and in the energy sector, but unfortunately there has been a return to democratic values. Moldova must move forward with electoral reform as well as the rule of law, media freedom and the promotion of civil society. Further assistance will certainly depend on Moldova's progress in these areas.

name: Președintele. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Mrs Sabine Lösing, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on arms exports: implementation of Common Position 2008/944/CFSP (2018/2157(INI)) (A8-0335/2018).

name: Sabine Lösing
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which We can say that the outrage over the deadly business of arms exports has never been as great and has never been as widespread as it is today in the face of the horrors in Yemen. Frigates, patrol ships, artillery tracking and bombs – mainly from Germany, France, and Spain – make life hell for children in Yemen. Perhaps, at this very moment, hospitals and school buses are again the targets of the murderous attacks. In addition to the US corporations, at the moment, those from Europe are supplying almost half of the war equipment to the areas of the Middle East. How can this be possible? After all, there is a set of rules prohibiting the supply of arms to crisis regions and countries where vile human rights violations are on the agenda. How can this be possible? After all, we have the common position with its eight criteria for controlling arms exports. How can it be that Saudi Arabia and the Arab Emirates get all the weapons from Europe that make the Yemen war possible and implement the naval blockade – this naval blockade, which is leading to the humanitarian catastrophe about which we are all informed? We have the common position, but it can only be really good if it is implemented. I do not believe that arms exports are necessary to guarantee the stability of states and regions. We do not all agree on this. Nor do we all agree on whether and how much the profits of the arms industry should be protected. It is wrong how the economic positive effects of the arms industry are also exaggerated with regard to jobs. However, even with all these differences of opinion, we should also remember one thing in common: anyone who refers to human rights, humanist values, peace and stability must strive for everything possible, so that the common position on the control of arms exports is effectively implemented. This includes a strong and common language to end the different interpretation and application of the criteria, and in particular the introduction of a sanction mechanism. Final control must be improved and licence production must not be misused to circumvent export control. Although we in my group are the sharpest critics of the new EU armament programmes and reject the defence fund, including the so-called peace facility, I welcome the fact that the report develops common ground in integrating programmes such as EDIDP and Co. into parliamentary control mechanisms. What is also new and pleasing is the extension of the criteria to the deployment of military and security personnel for training purposes and much more. Finally, this report is the first time that this report has been a programme for socially acceptable conversion, let us allow this report to prevail over joint responsibility and let us take further steps towards effective control of arms exports, just as very large sections of the population are asking us to do.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, thank you again for this opportunity to discuss arms exports and the report prepared by Ms Lösing. Arms exports are a national prerogative of course but through the years Member States have agreed that national policies should converge and that transparency should always be guaranteed.  Parliamentary scrutiny is essential to transparency and your work should also encourage national parliaments of Member States to play their role with regard to arms exports control. Channels for dialogue on arms export issues with this Parliament have developed considerably over the years, with the crucial engagement of NGOs, the academic world and the defence industry.  This is an important achievement and it shows that transparency and dialogue can take place without prejudice to the respective responsibilities of national stakeholders. At a time when we advocate further transparency worldwide, notably via the Arms Trade Treaty, it’s important to show there is no contradiction between transparency and national security. The EU framework governing arms exports mainly revolves around the EU Common Position on arms exports adopted in 2008. This framework is based on the national responsibility of EU Member States on arms exports licensing decisions together with well-developed information sharing between export control authorities of Member States. The EU Common Position has allowed the creation of common criteria for export control. This has led to increased convergence, increased transparency through obligatory public reporting and it has facilitated the exchange of information between the Member States’ export control agencies.  As the report by Ms Lösing recalls, the Common Position demands that all Member States publicly report on their arms exports. The risk assessment criteria laid down by the EU Common Position are comprehensive and far-reaching in terms of respect for human rights and international humanitarian law, the risk of diversion and the impact on internal and regional stability. Their daily application by national licensing officers is supported by the so—called User’s Guide, which was revised in 2015 in order to align it with the Arms Trade Treaty.  The EU Common Position aims to promote responsible arms export policies and the convergence of national arms export policies. In support of these objectives, the Council and the European External Action Service have set up an information-sharing platform through the Council Working Party on Arms Exports and an IT platform enabling the exchange of information relevant for risk assessment, including details on licence denials.  As the report also notes, at the beginning of 2018 this Working Party on Arms Exports began work to reassess the implementation of the EU Common Position and the fulfilment of its objectives in accordance with the mandate given in the Council conclusions of July 2015 and this work is continuing to date.  We welcome that the report by Ms Lösing pays tribute to the work of the Working Party on Arms Exports in connection with cooperation, coordination and convergence.  Let me now briefly widen the picture of the EU’s cooperation and assistance on export control capacity development in third countries. A number of countries in our close neighbourhood, mainly in the eastern neighbourhood, have aligned with the criteria of the EU Common Position. To assist them in the daily operational implementation of the Common Position, the European Union has put in place a programme to fund technical cooperation. The latest phase covering 2018-2019 was approved by the Council in January 2018.  Secondly, let me stress once again how central the Arms Trade Treaty is to raising the standards that govern arms trade towards greater responsibility and transparency. One hundred and thirty states have signed the Treaty and 96 countries are state parties, including all 28 EU Member States. However, some of the largest arms exporters and importers, such as Russia, China, India and Pakistan have not signed or ratified it yet.  Our goal remains to make the Treaty even more universal. Last August the Fourth Conference of States Parties of the Arms Trade Treaty met in Tokyo, hosted and chaired by Japan. The conference discussed the effective implementation of the Treaty, including transparency in reporting and how to encourage further universalisation. Our work for the effective implementation and universalisation of the Arms Trade Treaty includes both financial support and diplomacy. In 2014-2016 a dedicated EU assistance programme with a budget of around EUR six million was active with 15 countries in Latin America, the Caribbean, Africa and Asia.  A total of 113 countries participated in the activities organised in the programme’s framework, which focused on showcasing regional best practices, encouraging regional cooperation and strengthening regional arms control structures. A new EU outreach programme adopted last year extends our assistance to 18 roadmap countries and 14 ad hoc partners to strengthen their domestic capacities to implement the Treaty. We will continue to bring together dozens of other countries to share experiences on a regional level. This programme receives over EUR seven million in funding from the European Union and it benefits from the technical expertise of export control officials from EU Member States. In addition to these tangible actions on the ground all diplomatic opportunities are used to encourage more countries to join the Treaty, including by offering EU assistance where needed and requested. The arms trade is becoming more and more globalised so it’s every day more important to work for the globalisation of the Arms Trade Treaty. At the same time it’s our duty to lead by example when it comes to arms exports from the European Union and your report is an important contribution to this goal.

name: Gilles Pargneaux
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to make several comments on this report. First of all, this legislation is politically very important, because it reflects the common position of the 28 Member States of the Union on arms exports. Secondly, it expresses the political will of the European Parliament to ensure that the eight criteria that define the right or not to export arms are applied better and that these criteria are applied more transparently, in line with the fundamental values of our Union. What we want is to keep export control in order to build a defence Europe, Commissioner, Mr President, by setting up a European defence market that relies on a European supervisory mechanism to better monitor exports. Finally, the construction of this Europe of defence obliges us to develop a common strategy, I am thinking in particular of the embargo that we are calling for after the assassination of journalist Jamal Khashoggi and in the face of the bloody war in Yemen. These are the commitments we want for Europe's defence.

name: Ангел Джамбазки
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Without any doubt, this report is useful and important and must be viewed with great care in this Chamber. But let's be honest: we cannot talk about arms exports seriously, while there are such double standards in the European Union as the treatment of Saudi Arabia.  When it came to killing a journalist, the answer had to be very sharp and very clear, and very consistent. But many leading countries in the European Union do not want to impose an arms embargo on Saudi Arabia because they sell arms to Saudi Arabia for a lot of money. And in Saudi Arabia, journalists are killed. In Saudi Arabia, people are beheaded in the square. This is a theocratic dictatorship, and as long as we continue to pretend to be misunderstood, it will be hypocrisy and a double standard. And this hypocrisy and double standard do not give anyone the right to think that they are defending any fundamental rights and freedoms. The murder of journalists must be condemned clearly and accurately, and this is the place in this room.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, in a world that is changing fast and with authoritarian power blocs acting increasingly assertively, the EU needs a strong foreign and security policy now more than ever. We heard Chancellor Merkel today sharing her vision of a European army. Now the question is, how can we get out of the often fragmented approach that we see in Europe today?  On arms exports, I would like to make three points. Firstly, countries need to share their interpretation of arms controls rules, because currently we see Member States failing to even make four submissions. Secondly, dual—use items, including hacking and surveillance technologies, are currently insufficiently controlled. Our House has adopted a very strong position already, which includes respect for human rights as an assessment criterion before granting a license, and we are waiting for the Council to take its position so that we can enter into trilogue before the end of our mandates here. My third point is that we have been crystal clear about ending exports of arms to Saudi Arabia. In fact, we voted for it in a majority four times already, and I want to echo our appeal to Member States again today to stop selling the very arms that are causing such extraordinary bloodshed in Yemen, and the humanitarian price that we see of that war is far too high for anyone in Europe to contribute to it. European companies combined represent the second largest market of arms, so making sure that this industry serves our political objectives and respects minimal ethical and international legal standards and values is essential for a common European credibility. Of course, we don’t have a magic wand to spread peace in the world – we would be happy to use it if we could – but at least what we need to do is act seriously to avoid the export of instability.

name: Bodil Valero
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The common regulatory framework for the control of exports of military technology and armaments is binding on the Member States, but when you look at how it is applied, it is hard to believe that this is actually the case. For example, we must not issue export licences if there is a clear risk that the military technology or armaments to be exported may be used in the event of serious violations of international humanitarian law, nor if it can be used for internal repression, such as torture and other serious violations of human rights. However, that is exactly what is happening in both Yemen and Saudi Arabia, as we all know – in Yemen, blatant violations of international humanitarian law, and in Saudi Arabia, serious violations of human rights. The attacks on the port of Hodeidah have dramatic consequences for the population, which is already severely affected by cholera and famine. In Saudi Arabia, bloggers are imprisoned and journalists are murdered. The fact that the Member States continue to sell arms to Saudi Arabia means that we are complicit if we do not put an end to it. An EU embargo can put an end to all arms exports, not just new sales. That is why we in Parliament have so many times already called for an embargo, but the Member States seem to care more about jobs at home than people's suffering in other countries. According to our common rules, jobs are never the basis for arms exports. We have also asked in this House for the embargo to cover other countries in the Saudi-led coalition. Instead of an embargo, however, the Commission is preparing a multibillion-dollar European defence fund. It will lead to even greater overcapacity of armaments in Europe and an even greater need to be able to export to creti and pleti in order to make ends meet.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, we are facing a minimum agreement, but an agreement necessary to be able to have a common European position. We must remember that humanitarian crises are not atmospheric phenomena, but are the product of our policies. Policies such as arms sales. Indeed, this European Parliament has repeatedly voted, for example, against arms sales and the boycott of arms sales to dictatorships such as Saudi Arabia. But we see how member countries of the European Union continue to repeatedly sell arms to Saudi Arabia. The spanish government's position, the socialist government's position, which looks like a contractor from Saudi Arabia, seems to be Saudi Arabia's butler in Europe, is particularly bleeding. I believe that the European Parliament has to take binding positions. If not, they'll be wet paper. We cannot simply wait for governments to look the other way on what is said in this House. And measures must be taken to stop the effective sale of weapons to conflicting places ...  (The president interrupts the speaker)

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Lösing has done an excellent job with this report. Now it is time for the intentions to finally follow concrete facts. The idea of a Europe as a bulwark of human rights and democracy is often counterbalanced by a very different and far more worrying reality. About 40 % of export licences go to countries in the Middle East and North Africa. As we all know by now, the same weapons that we sell to countries such as Saudi Arabia not only violate two of the eight criteria of the common position, but become an instrument of death, fuelling unprecedented conflicts and humanitarian crises, just as in Yemen. How many more deaths do we still have to count before the common position is fully respected, before there are sanctions for Those Member States that continue to violate it? Because they do not want to implement an arms embargo, after our Parliament has called for it several times, even after the barbaric murder of the journalist Khashoggi. To what extent are we prepared to remain silent accomplices in this inconsistency that continues to reap innocent victims in the name of the one God money?

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, once again, in this draft resolution on arms exports, we propose to strengthen the control of The Member States, and in particular the control of the information they disseminate to the Union authorities. What right, whether defence or any other area, does the Union once again exceed its prerogatives? On the merits, let us say that certain criteria are particularly vague and do not allow objectivity. I will mention, for example, the preservation of peace, regional stability or the internal situation of the client country. On form, all EU Member States have already signed and ratified the UN Arms Trade Treaty, which establishes a code of conduct for conventional weapons. What do we want to add to the UN treaty? I would remind you that, with regard to the national security of States, the Union is not competent. This draft resolution does not correspond to the interests of the Member States. We will vote against it once again.

name: James Carver (NI).
text: – Mr President, my problem with this resolution is it does not deal with arms control in any practical sense. Instead, it is a vehicle for anti—Saudi rhetoric, the usual tired comments about Yemen and an opportunity to yet again criticise one or two Member States. We all agree that a robust and ethical system of arms control, and in particular licensing, is vital for successful de—escalation of the many conflicts across the globe. Arms sales to non—state actors are of particular concern and therefore the transparency of end—user certificates becomes paramount. Yemen is a political problem and peace will only come through dialogue between Yemeni factions, not through the response of international actors. The simple fact is that the international community has outsourced the Yemeni conflicts to the Saudi—UAE coalition. We rightly decry the humanitarian crisis in Yemen whilst ignoring the underlying issues. The UN Special Envoy is doing a good job, but he is constrained by the lack of options on the table due to so many groups being excluded from the talks. Let’s properly debate this, rather than this constant cheap—point scoring. If we are not prepared to intervene then surely we cannot deny material support to those who do so on our behalf. As the Houthis deploy ever more sophisticated weaponry, including ballistic missiles fired into Saudi Arabia, the EU is strangely silent on this. Call me a cynic, but maybe it is something to do with European business interests in Iran. If you want real influence then stop this self—serving rhetoric.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: – Dear Chairman, at a time of deteriorating security opportunities globally, when our main transatlantic ally is also questioning the multilateral security and cooperation system, strengthening the global role of the European Union is becoming increasingly important. The European Union is the second largest arms exporter in the world, but it is the only one with a legally binding framework for strengthening the export control system. So let's not hesitate to ask for a greater level of transparency where guns end up. I welcome the rapporteur's position that strengthening the competitiveness of European military industry must not harm the consistent application of the eight criteria of the Common Position.  The high percentage of export licences granted to Saudi Arabia, which is openly violating human rights in Yemen, and the amount of European weapons used in conflicts in the Middle East are disappointing. As a community of peaceful states, we must seek the establishment of a single supervisory authority and the imposition of independent checks and sanctions against those who do not comply. This is the credibility of a European project whose most recognizable trademarks are peace and cooperation.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I will refer to my country, Romania. Romania must apply the Common Position of the European Union for the transfer and retransfer of weapons, especially when we are talking about weapons that do not correspond to end-user certificates, and also refuse export licences where there is a risk of using military equipment for other purposes. All Member States must stop supplying arms to Saudi Arabia and other members of the coalition in Yemen and report all arms exports correctly and fully. Why are we saying this and why are we doing this debate? For example, because the amount of weapons and ammunition in Daesh's possession in Syria and Iraq but manufactured in the European Union is alarming.

name: Jordi Solé (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the need for a state to exercise effective control over arms transfers is universally accepted. However, arms exports keep fuelling conflicts and are a tool for mass violations of human rights. Yemen is just one, but a very sad, example of this. Some Member States, like Spain, continue providing arms to Saudi Arabia, despite the common position, despite the regime’s behaviour, despite this Parliament’s position and despite the well-known end use of arms, because as we know, business is business. But EU Member States’ divergent policies and practices in arms exports controls make it more difficult to achieve the goals of our common position; indeed, they undermine the common position. We want the EU to act as a uniform, credible and responsible foreign policy actor, also in the eyes of citizens. But this will not happen until Member States act in a more consistent, brave and responsible way.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are discussing the 5th report of the European Parliament on the common position on arms exports. Of course, the data we have so far is that the European Union, with 27%, is the second largest arms exporter in the world after America. France, Germany, the United Kingdom, Spain and Italy accounted for 23%, while exports increased five times between 2013 and 2016. Everyone knows that real sales are more than official figures. 40% of these weapons are exported to the Middle East - as has been said many times by colleagues in the Chamber today - and North Africa, which is being ignited by civil conflicts and wars, creating millions of displaced people and refugees. European weapons sold to Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates are used in Yemen and elsewhere. European weapons end up in terrorist organisations. Ladies and gentlemen, if we really want transparent and effective control of arms exports as the European Parliament, we must require an independent evaluation and verification mechanism to monitor compliance with all 8 criteria of the... (The President removes the floor from the speaker.)

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Mr President, every state has the right to its legitimate defence and self-protection. In this context, it makes sense for a state to want to be able to acquire military technology and to create and maintain a defence industry. Especially when this state is threatened by an external enemy - as is the case with Cyprus and Greece - this is imperative.  But when we talk about gun sales, things get different. Weapons can create or sustain a war. They have an impact on immigration and can also be used to violate human rights. From this point of view, the debate we are having here now is hypocritical, because we know very well that the European Union is supposed to be the world's peacekeeping factor. At the same time, it is also the second largest exporter of arms. In order to sell weapons, therefore, the European Union itself is in breach of the rules it has adopted. For example, it gives arms to states in the Middle East and Africa. It gives weapons to Turkey, which uses them to oppress its population and violate its human rights, and there is also the possibility that it will use them against armed forces of European Union countries - such as Cyprus and Greece - which is prohibited. The same is happening with arms sales to Saudi Arabia, which uses them against Yemen and has created a humanitarian crisis. So, if we are going to vote in the report on the implementation of the common policy, we will have to not vote on the eight criteria, because otherwise we will formalise the... (The President removes the floor from the speaker.)

name: Soraya Post (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the EU is collectively the second largest arms supplier in the world. This is the reality, even if we know that disarmament is an imperative for human rights and human security. Also, Goal 16 in the Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) states that peace, stability and human rights are deeply connected to sustainable development. We must control the weapons in the world, but most of all, we must act for a complete and global disarmament. We have to change the global agenda on security. The first priority must be to make every individual secure in their daily life. This is security – human security. We, the EU, should not supply the world with arms. Our moral and human duty is to supply the world with peace. I am a proud pacifist.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the Common Position defining common rules governing the control of exports of military technology and equipment, which has been binding since 2008, is an essential element of our common and security policy, but the problem is that Member States must respect it. I would like to thank the rapporteur for the report, because I think it sets out very well all the challenges we have for proper implementation. Firstly, because of the data, because Member States still do not give all the data to the COARM, which is what the annual report does on its compliance. And, of course, that tells us that the non-compliance with the rules is much greater, that phenomenon is much greater than what is actually exposed in the data. But there are Member States that continue to send arms and sell weapons to countries that violate human rights, which violate humanitarian law, which is contrary to the principles of the Common Position. And we also have a problem with tracking this weaponry, which often ends in terrorist organizations, with the problem of dual-use weaponry, etc., etc. And finally, a proposal which I think is important, which is contained in the report. The European Defence Fund. We must be very careful that this will not finance arms exports that are illegal in the eyes of the Common Position.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Article 2 is crucial for today's debate. This is an article where the criteria are listed, the minimum completion of which means the possibility of conducting arms trade, selling weapons. As we draw attention to these criteria, they are de facto not possible under the current conditions. Not because it is impossible, because someone does not want to, just because the criteria have been built so that it is difficult to meet them. Respect for the human rights of the citizens of the target country is a rarity. Secondly, an assessment of the internal situation of the target country in terms of the risk of conflict. Most often, this assessment is made in error. Preserving regional peace, stability and security. It would be a miracle if it actually happened. But also the behavior of the purchasing state towards the international community. Most of these situations are critically assessed. I believe that this report is very, very necessary, transparency is essential, but naivety accompanies it all the time.

name: Arne Lietz (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Many thanks to the rapporteur for the very good report.  Unfortunately, the report is necessary because the EU Member States are failing to comply with the criteria of the common position adopted in 2008. This means, for example.B not supplying weapons in war and crisis areas, as Saudi Arabia repeatedly points out here, which is why this report also mentions.  Only a single arms export policy will also enable the objective of a single EU foreign policy. That is why we need a stronger and, above all, more consistent European regulation of arms exports, as the German Chancellor has also called for here today in plenary.  However, I also call on the Chancellor to place the bilateral deals – for example between Germany and France – under these common EU rules. The forthcoming European Defence Fund should also demand that the resulting products be strictly exported only in accordance with the 2008 common position. Because that will not be the case, I shall vote against this report, and I think that is absolutely consistent.

name: Sajjad Karim (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I am obliged. Commissioner Hahn very comprehensively outlined the standards which are applied and the transparency that exists. Member States of course have competence so far as export control is concerned. As long as we have the transparency, the information—sharing and the reporting criteria working properly and efficiently, then that gives us the protections that we have.  What concerns me today is that it’s wrong that a report which seeks to set a framework for a comprehensive and wide—ranging policy development seeks to do so in a singular specifically—targeted manner. A snapshot approach delivers bad policy, and time and time again today I’ve heard that ‘Saudi Arabia this, Saudi Arabia that’ – a snapshot approach will deliver bad policy. Don’t forget it is a vital partner for EU countries, our economies are interconnected, and for us it is a reliable source of energy. Time will pass. Snapshot approaches in relation to individual countries will not deal with the real challenges we are seeking to address.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the convergence of Member States' arms export policies is a declared objective of the European Union, and there are also criteria, such as respect for human rights, regional security and stability, the avoidance of the risk of dispersion of defence materials and the prevention of a crisis in the immediate environment. In the end, however, there is a huge bilingualism. Apply these criteria in the case of Turkey, where the Member States of the European Union sell arms. Turkey does not respect human rights. Turkey threatens Greece and Cyprus. Turkey owns 37% of the Republic of Cyprus and nevertheless continues to export European arms to Turkey. So this is a clear bilingualism. The same applies to Saudi Arabia, which has the privilege of procuring weapons from European industries while slaughtering the Yemeni people.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, this may come as a surprise to many of you, but the European Union, by the way the Nobel Peace Prize winner, is the second largest arms supplier in the world after the US. In some cases, weapons were taken to, for example, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates and were used in Yemen. Meanwhile, a war is unfolding in Yemen, leading to the world's biggest humanitarian disaster. For two and a half years, the European Parliament, all of us, have been calling for an arms embargo against Saudi Arabia, and nothing is happening. Only people are still dying, thanks to weapons from the European Union. I am fundamentally convinced that the only directly elected institution of the European Union must say this: the European Union must not export arms to warring countries. The European Union must not support war, otherwise we will once again wonder where migrants have arrived at Europe's borders, and the European Union must always promote peace and cooperation first and foremost and must not sell these values to the highest bidder. That's what I'm asking you to do.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D).
text: Mr President, European weapons end up in terrorist countries such as Saudi Arabia and Turkey. But I will give a specific example, Commissioner, that concerns you. Germany exports weapons and weapons systems to Turkey. German tanks were used in the invasion and continued occupation of Afrin - we saw them with our own eyes - and, at the same time, German submarines end up in Turkey. These submarines - as has been said publicly - are appropriate for Turkish expansionary policy in the Eastern Mediterranean. At the same time, the Republic of Cyprus, in cooperation with countries in the wider Eastern Mediterranean but also with countries that are members of the European Union, is trying to develop an energy policy to serve the European Union. How is it possible to accept arms exports to Turkey, a terrorist country, and, at the same time, to support the energy planning of the Republic of Cyprus? We have to decide what we want.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you for the debate and also thank you for the many interesting questions you have tabled.  Let me reiterate that the nexus of transparency and accountability is the sense of the EU common position, and at the larger global level of the Arms Trade Treaty. The EU common position supports greater convergence through a number of common elements and information sharing. As such convergence remains, by definition, always work in progress. Undoubtedly, as stressed by rapporteur Lösing, greater parliamentary scrutiny at the national and EU level can further incentivise convergence. Let me close by signalling once again my appreciation of Parliament’s role in keeping this important issue on the European agenda.

name: Sabine Lösing
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the Most Members have made clear the need for greater implementation of the common position, and have set this out with various different, very gripping examples. I would like to remind you once again that this debate, and also in this report, is not a debate on the common position per se. That is why I do not want to make any specific comments about the speeches that have called this common position into question. I would like to remind you once again that this is a technical report, the implementation of a common position which, as such, was adopted by a majority in this House a long time ago.  Reality shows that there are holes, and that is precisely what this report is about to plug these holes effectively. I agree with Mrs Schaake that we do not have a magic wand here. But I think that if this Parliament really agrees with this report, it will send out a strong signal. I think, to take up mr Hahn's words, it is also a strong signal to the national parliaments to do their homework and not to issue export licences to countries that violate the common position. I very much agree with what the last Member said about the supply of arms to Turkey. I would like to go back to what Mr Carver said – he is no longer here, but I do not think he was concerned with a real debate either, but with letting go of some positions here. I do not think that these weapons in Turkey, which are now targeting the multi-ethnic groups fighting ISIS, are doing our job there. That really isn't the same, and not anywhere else!

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 14 November 2018. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – It is worth pointing out that the EU is a major exporter of armaments. In the last five years, arms worth 27% of global exports have been exported from the European Union, which means that the Union is after the United States (34%) second supplier of weapons. Unfortunately, there are numerous signs that these weapons are also being used in countries that are banned from exporting, such as Yemen. There are also cases where EU-made weapons and ammunition were found with DAISH fighters in Syria and Iraq. This information indicates that existing European arms export rules are not effectively enforced.  Of course, the main responsibility for controlling arms exports lies with the countries from which exporters come. In my opinion, the EU could also contribute to more effective control of arms exports. This would require, in particular, an increase in the competences and number of staff of the European External Action Service to analyse export authorisations and enforcement in the Member States. The main problem is not the weakness of the legislation, but the circumvention of existing solutions.

name: President. –
