text: The next item is the debate on the report by Andreas Schwab, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council to empower the competition authorities of the Member States to be more effective enforcers and to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market (COM(2017)0142 – C8—0119/2017 – 2017/0063(COD)) (A8-0057/2018).

name: Andreas Schwab
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. First of all, I am pleased that, within a manageable timeframe, we have managed to bring the cooperation of the European competition authorities within the framework of this European Competition Network here in Parliament, together with the Council and, of course, with strong commitment from the Commission, to put it into place. I believe that it is possible to say today, thanks in part to the work of the shadow rapporteurs and the rapporteur from the Committee on the Internal Market, Mrs Maydell, that we have managed to find a very round solution here which will take us an important step forward in the area of the application of European competition law. As you know, this is only the second legislative proposal that the European Commission has brought to the European Parliament in the field of competition law, and I believe that the House has been perfectly able to resolve the sometimes difficult balancing issues in European competition law in a sensible way. I am extremely grateful to all those involved, especially the shadow rapporteurs. However, I would also like to point out that the perception that in many areas of the classic internal market, to which I am now counting competition law and its application in a broader sense, we are not as far as one or other citizen, as one or other parliamentarian in the Member States might think, because we still have different principles of application in the technical and executive conduct of procedures. Here we have succeeded in taking an important step forward. I believe that this is a sign that the internal market is still alive and that we are ultimately able to achieve better results for businesses in Europe with uniform standards – better than can often be the case through different application of European law in different Member States' authorities. That is why it is right that we have taken this step, and that is why I believe that we should do it elsewhere and that, perhaps at a later stage, real unification should indeed be required, not only of the legal bases, but also of the procedures. However, it is true that we have, of course, made many improvements, not only in relation to the Commission proposal, but also in relation to the current legal situation, but there are still – albeit smaller – differences in the application of European competition law in the Member States. In the end, they were necessary in order to reach a consensus with the Council and the Member States. And it was good that the Member States took part in this. However, it is, of course, always tricky in the end in competition law when different procedures in different Member States are reflected in the procedure, because competition law thrives on the fact that we have a real level playing field in the European Union, in the European internal market, and this real level playing field is best demonstrated by the fact that equal law actually applies to everyone, and in all respects. One of the problems that has arising in the deliberations of this directive, which concerns not only European competition law, but also economic law in the European Union in its entirety, is that we have just repeatedly stated that, unfortunately, legal principles already laid down in European law in the broad sense have not been implemented in this way by the Member States, in so far as they themselves were responsible for implementing it. , that we could have been satisfied with this in a single European legal framework. That is why we have had to re-spell a whole series of general legal principles in this directive as well. We in the European Parliament hope that the Member States will now be able to cope with this rather second definition of European law in application and that we can rely on the Member States actually implementing the principle of 'equal rights for all' in competition law. This is an important step that we must take here. That is why I am now very much looking forward to the debate.

name: Margrethe Vestager
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it is indeed a pleasure to be here to have this debate before the final vote on this proposal. As the rapporteur already mentioned, this is a key proposal to enable national competition authorities independently, with full resources, to make sure that consumers can have the full benefits of competition, because yes the directive may be to some degree technical but the idea is very simple: we want to make sure that consumers can have the benefits of competition, affordable prices, choice and innovation in the marketplace.  This proposal was made end May 2017. It was thoroughly prepared, after a long public consultation, between November 2015 and February 2016. So now we are at the end. The legislator – the Parliament and Council – has taken I think very worthwhile efforts to make this proposal a proposal that will work.  The thing is, and I hoped more people would know this, that we work on a daily basis with national competition authorities to enable the benefits of European competition law for every citizen in Europe. This is important because the national competition authorities are on the ground, they are in the national market, they know exactly what may be the problems in the construction industry, in retail, in the national markets, so that consumers are well served.  The thing is that enforcement is only as good as the tools at hand and here unfortunately it has turned out that, well, currently there are too many gaps and too many discrepancies in the tools of national competition authorities. That poses a problem, because it makes it obvious that in some Member State there is a risk of one way of doing things, in another Member State the risk of another way of doing things or illegal behaviour not being detected and consumers therefore suffering harm.  This is why this proposal is a good proposal and this is why I’m so grateful for the very constructive cooperation that we have had to enable this proposal. Companies will benefit from the ability to compete fairly within the single market and consumers will benefit from more efficient and even competition enforcement.  We have enabled a political agreement on this directive. You will soon vote and we will then have implemented the agreement that we reached in May this year.  I do agree with the rapporteur. This is a milestone. It is a milestone in the history of European competition law enforcement and following its transposition into national law, following its implementation, the national authorities will have the most necessary tools to stop and to sanction illegal behaviour that harms consumers. That, I think, is the important thing, because this is all about the citizen. No matter the legal technicalities, it’s all about the citizen, also in the role as a consumer being well served in the marketplace, so that the markets serve the consumer and not the other way round.

name: Ева Майдел
text: of the IMCO Committee. – This directive is an example of legislation which, for the reason that it is quite technical, can be quite difficult to communicate for citizens. But this is an example of legislation that will significantly improve the functioning of the single market and therefore lead to much greater growth and will then be felt by consumers in their favour. This is because the Directive will lead to better enforcement of competition rules in the Member States. Eighty-five per cent of decisions on cases relating to the detection of non-competitive practices are taken precisely by the national authorities and this leads to fragmentation of the internal market and distortion of competition.  As rapporteur in the Committee on the Internal Market, I have, in my opinion, defended, on the one hand, the right of national authorities to have more leeway with their budgets allocated to them, and to improve their technical resources in order to give them the necessary powers to successfully uncover cartels of a cross-border nature. I believe that from poor competition and timid business there are lost benefits not only for the economy, but especially for consumers. That's why I welcome today's decision.

name: Markus Ferber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, rapporteur, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Although we like to talk about European competition law, we should always be mindful that, apart from some of the big cases that dominate the headlines, the actual work is not done by the Directorate-General for Competition, but by the national competition authorities in the Member States. In most years, for example, more than 85% of all decisions and decisions that apply EU antitrust law are adopted by national competition authorities. If we want competition law to be applied effectively in the sense of the social market economy, we therefore need strong national authorities that can do so. Today, we see major differences in the quality of national competition authorities. The range in the Member States ranges from powerful and independent authorities with several hundred employees to authorities with a handful of staff. There are also significant differences in the political independence of national competition authorities. We have competition authorities that can operate freely within their mandate, and we have competition authorities that are hanging on to the fringes of national policy. The length of the proceedings, the quality of the proceedings and the penal framework also vary considerably in the Member States of the European Union. The overall question is whether all national competition authorities are capable and willing to ensure effective enforcement of competition law. That is why it is right – and thank you very much to the rapporteur – that we can adopt common minimum standards today. That is why the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats strongly supports this proposal.

name: Tibor Szanyi
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, first of all let me thank all the shadow rapporteurs and rapporteur Schwab for the work we have done together.  The constructive approach I experienced in the procedure guaranteed that the European Parliament’s position was representing most of our views and we could stand for it unanimously in the procedure of the trilogue. I am personally very happy that this report, based on my request, approved by one of the previous annual competition reports.  As shadow rapporteur and also on behalf of the Socialist and Democratic Group, let me underline some points which were key elements for us to be able to support the procedure. Namely, strengthening national competition authorities and granting them more effective investigation, decision-making and sanctioning tools, granting sufficient independence from political interference and also in the allocation of the budget, to find solutions to divergences in leniency programmes in different Member States, to keep the maximum amount of fines at least at 10%, and that fines will be calculated on global turnover and not on relevant turnover.

name: Jasenko Selimovic
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the EU competition rules and the national competition authorities which are able to enforce them are the cornerstone of the proper functioning of our single market. However, many breaches of the competition laws still do occur. Each year losses of about EUR 250 billion happen because of the undiscovered cartels. These cartels are not raising the prices by 5% or 10%; they are raising prices by up to 30% and this situation is of course unsustainable. Why is it happening? Because the national competition authorities cannot enforce the rules. Some of them do not have proper human, technical and financial resources, some do not have proper tools in order to detect competition law infringements. Not all of the authorities can impose fines and not all competition authorities interpret competition law in the same way. My colleague, Andreas Schwab, in his excellent report has proposed to solve these problems. He proposed to reinforce the impartiality of national competition authorities, to provide them with a greater budgetary autonomy, to allow them to carry out joint inspections and to harmonise somehow the level of fines against competition infringement in the EU. This report is aimed for better implementation of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. As is said in Article 102: ‘Any abuse by one or more undertakings of a dominant position within the common market [...] shall be prohibited as incompatible with the common market’. I therefore urge the Member States and this Parliament to swiftly conduct a negotiation on the matter.

name: Bronis Ropė
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Dear President and honourable Commissioner; colleagues have today circulated a joint appeal signed by The Baltic MEPs to the Council, Parliament and the Commission, calling for the equalisation of payments to our farmers in the next financial period. Agriculture is an integral part of the single market and it is therefore necessary to give the European Union competition authorities powers that ensure equal treatment between farmers in all our Member States. As farmers in the Baltic states receive the lowest direct payments from the European Union, they find themselves in a particularly discriminatory competitive situation. I hope that both you, colleagues and representatives of the European Commission and the Council, will agree that Europe must take responsibility for all its farmers equally and that the payments must be brought to an end in the next period.

name: Paloma López Bermejo
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, national competition authorities are an essential tool for the control of a single market which focuses its objectives on economic aspects and on obtaining greater business benefits. The intention to move towards common standards for its operation and to improve its efficiency must be positively valued. However, this proposal for a Directive does not mean walking in the direction indicated. It's true that aspects like clemency programs improve. However, central aspects, such as the increase in the minimum amounts of sanctions, have not been taken into account. The stops set by the Commission are maintained, clearly insufficient. Fines in competition have a deterrent effect. Otherwise, they are meaningless, as committing wrongdoing is very cheap. We also regret that a minimum cooling-off period has not been established for those who have been related to specific reports and companies, thus avoiding conflicts of interest or revolving doors, so unfortunately known. Finally, the necessary independence of these bodies in their inspection and control work can only be ensured by ensuring sufficient resources by specific laws not subject to the interests of governments. There is no point in having competition rules if the inspectorate and supervisory bodies, at Member State level, are not able to carry out their work properly.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for This report seeks to strengthen the competence of the national supervisory authorities when it comes to competition in the single market, and I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Andreas Schwab, on a very good report. Among the important compromises that have been included in this report, I would like to draw attention to three. Firstly, the establishment of a legal framework for proceedings against anti-competitive institutions or companies which allows those proceedings to be shortened and the prosecution of those illegal practices to be made more effective. Secondly, it is a question of creating the possibility of repealing the obligation to impose penalties where the institutions or firms concerned disclose the existence of a price conspiracy or other conspiracy which is intended to distort the fundamentals of competition. These leniency procedures, as we call them, are important for a more effective fight against competition violations. Thirdly, we are imposing a limit on the financial penalties that will be applied to anti-competitive companies, and I believe that this proposal that they should be equal to at least 10% of the value of annual turnover is correct.  Finally, however, I would like to say that we have a lot of work ahead of us when it comes to competition in the single market, particularly in terms of service trade. There is a lot of work to be done, and here I would like to ask the Commission – and also our colleagues – to pay more attention to competition in the services market as well.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, consumers are willing to pay a fair price for comparable products and services. However, far too often fair price can be difficult to ascertain – as demonstrated by some recent cases in energy, food and the pharmaceutical sector. A fully independent and well—resourced national competition authority in cooperation with the European Commission is the best guarantee for a well—functioning internal market for EU consumers. Therefore, this text is crucial. Thanks go to the rapporteur and the negotiating team for achieving this outcome.  I particularly welcome that Parliament’s position on the level of fines, as well as the calculation base for the fines, on the global turnover of a company, was retained in the final agreement. Only if the NCAs have the right deferring instruments available will they be able to keep companies accountable and change their behaviour to the benefit of the end consumer. Commissioner, as a UK MEP, I’m concerned about how to ensure that the UK competition market authorities ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Commissioner, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The European Commission is working very successfully and very well with the competition authorities of the Member States in enforcing competition law. Since 2004, more than 1 000 enforcement decisions have been adopted together. What's the problem? The fact that fragmentation in the national application of the rules treats anti-competitive actors differently from one country to another, and that it is also possible for cartels to escape fines simply by carrying out restructuring. It is therefore right and necessary that we demand more harmonisation in the enforcement of competition law and more harmonisation of the powers and resources of competition authorities. Our rapporteur, Andreas Schwab, has very clearly outlined the development that has been initiated here – a thank you for that. There are, in fact, four clear areas. Tomorrow, we will adopt a more coordinated leniency regime, which will encourage companies to present evidence of secret cartels, a deterrent penalty of up to 10% of total global turnover, better protection of consumers against illegal business practices and a response to the new distortions of competition that the digital age is bringing. In this way, we are strengthening the eco-social market economy and competition policy as the heart of the internal market. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: President. –
text: Mr Karas, my apologies, seriously it’s not just about us in the Chamber now, it’s about the colleagues who will come in for the other items, let’s be fair. I think that the point was clear so thank you.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, last but not least! I’d like to start by congratulating the rapporteur and by welcoming the proposal as the latter aims at strengthening national competition authorities, granting them more effective investigation, decision—making and sanctioning tools, considering that some national competition authorities do not have sufficient independence from political interference as well as all the tools they need to detect and tackle competition law infringements. I share the opinion that, in order to ensure protection of consumers and fair competition between companies in the internal market, strong and effective enforcement of EU anti—trust rules is of paramount importance. I believe that the new rules will ensure a level playing field in terms of powers and tools as all national competition authorities should have to properly enforce EU competition laws, investigate possible breaches and apply sanctions. Finally, dear colleagues, I would like to pinpoint that I support full independence of national competition authorities so they can carry out their work without undue influence.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by This is a theoretically technical directive, but it is very important for consumers. I will immediately add that I am a realist and do not believe that a common denominator for services and an identical price can be found on the European market, but that does not mean that this should not be pursued. While in goods we are slowly approaching a similar composition, similar information, safeguarding certain basic interests of consumers, we still have a problem in services. I am very pleased that the directive itself takes into account the sovereignty of national supervisory authorities, but also complements those tools that they use and use in Europe to make them more effective, in short.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, it is a given that the aim of the directive is to increase the powers of national competition authorities, and I think that is very important. Of course, we must be careful that there is no conflict of interest, that there is independence and that there is no political influence. The aim, of course, as analysed, is to support consumer rights.  I would like to refer to a serious issue of lack of competition in Greece, with regard to air ticket prices, where Aegean is essentially now a monopoly. The prices it imposes for air transport from Crete and the other islands to central Greece, and especially to Athens, are excessive. It is cheaper to go from Athens to Berlin than to go from Heraklion, Crete to Athens. The situation is intolerable and I think it is time for the Competition Committee to check aegean, because it has a monopoly position on the market, and I would also like you, Commissioner responsible, to look into the matter.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, in general, I would like to note that the increase in powers for the European institutions should be conditional on the transparency of this process, and I would like to point out on this proposed directive that we should convince citizens and Member States of the independence of each European institution, that is to say, it complies with the rules laid down, including the procedures for investigation. This concerns, in particular, competition and rules on equal competition. The joint fight against cartels and other forms of free market cheating is one of the achievements of the European Union, where the Institutions of the European Union are able to harmonise with local organisations, thus creating a fair environment for all. Cooperation with Member States is also important in other matters. It is important to be able to explain to the citizens of the European Union that the role of the European Union in this case is not to monitor the Member States, but to cooperate with them as a matter of priority. At a time of rising populism, which often benefits precisely from scepticism towards the European Union, it is important to devote itself to this work and to bring Brussels' actions closer not only to the Member States, but also to citizens.

name: Margrethe Vestager
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the very specific question, among others, Ms Bermejo: the 10% cap is a minimum so that Member States may provide for a higher cap, which also means higher fines because there are differences and there are also differences in tradition. But I think the very clear message from Parliament is that we need higher fines in order to get a better deterrent, and if you do something illegal, it should be felt in the level of fines. Second, I think it was a very important compromise that we reached on exactly the question of a cooling-off period, because independence from political decision—makers is one thing, but also independence in your mind so that you avoid the revolving doors between business and the authorities is a very important point, which is why we focused on the decision-making parts of the competition authority, and I think these compromises are very balanced and very good.  Also, thank you very much for the very specific example of what the risk of a monopoly is, because sometimes people think ‘well, this is out of a textbook, what is this nonsense, it’s theory’. No, no it is real life. There is a very obvious risk when you have a monopoly that prices go up and you see it and people feel it. I want to thank you – because this is only enabled because there is a very strong cooperation with the rapporteur and a strong report – the Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee of course as such, but also all the shadow rapporteurs who have engaged very thoroughly in enabling the compromises that ended up with a political agreement. For us, the Commission, it was very important with this involvement from the side of Parliament. It is the second time, and this has been a full involvement of Parliament, and I think it also paves the way for the future. I would also like to thank the Bulgarian Presidency, because they did a very important job: to make sure that things were clear, that there was a clear mandate from the Council, so that the negotiations could proceed. Of course, this has been difficult, but we have a lot of things ahead of us still, because now comes the important point of transposing this directive into national legislation so that it becomes real life, and of course the Commission is fully dedicated to enabling the national legislative authorities to transpose this in a correct way. This is our priority, but it will not change the fact that we of course stand by our promise that we have committed to look into how interim measures are adopted within the European competition network within two years from the transposition date. This, of course we will do, because the rest of the work should not stop because we have this ahead of us. We will do this with the help of our partners, again with the help of our national authority, and the result of that endeavour will of course be available not only for your information, but also for your discussion as well as with the Council. Wholeheartedly, thank you very much for the constructive cooperation so far and for the very constructive debate tonight.

name: Andreas Schwab
text: Rapporteur. Mr Vice-President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the work she has I can only return the thanks. I believe that we have actually managed to find really good compromises at many interfaces, and I would like to return to what colleagues have just said. I just believe – and this is perhaps something that still divides Mrs Lépez Bermejo and myself – although we have worked very well together – that, of course, the rights of defence of companies and the leniency scheme, even if they are perhaps a little difficult to understand at first glance, will ultimately bring more to citizens and consumers, because they will create transparency. , which the Commission or the competition authorities alone could not provide for. Secondly, I believe that we have also succeeded in finding a good compromise with regard to independence and resources – As Mrs Maydell and also Mr Karas pointed out – which, on the one hand, respects the budgetary sovereignty of the Member States, but on the other hand offers the national authorities the necessary flexibility and investigative capacity.  All this can, of course, only be particularly successful if there is a good and constructive atmosphere in this European network of competition law. The European Commission is, of course, responsible for this. I believe, Commissioner, that you have done this very well over the last four years. It is, of course, also a matter of course, of the mood of colleagues in the Member States who feel taken care of. In the end, we did not get into a major dispute about the level of sanctions. The question is what the calculation scale must be. In this respect, I still find it questionable from a legal point of view that we should take as its basis the overall world of a company, because the competence of the European Union is, of course, necessarily limited to the European legal framework. However, by the fact that the European Commission ends up denying this penalty with other antitrust authorities at international level, I think that the majority, which wanted to go in a different direction here, can certainly be followed. I therefore believe that, on the whole, we have found really viable compromises. It will now be a question of further examining the question for the Digital Single Market – which we did not do here in the end – to what extent interim measures are actually a possibility here. But you promised, Commissioner, that we would look into this. That is why we are curious to see what this examination will ultimately reveal. With this in mind, I would like to thank all those who have contributed.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The agenda item concludes with this. The vote will take place on Wednesday 14 November 2018.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the Commission's statement on the regulation of virtual currencies and ICO issues (2018/2923(RSP)).

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, there is continued excitement and speculation on initial coin offerings and crypto-assets. To the proponents they present a new paradigm for the internet and watching-based value transfer systems that can overcome shortcomings inherent in systems of corresponding banking between intermediaries. They also offer enormous potential for simple and fast capital raising and the figures are quite impressive. Widely quoted estimates are that this year to date more than USD 21 billion was raised in over 900 initial coin offerings globally and this is more than three times the amount raised in 2017. Sceptics believe that crypto-assets and initial coin offerings are not serious, that they are vehicles for fraud and manipulation, tools for speculation, manipulation and money laundering. For the Commission, crypto-assets and initial coin offerings present most opportunities and risks.  It is still early days and the technology has a long way to go, but we believe that crypto-assets are here to stay. The underlying blockchain technology is very promising for our digital economy, which we should embrace and support.  Crypto-assets cannot be separated from blockchain technology. Blockchains, as opposed to much broader categories of distributed leisure technology, are chains of crypto-asset transactions. Pursuing the opportunities of blockchain implies that we take an interest in crypto-assets, both in terms of the advantages they offer but also to address risks they may present. The Commission was closely involved and fully subscribes to the Financial Stability Board’s assessment that, for the time being, crypto-assets do not pose a financial stability risk. This may however change if the market grows quickly. The market remains volatile and presents significant investor protection and market integrity risks. Warnings to investors about risks may not be sufficient. Rules of the road are necessary, not only to protect investors and increase market integrity but also to provide legal clarity and certainty for a legitimate crypto-asset ecosystem.  We have already expanded the scope of EU anti-money laundering and anti-terrorist finance legislation to crypto-asset exchanges and wallet providers through the recent fifth Anti-Money Laundering Directive.  The main question for financial regulators is whether crypto-assets are financial instruments and therefore covered by financial regulation. The second question is whether that regulation is suitable and addresses the risks while supporting and enabling the opportunities. There are no simple answers to these questions. Whether the current EU financial regulatory framework applies to crypto-assets on the one hand depends on the specific characteristics of each crypto-asset. On the other hand, it largely depends on how EU law is applied in national law and supervision. Financial regulation and definitions of financial instruments were developed before the age of crypto-assets and initial coin offerings. It is therefore often not clear whether they are covered or not, even if they present similar features to financial instruments. We are assessing this together with the European supervisory authorities, which are expected to present their conclusions by the end of the year. Without jumping to conclusions, the Commission notes that some Member States have already established that existing law is not applicable or that it is not suitable and they are developing sui generis frameworks. Other Member States consider that at least some crypto-assets fall within existing definitions of financial instruments, but even in these cases, applying existing growth raises complex, practical and enforcement questions. Crypto-assets that do not meet the definition of financial instruments, whether under EU or national law, also present investor protection and market integrity issues. So this legal twilight zone is not good for a single market, it’s not good for developing a potential new source of market-based finance and it’s not good for investor protection and market integrity. Following the conclusions of the European supervisory authorities’ legal mapping exercise, the Commission will assess the possible way forward. Thank you and I look forward to hearing your views on this topic.

name: Markus Ferber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Virtual currencies have received a lot of attention in recent years, first because of their promise to revolutionize payment transactions, and later because of the rapid price rally of many virtual currencies. If you look at how they are being used, it quickly becomes clear that they cannot deliver on the promise of a revolution. In view of the enormous price gains that Bitcoin & Co. have had in the meantime, virtual currencies became interesting for many private investors as speculative objects. They were often held as a substitute for stocks, bonds or gold. Unlike other financial instruments, however, virtual currencies are completely unregulated. The markets for these currencies are opaque, volatile and prone to manipulation. Many investors have suffered a total loss because they have participated in windy initial coin offerings. This regulatory Wild West must be stopped. When private investors invest in virtual currencies, they should be able to be sure of a certain level of protection throughout the European Union. The good news is that, in principle, all the elements of sensible regulation already exist. We have consumer protection rules, we have provisions against market abuse, and we have already established transparency rules in other areas. There is now the possibility: either we take these requirements for a tailor-made regulatory framework, or we clearly define under what conditions virtual currencies can already be classified in this legal framework today. Both would work, and I can only call on the Commission to act in this direction. We need a European solution, not 28 national solutions.

name: Pervenche Berès
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Madam President, Commissioner, we know that cryptocurrencies bring about profound changes in the economy and financial services and that they sometimes inflame engineers. The initial offer of tokens offers entrepreneurs new opportunities to raise funds for their projects through crowdfunding. Like any technological advance, it requires a framework that accompanies innovation by protecting users from possible excesses. In the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, we have refused to include these virtual currencies in the draft regulation on the European provision of crowdfunding for businesses. There was no place. However, we believe that there is an urgent need for the Commission to act. As you said, Commissioner, some Member States are starting to prepare their own legislation. So what is the Commission doing when we know that there is an urgent need to protect investors, to issue obligations to inform potential investors about the risks involved and, of course, to put in place effective and unified supervision to combat all sources of fraud that might arise from the development of this sector. Acting early to remove the ICO (initial coin offering or initial token offers) from their legal vacuum will enable Europe to participate fully in the development of this market under acceptable conditions, without creating a new source of excesses and frauds. Then it will be too late to control the situation. Commissioner, I know you have little time left, but you must act. What are you going to do?

name: Marisa Matias
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, I think that the debate on initial coin offers should start with issues as simple as fundamental. What are initial currency offers or virtual currencies for? Why will costly systems that aim to generate trust, by freeing and fleeing public regulation, have anything to offer from the point of view of the general interest? Behind much ideological fanfare about a brave new financial world, endless schemes of tax evasion, money laundering, speculation or just pure and hard fraud have been revealed. For our part, we are available to discuss any regulatory effort that adequately responds to these problems. If this regulatory effort is successful, which is not always the case, we may see a sudden decrease in the already decreasing levels of interest in these types of operations. If so, for us that's fine, but for our part we are not available to continue in this pseudo-legislative ping pong that eludes people and solves absolutely nothing.

name: David Coburn
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, once again the EU seeks to stifle rather than encourage competition. Today it wants to regulate virtual currencies: currencies which compete as a store of value with the euro. The intention is not to nurture these exciting developments – which provide individuals with an alternative to being trapped in the failing euro – but to close off all escape routes for capital, both physical – as I mentioned before – and now virtual. All in preparation for the next eurozone crisis hurtling towards us like the Milan express in the form of a collapse of confidence in the Italian Government debt. My message to investors regarding the euro is the same as to the British cabinet: get out while you can.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Cryptocurrencies are a kind of private money issued by market participants, and this is natural because they offer some important advantages. Firstly, the speed of the trading circuit, secondly, the whole history of existing transactions, which is recorded in a very innovative blockchain technology. These are certainly attractive matters and, moreover, they also offer anonymity, which is more controversial because anonymity actually also allows us to hide the source of funds and to carry out various illegal transactions. But I want to say here, contrary to what my honourable erigo tried to say, that this is not enough for virtual currencies to become money. Money, as the science of economics teaches, is a public good because it should provide certain important characteristics, such as, above all, stability and state guarantees. Virtual currencies will never have these characteristics, they can actually perform only one only function of money, namely, they can be a means of storing value. But for that to be the case, they must become financial instruments, and on this point, of course, I agree with the Commissioner, and with the speeches, that regulation is needed, in the public interest, in the interests of investors. It must not be the case that we have a kind of Wild West in this regard, as Mr Ferber said. I am not against virtual currencies, but I warn: They will never be money, as long as governments do not collect taxes in this money, and it will not be.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Commissioner, I am shocked by your complacent excitement about blockchain technology and the cryptocurrencies it supports. It is in line, in the background, of Member States such as Malta, where the Prime Minister recently said at the United Nations that it was the island of blockchain Europe, which is highly worrying because it is obvious that mafia organizations have been taking advantage of these unregulated technologies, which are therefore support of cryptocurrencies, to launder capital, to evade taxes and to finance all kinds of crime , including terrorism. ESMA and EBA have been warning of the risks incurby consumers exposed to these fraudulent and speculative schemes. Economist Nouriel Roubini has been denouncing cryptocurrencies as shitcoins and blockchain technology that underpins it as the most overvalued technology ever. Nobel Prize winner Stiglitz warns: "You can't have a payment method based on secrecy when you're trying to create a transparent financial system."  If we open a hole with a bitcoin, then all the harmful and illegal activities will go through that hole and no government should allow that, let alone the European Commission, Mr. Commissioner. Please regulate, regulate and do not leave this fragmentation that we are already seeing there in several Member States. Regulate and don't let these virtual currencies and so-called initial coin offerings, etc. be seen as an El Dorado. If they are true financial transactions, then they have to be treated as such and regulated as crowdfunding operations or capital increases. There is an urgent need for the Commission to prevent dangerous drifts such as the one we have seen in Malta and to produce European regulations that end the vacuum of crime and European governments must also urgently ensure that their FIU and other law enforcement have the technological and human means necessary to dismantle criminal applications of these dangerously deceptive technologies and to end the impunity of the criminals who exploit them.

name: Tom Vandenkendelaere (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the temptation is great for investors. The Bitcoin, the Ether, the Litecoin, the Ripple, they all promise huge returns that you can never achieve with traditional savings products. But anyone who invests in Bitcoins and other virtual currencies, to date, gets into a roller coaster without seat belts to have.  As an investment, the risk is enormous: the price really goes all the way; there is no intervention from banks or countries; There are no rules, and there is no supervision.  If something goes wrong, like your digital wallet being hacked, you can't go anywhere. The need for action is an understatement. We all agree on that. In addition to the need for consumer protection, there is another adder: a potential jackpot combined with anonymity naturally attracts investors, but unfortunately also criminal organisations. Exact figures are missing, but according to rough estimates, it is more than 7 billion euros of criminal cryptocurrency annually. The key question with this is: can we make the link between the online user and the real identity behind these coins? With Bitcoin you can, but dash, for example, can't. We have to keep that in mind when we start regulating. Last question: who should regulate? Well, the players of this game are unfortunately not bound to our European borders alone. A G-20 initiative on a global framework for regulating and controlling virtual currencies is therefore necessary. But don't let that stop us, dear Commissioner. Time is money, especially in this case. Literally even. Only by intervening quickly and consistently will we be able to systematically close the loopholes.

name: Anne Sander (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome this debate on virtual currencies and initial offers of tokens. In recent years, we have seen significant increase in the use of virtual currencies and initial token offerings around the world, particularly in Europe. These financial innovations open up opportunities for the speed and multiplicity of uses, but they also carry certain risks, including money laundering or fraud. The fifth anti-money laundering directive provides for several provisions on virtual currencies, but this is not enough and nothing has been thought for the tokens issued during the initial offers. It is therefore necessary to examine the world of crypto-assets as a whole, which includes, among others, tokens and virtual currencies. It is crucial not to leave a legal vacuum and a framework should be developed that can provide better security for investors as well as control tools in the hands of regulators. While their classification as a financial instrument may seem like an attractive option, it is necessary to measure all the implications and, in particular, the risk of applying unsuitable rules to this nascent sector. The Europe that protects has a great opportunity to take shape with its citizens. It is therefore important for the Commission to take up this and to develop a European approach that is both protective and intelligent while giving way to innovation.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Disregard for cryptocurrencies or, as the Commissioner rightly so, probably uses this category, crypto assets is a serious mistake, and it is a double error. Because, on the one hand, it is an underestimation of the development of technology and, consequently, the consequences of the development of these technologies and, on the other hand, of very serious risks.  In the discussion itself, quite short, there were at least five such serious comments, critical remarks, and expectations as well. This is a question of responsibility – there is no responsibility for crypto assets. Beneficiaries who may lose their income. The third element – operations that are nontransparent. Very often, suspicious operations are financed from cryptocurrencies or crypto assets. But also a risk assessment, which, in my opinion, is still underestimated.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, in this Chamber we demand control of the financial system. We demand transparency and control at the European Central Bank, national central banks and other banks. It is now a given that we have achieved this to some extent. But is it possible to leave an entire sector, cryptocurrencies, without control and without transparency and, in essence, to allow a process through which tax evasion, tax avoidance, money laundering and complete opacity are legitimised? Because that is what this is about: cryptocurrencies together with the blockchain do, in essence, exactly that and there should be control. The European Union cannot be indifferent and we need very specific legislation. It is a given that the process through cryptocurrencies actually facilitates money laundering and we must act decisively.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to start by saying that this idea may have been a good idea, but it can nevertheless become a nightmare, or, he would be a good servant, but an evil master. I did not understand unequivocally from the Commissioner's speech whether he was covered by any European regulation. I understood that it was more up to the Member States. I'm quite afraid of this rule. I think that this virtual currency could undermine our monetary rules, the global order, and I don't think that's entirely happy. There are also environmental impacts, it is estimated that only the mining of these virtual currencies, for example, consumes energy such as denmark's year-round consumption. One Czech pirate MP even benefited from these cryptocurrencies with czech taxpayers' money in his parliamentary apartment. We clearly need rules, we need transparency and we need to protect our consumers, our citizens against speculation and manipulation. I think that the global response is also important, and in this the European Union should definitely be a leader.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, let me first come back to some of the points which have been raised during this debate. For example, Mr Rosati and some other colleagues were raising the point of cryptocurrencies actually not being currencies. That’s why, from the European Commission side, we also change the terminology and we’re no longer talking about cryptocurrencies, we’re talking about cryptoassets. Because, indeed, there is only one currency in the euro area and it’s the euro, so the rest is cryptoassets. Second, on the need also for international cooperation in this area. Cryptoassets and blockchains are a global phenomenon. As regards policy and regulation, to be effective it also needs to be internationally coordinated, so we need to do our homework here at EU level but also need to coordinate this work internationally. At the EU level, as I said, we need to complete our assessment of the applicability and suitability of existing rules and, together with European supervisory authorities, we intend to do so by the end of the year. Based on this assessment, then we need to look at what is the best way forward for risks to be confined and monitored, consumers and investors to be protected and innovation to be encouraged. In addressing legal uncertainty and risks for market integrity, investor and consumer protection or security requirements, we should not throw the baby out with the bathwater. The underlying technologies which make cryptoassets work and spread have major potential across sectors. It is a new development, so we need to make an informed decision to find a right balance. So, once again, based on assessment of the applicability and suitability of existing rules and regulations, the Commission will consider if measures are required at EU level to seize opportunities and address the risks.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. – Crypto-assets and Initial Coin Offerings (ICOs) are innovative ways to store value or raise capital quickly. Both have clear benefits for investors and savers. However, it is unclear whether the current national and European definitions of financial instruments cover crypto-assets and whether the applicable financial rules apply to them. The regulatory framework and taxonomy were developed before the rise of crypto-assets and ICOs. The market for these products and services remains very volatile and carries significant risks in the area of investor protection and market integrity. Warning of these risks may not be enough. Rules are necessary to provide clarity and legal certainty for the crypto-ecosystem. Under the fifth Anti-Money Laundering Directive, the scope has already been extended to crypto-asset exchanges. This is a step in the right direction. At the same time, however, innovation in the financial sector must not be hindered, which is why, from a regulatory point of view, a balance must be struck between promoting innovation and protecting market integrity. Investor protection risk must be mitigated without hindering investment in the development of crypto-assets and blockchain technologies.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: Next item is the Statement by the Council and the Commission on EU Member States' support for the UN Global Agreement on Migration (2018/2924(RSP))

name: Karoline Edtstadler
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, thank you for inviting me to this debate on an issue which, I know, has generated some concern. At the outset, let me state very clearly that I am here in my capacity as the Presidency and not to defend or comment on national decisions or standpoints. Migration is a global phenomenon requiring the engagement of the whole global community to deliver global responses. This debate and your intention to be present with a delegation of Members of Parliament at the intergovernmental conference in Marrakech, where the Global Compact for Safe, Orderly and Regular Migration will be politically endorsed, demonstrate the importance you attach to this initiative. Since the first draft of the global compact was put on the table, Member States have engaged in extensive discussion on the document in the Council, during both the Bulgarian and the Austrian Presidency. Member States also actively engaged in a discussion in New York, where six rounds of intergovernmental negotiations were held on this document. Of course, the preparation of the global compact had started well before that, with the adoption of the new Declaration for Refugees and Migrants in September 2016. From then on, the EU actively engaged in providing input at the various stages of preparation of the first draft of the compact. Let me seize the opportunity to comment on the role of the UN High Commission on Refugees in the process of the debates in the Council. Representatives of this key partner body were invited to various Council meetings to ensure that Member States had the most up-to-date and complete information when debating the global compact, the final draft of which was the document put on the table in July. As you are aware, the Council does not have a common position on this text, which will be considered and handled by each Member State. The political endorsement of the global compact at the intergovernmental conference in Marrakech and the subsequent adoption of the document in New York at the UN General Assembly session in January will not be the final steps in the process. One of the crucial elements of our success in the field of migration is our good cooperation with third countries. I can assure you that the Council and the Presidency will continue to contribute to that purpose.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I welcome this opportunity to join you today to discuss the UN Global Compact for Safe, Orderly and Regular Migration, in particular as we approach the final stage of the process – its adoption. In our globalised world, human mobility can only be addressed effectively by the international community as a whole. It is a global phenomenon that requires global solutions, a global response. No country can manage this alone, but together we can set up a humane, dignified and secure mechanism for governing human mobility. This is why the Commission strongly supports the Global Compacts and will be actively engaging in their follow—up. Over the past years, the European Union has built a comprehensive approach to address migration and forced displacement. Our approach has proved to be the right one and delivers results. All this was possible thanks to our common work inside the European Union, and to strong cooperation with our partners, in our region and also worldwide. Our approach is based on solidarity, shared responsibility, multilateralism and engagement. And this is exactly what the UN Global Compact for Migration is about, as the UN compact on refugees.  The Migration Compact is the result of two years of intensive consultations and negotiations at the UN level, involving governments and other actors. It is the first ever agreement at international level on migration. The commitment to work together to improve cooperation on international migration in order to make it safe, orderly and regular. We all know that the text is not perfect. As you know, ‘perfect’ is the enemy of good! As in any international negotiations, EU Member States had to make compromises with states from other regions in the world that have a different perspective on migration. But overall, we have good reasons to be satisfied with the Global Compact on Migration.  The final text of the GCM contains many actions that will help us firstly to improve the situation for migrants; secondly, to reduce irregular migration; thirdly, to address the drivers of migration, fight trafficking in human beings and migrant smuggling, and manage borders and facilitate return and readmission.  Several misconceptions on the compacts have been floating around. I think we need to address them. First, the compact is not legally binding. It will not create any legal obligations for States. It is a menu of policy actions and best practices from which States may draw to implement their national migration policies. More than that, it is fully in line with the principle of national sovereignty and fully respects the sovereign right of States to determine their national migration policies. Second, the compact does not encourage migration, nor does it discourage it; what it aims at is that migration takes place in a safe and orderly manner. It contains no language to promote a ‘human right to migrate’, but it stresses the need to protect migrants’ human rights. Migration has been part of the human experience throughout history. It is our task to make it work for all. The compact as an international cooperative framework will usefully underpin our existing work with third countries and international organisations such as IOM and UNHCR. It will also serve as a platform for new partnerships. Europe is already at the forefront of migration and has a developed migration policy with high standards for migrants and refugees. The compacts will allow promoting the same standards outside the Union borders, thus improving international cooperation on migration in all its aspects. It will help to jointly turn migration from a European and national challenge into a shared one, and into an opportunity for human development, in line with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. We all supported the UN initiative to hold a high-level meeting on migration at the 2016 United Nations General Assembly (UNGA). The unanimously adopted New York Declaration launched the work on the two Global Compacts, on refugees and on migration.  The EU took an early lead in the discussions on the Global Migration Compact and participated actively in the preparatory work. Our delegation in New York has been working closely with our Member States in order to ensure that the European Union’s priorities were reflected in the final text. We have done so together with the 27 Member States that have been actively negotiating and speaking with one voice.  This has allowed us to bring forward a Global Migration Compact that largely reflects European objectives and respects our key concerns. We therefore regret the decision by some EU Member States not to support the Global Compact on Migration. It is their national decision, which does not affect the position of the Commission.  The Commission will continue our work to improve migration management worldwide. This is what the EU acquis on migration and development leads to. We will notably continue our engagement with the IOM, which will lead on the implementation of and follow-up to the compact, which will entail sharing experiences, helping countries to overcome shortcomings and searching for solutions to a global issue.  We will also continue to support partnerships at bilateral, regional and global level in the area of migration. With our partners in the world, the Migration Compact will be an important basis for cooperation along with what has been agreed as the common EU approach to migration. Here our common work and your contribution as the European Parliament will be essential, dear colleagues.

name: Kinga Gál
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – If we read the UN global migration package thoroughly, it becomes clear that it does not reflect Europe's interests, it is not for Europe. The document makes migration a positive phenomenon, blurs illegal economic migration with the issue of genuine refugees and legal migration, and makes illegal migration a fundamental right. The adoption of the package would therefore have irreversible consequences, due to the interpretation of the law and the development of customs, which are contrary to the interests of the European people. At the same time, they are contrary to the interests of the Third World, because they suggest false, unfulmountable promises of better prosperity, while many third countries will lose their working generations and this illusion will lead to more and more individual tragedies.  I consider it fortunate that, following Hungary, Austria and Bulgaria are also withdrawing from the process of adopting the package and that a number of other Member States are considering withdrawing from the migration pact, such as Estonia. I see that more and more people are realise that this is a document that is offensive to national interests and dangerous to our Europe. The way out of the migration crisis is to separate subsistence immigrants from genuine refugees outside the EU, to make returns more efficient and to help third countries by addressing the real root causes of mass migration, rather than dissemploying the problem.

name: Elena Valenciano
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President. It is that I am a little perplexed, Mrs Gál, because the European People's Party supported the Resolution supporting the United Nations Global Compact for Migration, that is, this Parliament has already spoken in favour. You should know, because you are a member of this Parliament. The Austrian presidency should know that too. That this Parliament supports the United Nations Global Compact for Migration. I am not going to define what the pact is, because Commissioner Stylianides has done much better than I would. What I do tell you is that it produces much sadness and great shame that your Government has decided not to support this pact. It produces sadness because it's a very unsy intelligent decision. Because we, Europe, are the most interested in global migration management, and we have always demanded it. And it is embarrassing, very embarrassing, that a government like yours does not want to support a multilateral perspective on migration management. And much more shame comes when you are presiding over the European Union right now. And I do not know how you are going to represent the European Union in Marrakesh if your Government has decided not to follow the pact. I ask you to reconsider. We cannot weaken a position which is a global position, which benefits not only the European Union but the dignity of all people. You are representing us all, and that is why you have a greater obligation than others. Hungary seems to be desisting from the pact. Czech Republic too. Poland too. You guys want to follow that path? The path of closed nationalism, xenophobia, the exclusion of human beings who need our help. Are you really going to maintain that position and continue to preside over the European Union? We are deeply ashamed of its position and saddened, if any, that Austria has decided not to support a global pact for the dignified and orderly management of migration.

name: Jussi Halla-aho
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, the Global Compact for Migration (GCM) is a non-binding policy paper. However, many countries, including the US, Australia and some members of the EU, have already declared that they will not join this declaration, as they believe it would limit their sovereignty in immigration matters. In terms of content, the GCM is a misguided and dangerous document. What Europe is facing is a century of massive migratory pressure from Africa and the Middle East. This is an existential threat to our societies. You simply cannot tackle this kind of a problem with a migration policy that is only focused on the rights of the individual migrant or by opening new legal avenues to Europe or by silencing criticism with hate speech legislation. We need effective tools to curb mass immigration from the Third World. The GCM, unfortunately, does not offer such tools, and therefore, it would be wise for all EU Member States to withdraw from it.

name: Michel Reimon
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The UN migration pact is the first global agreement on such an issue and is completely non-binding. Nevertheless, there is resistance from Donald Trump, to Viktor Orban, to Sebastian Kurz in his role as Presidency of the Council, at least at the same time, while he is President-in-Office of the Council. This is shameful for Austria, and I would like to say this first.  It is laudable for the Commissioner to explain here the substance of the content of this resistance, which is not justified. But I also believe that it is wrong to argue in substance. It is not a question of substance, it is a cultural issue. It is a matter of fear. The question here is: do we want international cooperation in a more complex world, or do we want to retreat to nation states and try to regulate everything ourselves and on our own? That is the question that is being discussed and decided here. We see how certain right-wing governments want to interpret and decide them. International cooperation has been growing for 70 years, and that is a good thing. Now we are dealing with a fundamental question: will this continue in the future, or will some right-wing governments succeed in dismantling and turning it back in the coming decades?  There is a lot to criticise. This is a pact that wants to manage migration and not solve it as a problem. Mass migration occurs when there is war, when there is hunger, when climate change drives people to flee. These are problems that we should solve. I would like to point out that we in the European Parliament, too, are constantly triggering such problems. We are making trade agreements with Africa that trigger flight. We are making fisheries agreements with Asia and Africa that trigger this. We are not sufficiently committed to conflicts in Syria, Yemen and so on. We should prevent mass migration and not manage it.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, the global pact for emigration is a source of great hope. The UN Secretary-General has titled his initial report "Making Immigration Good for All." This pact, in order to rally as many people as possible, as you said, is the subject of compromises, but for me, the account is not there. In an age of globalization and increasing interconnectivity, not all human beings are equal in law and dignity in the face of mobility and migration. This right is only open to one third of the world's inhabitants and, on closer inspection, the pact is aimed primarily at the other two thirds, those of the South. Let us imagine that each of the objectives of the pact is applied to migrants with European nationality. There are 60 million, almost twice the number of African migrants. They should therefore be concerned. If this pact is just a governance tool to block immigration from the south, it is a decoy. Detention must remain the exception, it is said. Evictions must be done in accordance with international law, without risk to life and without exposure to inhumane treatment, according to specific procedures that respect legality. Whose act, let's be positive.  Let us therefore hope that every State that signs this pact will respect it to the letter so that all migrants live decently, regardless of their status, in all territories, respecting fundamental rights and freedoms. Let us look, here or elsewhere, at the reality of the migration figures, as the first objective of the pact rightly invites us. Let the Union uphold its principles, chick!

name: Laura Ferrara
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have been saying for a long time that the response to migration needs a global strategy and that the countries most affected by it cannot be left alone. We have always advocated cooperation in removing the causes of irregular and uncontrolled migratory flows and preventing the thousands of lives of fleeing people from ending up in the networks of criminals. There are currently 258 million migrants living outside their countries of origin.  The Global Compact goes in the direction of safe, orderly, regular migration and incorporates the need often called for by this Parliament to have shared principles, objectives and responsibilities and, in essence, to strengthen international cooperation. It is therefore a pity that several European states have already announced that they do not agree with its content, because once again national self-interest will prevent Europe from having a strong unique voice in better managing international migration in all its dimensions.

name: Harald Vilimsky
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to express pride in the Austrian Federal Government. I would like to say thank you to Sebastian Kurz, thanks to Heinz-Christian Strache, who, as Vice-Chancellor, was certainly the driving force behind the Austrian rejection. I would like to say thank you to Viktor Orban, I would like to say thank you Poland, Croatia, the Czech Republic and, since yesterday, also the Bulgarians who are leaving. I hope that Denmark, too, will choose the path of exit. I hope that Italy will choose the path of exit here. I would like to use my opportunities, as a partner in our ranks, to convince this part of the Italian Government with the arguments of the Austrian Council of Ministers to reject this in Italy. Why? Because this pact contains more than 40 commitments. I know that this will not become a primary legal component, but it will be about customary international law, it will certainly interfere with national decision-making sovereignty through decisions of the highest courts. And I know that listening to the political left – whether the Greens, Socialists, Communists and how they argue against it – I know how right this rejection of this pact is. And even if Jean-Claude Juncker speaks against it, I know that we are right with this rejection. We are sticking with it, and we are proud of it.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I shall begin by reading Article 13 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights: "Everyone has the right to move freely and to choose his residence in the territory of a State. Everyone has the right to leave any country, including his own and return to his own country." End of date. The European Union's commitment to migrants and refugees must be firm, and also to the Global Compact. The Emergency Trust Fund to Combat the Causes of Migration in Africa or the Union's Migration and Asylum Legislative Package are two key tools of the Union to help alleviate this situation. In an interdependent world, the most effective way for the international community to address these challenges is to do so together. The Union has a duty to show its link to these agreements, especially when other actors, such as the United States, are profiled. The European Union and its Member States should be seen, both within and outside their borders, as guarantors and protectors of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the 1951 Geneva Convention on the Status of Refugees and also of this comprehensive agreement.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: – Dear President! The dust raised recently by a non-binding, political global agreement on migration is throwing a bad light on Europe, challenging the credibility of sincere intentions of tackling major global challenges. Withdrawing EU countries from the deal is a race to see who gets to the bottom first and get closer to Trump's way of world regulation. He believes only in: "everyone for themselves," "only us and no one else" and "negative consequences exist," "promises of nothing apply." Is this the future we want? After the US and Australia withdrew from the deal, Hungary announced their resignation, then Austria, yesterday Bulgaria, scepticism remain czech, Poland, Croatia.  The global agreement, which will be formally adopted in Marrakesh as a declaration, does not open the door to migration, does not equalify migrants with refugees and is not contrary to international and European law. What is more, the agreement protects the interests of countries and confirms their sovereignty over migration management. The agreement is also pragmatic on the most difficult issues and strikes a healthy balance between the rights of states and their general obligations.  Unfortunately, it is particularly being used by right-wing politicians such as Orban, or in my country, Slovenia, by opposition parties, to abuse it for intimidation and manipulation and to distract from other major issues. The Social Democrats remain firmly committed to the global agreement and the honourable Austrian Presidency, and you have made agreements on cooperation and multilateralism one of the priorities in the field of foreign policy. But your moves testify to the contrary.  And I wonder whether the current governments in Vienna, Budapest and Warsaw would be able to agree and establish a community like the European Union today? I don't think so. So what future do you devote to future generations?

name: Richard Sulík (ECR).
text: – Madam President, we regularly hear that the migration pact is non-binding, that it is completely non-binding. Indeed, Article 7 says that this pact is non-binding. But I ask: what is the point of signing a non-binding pact? So what is it about when the pact is non-binding and does it not entail any obligations? However, the reality is that in the text itself the word 'commitment' is found 86 times! We are going to sign a non-binding pact that contains the word commitment 86 times! At the same time, the reality is that we are entering into a strong political commitment, and if a country wants to behave reliably and as a calculatable partner, it will have to take some further steps on the basis of this pact, which may not be binding at all. Only the citizens of the country concerned can decide who lives on their territory. Not some pact or officials in Brussels through some mandatory quotas, but only citizens. And on this, I really keep my fingers crossed for Italy's current interior minister to say, "Enough is enough!"

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, if we were going to have a UN global compact on migration it should be one that sets out a plan to control immigration and protect the borders of nation-states. This global compact does entirely the opposite. Genuine migrants are people who have legitimately applied to migrate to another country from their own country under the immigration laws of the country to which they want to migrate. People who force their entry into a country are not migrants: they are illegal migrants. This compact wants to solve the problem of illegal immigration by making it legal, thereby encouraging even more immigration into Europe. It wants to decriminalise so-called humanitarian assistance to illegal migrants, so that aiding and abetting an illegal act will become legal. The whole process of illegal migrants gaining entry to a country and their processing will be made simpler and it will be made almost impossible to deport them. Not only that, if anyone is bold enough to criticise these policies it seeks to criminalise that dissent by means of so-called hate speech and xenophobia laws. This compact is a plan to increase the mass importation into Europe of millions upon millions of people from non-Christian cultures in Africa, the Middle East and beyond. It would eventually make Europeans minorities in their own lands and change Europe and its cultures into something else entirely. If you want to know what that looks like, you only have to look at Germany, Sweden, parts of the United Kingdom and many other places. Several European countries have already said they will reject this compact. To prevent it becoming a reality, the leaders of the European nations will have to vote against it in the Council.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF).
text: Mr President, in March 2000, the United Nations was already advocating the entry of 159 million immigrants into Europe by 2025. Today, the United Nations wants to impose its global pact on migration. Although we are told that this text is not binding, it is actually intended to enshrine a so-called right to migration. Presented as a new human right, it would induce new duties for the signatory countries, in the name of a misguided charity that put others before our own. I see this as an odious moral blackmail that goes through the guilt of Western nations, because they are obviously the targets and not, for example, the wealthy Saudi Arabia, which does not accept any migrants but to whom the United Nations has entrusted its Human Rights Council. Donald Trump's United States is the first nation to withdraw from this scandalous UN pact. Many others also refuse it: Australia, Hungary, Austria, Poland, the Czech Republic, Croatia and now Bulgaria. In Europe, at this rate, it will be only Macron and Merkel who want to sign this text again. But Merkel's days are numbered. It was she who divided Europe by her unilateral decision to open the borders. For my part, I believe in the collective rights of peoples to self-determination and, first of all, to remain themselves. Is that not how all decolonization movements were justified in the fifties, sixties or seventies? Why, then, would these rights be denied today to the peoples of Europe who are undergoing a new form of colonization?

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
