text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has First of all, I would like to say that one can disagree, but one should stick to the truth. And here I have to say to my colleague, Mrs Goel, that your speech was a national position and not the position of the European People's Party or the European Parliament. And I have to say to Mr Vilimsky that Austria has not left, but will abstain, although I regret that. But that is not the same thing. This pact is co-negotiated by us, is a success of the European Union and is in our interest. As the European Parliament held in a vote on 18 April – by 516 votes in favour, 137 against and 43 abstentions. By a 75% majority, we have said that we strongly support the development of a global governance system to strengthen coordination in international migration, human mobility and refugee movements. And we have called on all Member States to pull together. This has not happened, and that shows the problem. That is why Chancellor Merkel was today opposed to unanimity on foreign policy: because we have unanimity, we have weakened ourselves as negotiating partners in the United Nations. Therefore: no to unanimity, yes to the European Union's ability to act. And we must ensure that there is a uniform European regulation. And I have to say that the Council of Foreign Ministers has failed here, where coordination within the Member States has failed. And I ask that this issue be included on the agenda of the Council of Foreign Ministers of Heads of State or Government and that we make the single European migration package operational.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the European Parliament – and I want to mirror what the Commissioner said – voted for the global compact and supports it as strongly as the Commission is supporting it. Because we didn’t just come up with this compact, we had meetings with the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), the Holy See, the International Organisation for Migration (IOM) and with national parliaments. Huge amounts of work and resources went into this, and I say to everyone who is trying to characterise this in a particular way that it is not legally binding, it doesn’t promote a human right to migrate, it does not threaten national sovereignty and it does not conflate migration with asylum. There are two global compacts. But it does establish something called multilateralism, and everyone in this Parliament, even those who want to isolate or who want to limit migration in any way, should understand the realities of partnerships with sending countries, the realities of refugee and asylum flows and all the talk about these things – which by the way the Austrian Presidency is dealing with in these six months are a reality – and must have principles with other countries to cope with. If the previous speaker, Mr Karas is correct, I would say to the Austrian Presidency, why have a situation in the final days of a Presidency when at least a quarter of your files are on the question here that we are talking about? Why, why even attempt to pull out and show no leadership to other countries? There is no common Council position on this, but you know what you’re doing? You’re sending a lack of leadership signal on a question of multilateralism, a partnership with other countries. This is something that will only promote a negative and inaccurate portrayal of something which is a multilateral tool that we need. I’m not going to repeat what the Commissioner said, but he said something which we can all agree with, even those who want to restrict migration, because we will need principles and when we need them most we will call on this global compact and then it may be too late, because we have the lack of leadership shown in this presidency.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, nowadays we are living in a world in which migration simultaneously is a global phenomenon. Therefore the world desperately needs a global intergovernmental instrument to effectively manage global migration and for displacement influx. Of the war’s refugee crisis since the second World War, I warmly welcome the UN’s ambition and initiative to establish the Global Compact for Safe, Orderly and Regular Migration. I believe that this will be a not only effective but also balanced framework through which international society can work together in order to manage and control migration in all countries involved – through origin, transit and destination alike. Unfortunately, some EU Member States – including my country, Bulgaria – with populists and extreme nationalists in power want to reject them, but I am glad that in general the EU shows a strong support for the process for GCM and is committed to making it a success. We need to find a constructive approach.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, after Belgium signed the Marrakesh political declaration in May of this year, with Prime Minister Jambon and Secretary of State for Migration Francken, Belgium is now threatening to travel again to Marrakesh. This time to sign this Global Compact for Migration.  This text is as disastrous as the Geneva Convention. International agreements, conventions and treaties all have one characteristic in common: they are the product of foreign diplomats and politicians. They are written above the heads of the people and the consequences are imposed behind the people's backs. For this reason, migration is only exceptionally a theme where free nations are allowed to surrender their powers. Under active pressure from my party, the Flemish Interest, Belgium's decision was postponed. I call on the Belgian Government not to sign this United Nations migration pact here either.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the When Donald Trump announced the US withdrawal from the Global Migration Compact last December, it was dismissed as an eccentric ride. However, one could bet that the imitator would find. It was not really surprising that six months later it was Hungary of all places, since it is part of Viktor Orban's political business model to create anti-migrant sentiment in order to distract from his own problems. A non-binding Declaration of Intent by the United Nations has been reinterpreted as a commitment under international law and elevated to the threat of national sovereignty and placed in the context of systematically spread conspiracy theories, such as that certain circles deliberately want to weaken Europe through planned immigration. In the aftermath of these topos, the conspiracy-theoretical International enthusiastically picked up and reinterpreted. A Compact for Safe, Orderly and Regular Migration became a pact for safe, regulated and scheduled migration. Everything somehow known and not unfamiliar. It was surprising that a few weeks ago the Austrian Government, which was involved in the negotiations, suddenly took over this spin and announced that it would not sign the pact, which, moreover, is not envisaged at all.  This is regrettable, because Austria, a hitherto reliable international partner, has now also said goodbye to the fantasy land of symbolism – politics. Unfortunately, this does not solve the problems.

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it was truly prophetic, years ago, to publish his pamphlet entitled the "Éloge des frontières" Régis Debray, which I do not think anyone will want to accuse of being like us, fascist, racist, xenophobic, a great fighter of freedom, because the rationale of this pact is precisely the abolition of borders, in order to realize the globalist demographic plan that dates back even to the 1920s with the SDN – the Society of Nations – , for a redistribution of the world's population. One plan, we don't talk about plots here, we talk about what we see. You only have to read the 23 points of this plan to see how binding there is, over and above the velvety statement to say that nothing is imposed on anyone. There is something very worrying about this fixation on promoting migration, namely the uprooting of the peoples against whom a man of freedom such as Régis Debray fought, not by chance engaged in this great battle.  If you want to achieve, through this pact, legal highways for irregular immigration and the transhumance of slave gods necessary for the last stage of financial neo-capitalism, we say congratulations gentlemen of the left, betray the peoples, you want the uprooting of peoples. You are the enemies of the people!

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the adoption of the World Pact on Migration represents an historic opportunity, because only with everyone's consent could we develop inclusive migration policies that respect the human rights of all, migrants and refugees. Yet this unanimity that would allow the World Pact to function as well as possible is being called into question by some populist countries who think they are freeing themselves by sabotaging it with the threat of dragging themselves behind other countries. Their pretext for safeguarding national sovereignty does not hold water, because we know full well that sovereignty will never be called into question by a non-legally binding pact. Those who act according to this logic completely lose sight of a fundamental concept: no country alone will ever be able to grasp the challenges and opportunities of this phenomenon. As has already been voted on by this House in its resolution on the holistic approach to migration, people's rights and dignity must be put at the heart of our policies. Only in this way can we facilitate ordinary and regular safe migration, in the interests of the entire national community.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF).
text: Mr President, the UN Global Compact for Safe, Orderly and Regular Migration is a draft international agreement that must be combated. If it simply asked states to respect the human rights of migrants, it could be accepted, but it goes far beyond that. It is a text that yields to a mad immigrationist. It states at its point 10) that migration is an integral part of globalization and infers from it at its point 11) that it is necessary, I quote, to "facilitate them". In fact, it wants to create channels of legal migration on the basis of the assumption, expressly taken up by the European Parliament's resolution of 18 April 2018, that migration is necessarily beneficial for host countries. On the contrary, I believe that mass migration is a scourge that destabilizes the host countries and I congratulate the courageous States that have decided to reject this disastrous global pact. Congratulations to the United States, Hungary, Austria, the Czech Republic, Croatia, Poland and Bulgaria!

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The withdrawal of Austria and the other governments involved in the migration pact is wrong, dangerous and small-minded. Global joint action is being jeopardised for purely populist purposes. Austria is a UN location and Austria holds the Presidency. This means taking responsibility instead of always having cheap domestic political debates. It is incomprehensible that Chancellor Kurz can be dispersed here by the FPÖ, by Vice-Chancellor Strache in front of the carts, thereby putting Austria's international reputation at risk. The pact offers minimum global standards, and it is another step towards bringing order to chaos. Working on safe and orderly immigration together with all countries is a historic compromise. It is therefore a question of principles that cannot be called into question and of joint decisions by the United Nations to meet one of the greatest challenges on a global high.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D).
text: – Mr President, moving towards orderly management of emigration is a matter of wisdom and dignity. Sensible, because it's a phenomenon that's going to live with us. There is no illusions about this agreement: migration will exist as long as there is deep inequality and as long as there is exclusion in the world. And of dignity, since, since there will be migration, we must respect the human rights of all who undertake it. We do a skinny favor by not going together, projecting an image of division within the Union. But I have to tell the Austrian Presidency, in a very clear way: Austria has taken sides as a country against the agreement, but it cannot take sides as The Presidency of the Union, because most of us are in favour of the agreement. If he cannot represent us, he resigns, and is replaced by a third party in the representation of the Marrakesh meeting.

name: President. –
text: For the record, Mr Karas mentioned that they abstained, but that is a different story.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Commissioner, I am very glad that, after the final text was approved by the governments in July, we are actually getting to this debate. I think that this is the first time we have commented on this in the final text.  I would like to thank you for your statement that this is not a legally binding document, I think that the hysteria that has arisen around this is indeed inadequate. What I think would be important to stress is that the status of refugees is confirmed in this global pact, which, however, differs from those of illegal, economic migrants. I have a number of positive goals in the global pact, he contains about twenty-three of them, including close border surveillance, the obligation to prove his identity, and so on. On the other hand, I think it is the Council's fault that it did not act in a united way, the strength and weight of the European Community would be much greater if the Council and the Member States were united. And secondly, the final text, I think that in many places, on the contrary, it also confuses the distinction between refugees, proper, wanted, managed migration and the illegal one. I think that is a fundamental rebuy to this document.

name: Elly Schlein (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, when we were in New York with some of our colleagues for the first UN summit on refugees and migrants, the parade of European Heads of State or Government filled their mouths with good intentions, except then, when it came to moving from words to deeds, they paraded.  Austria's decision to pull itself out of the Global Compact is extremely serious, all the more so since these are not binding agreements. So this is a move of pure propaganda, which aims to create an international anti-migrant front. However, I agree with what my colleague Guerrero Salom said, and then he suspends himself, because he is unable to represent the Council because he is in the Presidency today, he is not in a position to represent a strong voice of the European Union.  These are acts that the rest of the Union must strongly condemn, because they incredibly weaken the Union's position. This is a challenge, that of migration, which is clearly European and global and which requires responses based on solidarity and fair sharing of responsibilities among all.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the new order aims to redistribute populations, rather than to redistribute the wealth generated. It therefore creates a reserve army which, through immigration, will go to developed countries in order to have a reduction in wages. Refugees are one thing and migrants are another, and there is international legislation on this. In practice, we are being led to the abolition of the right of Member States and States in general to determine which populations will reside on their territory, because a right of immigration is created. Some say the Pact is not legally binding. Then why are you anxious if a state doesn't sign it? Secondly, you say there is protection of national sovereignty. Does not the non-signature of the Pact fall within the framework of the national sovereignty of a State? You contradict those who support this Pact because, in practice, it is an indirect way to legalise illegal immigration.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, 70 000 years ago, I think, Homo sapiens started from Africa and met Neanderthals somewhere in Europe and that is why we have 5% of genes from Neanderthals. I think they didn’t have a migration compact, that was the problem! I don’t understand the people who are shouting against the efforts of the United Nations – which is a forum for global governance – to organise the global response to geographical, climate—change, economic and other realities. By the way, the Geneva Conventions were written after the Second World War in response to the shock of what Europeans could do to one another, and they are unlikely to be up-to-date in terms of dealing with global migration flows. So I don’t see why we should be against the United Nations’ effort to organise a response to this problem.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Mr President, the Global Pact on Migration is yet another utopian, but also cunning, approach by a certain circle of the European Union to a very serious issue. While the wounds created in Europe by the invasion of millions of legal and – above all – illegal immigrants are still fresh, there are some who dream of global cooperation to supposedly tackle the problem of migration. I will not be tempted to analyse the text, because this is more literary in nature. Nor will I force myself to accept the choice between evil and the worst, as the Commissioner said earlier. As a Greek MEP, whose compatriots are fighting to ensure that their cultural, racial, ethnic and religious identity is not destroyed by illegal immigration, I will do everything in my power and what is necessary so that this obsessive and destructive effort by the European Union does not succeed.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, dar ndóigh is fadhb mhór í sa lá atá inniu ann fadhb na n-imirceach ach, mar a dúirt an tUasal Turcanu ní fadhb nua í.  I ndáiríre, ó thús ama, bhí fonn taistil ar an gcine daonna ar chúis amháin nó ar chúis éigin.   Ach is fadhb i bhfad níos casta í sa lá atá inniu ann, mar a lán de na daoine atá ag teacht go dtí an Eoraip ach go háirithe, tá siad ag teacht de bharr cogadh, easaontas agus míchothromaíocht ina dtíortha féin.  Dá bhrí sin, tá sé de dhualgas orainn mar a dúirt Angela Merkel inniu, cabhrú leo chomh maith agus is féidir linn.   Agus má dhéanann gach uile thír a cuid beidh sé níos féaráilte do chuile thír.  Freisin, caithfimid brú a chur ar na Náisiúin Aontaithe, brú a chur ar na tríú tíortha a gcuid féin a dhéanamh chomh maith, sa tslí sin is féidir linn cabhrú leo agus réiteach a fháil ar an bhfadhb seo.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the Austrian Presidency, the unilateral decision taken by some Member States to withdraw from the Global Compact, both on migration and refugees, is an incomprehensible decision, but above all it is harmful, detrimental to the interests of the Union, which is what it is all about. The Presidency is here representing the Union. We, as the European Parliament, represent a common vision that is steeped in meaning, when it comes to ordering migration flows. Because precisely, the Global Compact is not intended to encourage or stop the fact of migration, but to order it, to offer it some rationality, wisdom, some dignity to the migratory fact, and it requires a common response from the European Union. It is therefore deeply damaging and harmful to the interests of the Union that is being attempted to curb the effort that from the United Nations requires of a global actor called Europe. I therefore ask the Presidency to consider its position or resign from its presidency at the Marrakesh Summit.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Dear Chairman, in the history of mankind we have had various kinds of mass migrations, from the peaceful settlement of unoleased areas, through planning colonization to bloody contingebilizing campaigns.  What distinguishes today's times from past ones is the existence of a strictly defined international order and rules that must not be broken, and current migration waves in Europe and America are openly violating them.  To be more successful in tackling illegal migration, it is obvious that we need a new global framework for legal migration, devoid of all ideology, operational and widely accepted. The UN's Global Compact on Migration is not by rejecting it by the United States and more and more EU members. When creating documents like this, we need to stick to what we all agree on, not push a political agenda that brings divisions. Without unanimous support, this and similar agreements really don't make sense.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this has really been a very useful exchange, and I thank my dear colleagues for their interventions. But I take this opportunity to say something very concrete: from this debate I conclude that we all share a common interest in finding common solutions to global challenges such as migration, and the Global Compact is the definition of a common solution, because it is a global response; it is a global solution. I think the Global Compact will definitely help us to manage human mobility in a much more orderly and effective way. And in particular for Europe – because for us, as Europeans, the problem of migration is so important, because all neighbours around us want to come to Europe. So this is the best way; this is the best instrument to deal with mobility and to have a sort of good argument to advocate for a global solution. This is my strong conviction.  I close by signalling once again my appreciation of the European Parliament’s role in keeping this important issue on the agenda. I think it is not necessary to repeat my arguments from my first intervention.

name: Karoline Edtstadler
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, dear Commissioner, I consider the discussion we had as very useful and I would like to thank you for sharing your thoughts and also your concerns very openly. To conclude I would only like to recall one thing, and it was mentioned by some of you: there is no common position of the EU as such.

name: Președintele. –
text: The debate has been closed.

name: Președintele. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report of Mr Juan Fernando López Aguilar, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, containing recommendations to the Committee on Humanitarian Visas (2017/2270(INL)) (A8-0328/0000).

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner, 90% of human beings who have come to the European Union in demand for asylum and have managed to bring their demand together have done so by arriving irregularly. The reason is very simple, and it is that they were not given any opportunity to do so regularly. There was no option, no legal means of secure access; so those who got it are the survivors of a terrible adventure, in which they risked everything and often lost it. They risked the lives and loved ones' lives and often lost it. Thirty thousand deaths in the Mediterranean. And time and time again that we have discussed this chilling fact in the European Parliament, we have filled our mouths with the word 'shame', urging the Commission and the Council with an answer. But this Parliament is prepared to support that response, to promote that response. And this legislative initiative of the European Parliament is part of the response. It is an attempt to open a legal route for asylum and asylum seekers, or some form of humanitarian protection, to go in their countries of origin or transit to a consulate or embassy of the European Union and legitimately raise their claim for regular access to the European Union, without having to expose themselves to mafias dealing with people , to networks of illicit trafficking and exploitation of human beings, which systematically violate fundamental rights and are enramed with the most vulnerable: defenceless women and children. This humanitarian response is part of the European Parliament's sustained demand. We have signed it and voted for by large majorities in this European Parliament time and time again in our most significant resolutions. That of 12 April 2016, a Resolution calling for a holistic approach, i.e. comprehensive of all elements of the migratory event and the demand for asylum and refuge, in compliance with European law, which mandates common responsibility and shared management of external borders, migration flows and asylum claims. As long as this common European asylum system arrives, we will do the right thing by supporting an initiative which calls on the Commission to take the necessary measures to provide this common European regulatory framework to the Member States, which allows them to cover the possibility, in an orderly manner, of opening the legal door that has been demanding on us for years the whole of non-governmental organisations , humanitarian associations, legal experts, bar associations and even churches, which ask the European Union to live up to its promise and to do something to overcome divorce, which is terrible and regrettable, among its promise, among the ambitions proclaimed in the letter of its Treaties — and particularly in the area of freedom, justice and security — and what has been its performance to date. Therefore, ladies and gentlemen, I am asking for support tomorrow for this legislative initiative which aims to open a legal avenue, a legal channel, through this humanitarian visa instrument for potential asylum seekers and persons required of humanitarian protection. That they can do it legally without losing their lives in their efforts.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission has been carefully following the work on the report on European humanitarian visas, prepared by the rapporteur, Mr López Aguilar. We take note of the calls on the Commission to make a proposal on a European humanitarian visa by the end of March 2019. We also believe that in order to better manage migration comprehensively, we need to enhance legal and safe avenues to the EU for third-country nationals in need of international protection.  Increasing resettlement from Turkey or Niger is part of the solution to engaging with third countries and reducing irregular arrivals. At the same time, we believe that the greatest potential for reaching this common objective lies, at this point in time, in the swift adoption of the Union Resettlement Framework Regulation proposed by the Commission in July 2016. It will be the first legislative instrument of its kind to better coordinate Member States’ resettlement efforts, which until now have been the result of a combination of national or international programmes.  I commend the efforts of Parliament that have contributed greatly towards reaching a common position within the Council. But both co-legislators need to take the last steps to transform the preliminary agreement into the final adoption of the proposal. The Commission stands ready to provide all the support needed. We believe it is of utmost importance not to risk complicating the adoption of the Union Resettlement Framework Regulation, which now requires our full attention. It seems therefore appropriate that the Commission includes in the evaluation of the future Union Resettlement Framework Regulation an assessment of whether or not it covers, as intended, the main legal and safe avenues for international protection in the EU.

name: João Pimenta Lopes
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Equal Opportunities. – Mr President, I take the turn of my colleague Malin Björk, who cannot be here today. Approximately 90% of those receiving international protection in the European Union arrive by irregular means. Since 2000, 30 000 have been killed at border crossing; 17 000 in the Mediterranean, only since 2014. Around 1 000 kilometres of walls have been built in the EU. The European Union cannot take responsibility for the causes of this very serious humanitarian crisis. Instead of solidarity it imposes greater restrictions on the application for international protection. Asylum seekers are forced to risk their lives to get to safety by putting themselves in the hands of human trafficking networks. It is women, children and LGBT people who are most vulnerable at any stage of the migration process, have more difficulties in accessing protective instruments and are particularly subject to physical, psychological and sexual violence, how often dragged into networks of sexual exploitation and slave labor. Humanitarian visas, although insufficient, must materialise agile responses that ensure the mechanisms, structures and technical and human means necessary to protect those involved, with particular attention to the most vulnerable - women and children.

name: Heinz K. Becker
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to express my sincere thanks for the great commitment of the rapporteur. He has been following this project intensively for a long time, and we have also had constructive discussions, although we in the European People's Party have not enjoyed this dossier from the outset, just as the Council has already rejected the first versions of the Visa Code and the trialogue has failed because the humanitarian visa is not so easy to handle. Firstly, this humanitarian visa already exists in many Member States. Secondly, the rapporteur's proposal is problematic in that it allows access to EU territory without it being clear whether or not there is a right of asylum. And the third point is that the proposals on embassies and embassies could indeed massively overburden these institutions. Now the rapporteur has ensured that these recommendations are non-binding, not mandatory for the Member States. All that remains now is whether there is actually a change in the parallel negotiated visa code and whether the readmission of illegal migrants happens, yes or no. We don't have that yet. That is why I cannot promise my group's agreement at the moment.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to thank my colleague López Aguilar on behalf of the Group of the Party of European People's Party. We have just finished the debate on the Global Compact and the need, if not urgency, to create legal, orderly and safe ways of joining the European Union. Since the beginning of this parliamentary term, Parliament has not shirked its responsibilities. Already, with the resolution on the holistic approach, this House has strongly called for the use of humanitarian visas for those in need of international protection, calling on the Commission to make more specific provisions. The Committee on Civil Rights, Human Rights, Common Security and Security Policy reiterated this question by adopting the amendments on humanitarian visas within the Visa Code, which, as we know, sadly foundered as a result of the Council's refusal to proceed with the negotiations and the consequent withdrawal of the proposal. Now the Commission cannot back down. The march 2019 deadline should not be seen as an ultimatum, but on the contrary as a great opportunity to give a meaningful response to those who need international protection and succumb to achieving this right. Only an ambitious proposal will succeed in ensuring safe and legal channels and consolidating the foundations of a migration policy that revolves around people's rights and dignity.

name: Jussi Halla-aho
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the ECR Group does not support the idea of a humanitarian visa. The problem is that the asylum system is being abused on a massive scale as a channel of economic migration. The humanitarian visa would only make things worse. It would increase the overall number of applications and, as we have seen, it is very difficult to repatriate even those whose application has been rejected. There are many practical issues. Who exactly would be entitled to a humanitarian visa? How could we ensure that all Member States would apply the same criteria and that there would be no weak links as there are today? How could we prevent holders of humanitarian visas from disappearing in the Schengen area, and so on?

name: Bodil Valero
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The Mediterranean is deadlier than ever, according to the UNHCR report of 3 September this year. By the time the report was written, 1 600 people had so far lost their lives or were reported missing on the road to Europe during the year. The UNHCR claims that more people are now being killed, despite the fact that fewer are actually fleeing, and is calling on us to create more legal routes for refugees. One has to wonder what europe has done wrong when more people die on their way to Europe, even though fewer are actually fleeing. An argument in favour of the Turkey agreement, barbed wire fences at the EU's external borders and various other inventions to get people to opt out of Europe as a potential escape option was precisely that they would wait nicely in refugee camps outside, and then get to come legally here, but with no real prospect of coming legally. The result was new and more dangerous escape options, slave-like conditions in the Libyan desert, etc. In this House, we have been arguing for many years that humanitarian visas are needed to save human lives and break up the people smugglers' market, but the Council has totally refused. Instead, the Council's response to the problem is tighter monitoring of our borders and agreements with other countries to receive all those that the Member States wish to send back. The rapporteur, of course, has our green support tomorrow.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, this dossier on humanitarian visas is sadly representative of European developments on migration. Under pressure from the nationalists of the extreme right, European countries are dishonouring the values of hospitality, while our history, especially in the West, is nourished by movements of people fleeing poverty, persecution, pogroms and conflict. Fifty million Europeans migrated between the middle of the 19th century and the First World War, and this continued until the fall of the Berlin Wall. What about today? Europe hosts 6% of the world's refugees, or one refugee per 1,000 inhabitants. In Lebanon, refugees make up more than 25% of the population. And we are the ones who would welcome all the misery of the world? At least 37,000 people identified - and probably many more - have died in the Mediterranean. Most of them were asylum seekers. These people died due to a lack of regular routes due to a lack of humanitarian visas. Yes, I do! 90% of those granted international protection by states arrived irregularly, with the risks known. Resettlements, Commissioner, are not up to scratch, and that is not even the point. Some of those who govern us will one day be held accountable for their inadequacy in the face of this global refugee crisis. I would like to thank Mr. Lopez Aguilar for his tenacity. The report does not live up to my expectations. Member States refuse to discuss them on the grounds that these visas already exist at national level. However, we need European solidarity on this and other issues and we accept the mix as you have invited us, Commissioner.

name: Laura Ferrara
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ensuring legal avenues of access to the European Union for those entitled to international protection is the first step in combating human traffickers and overcoming the greatest contradiction we have in the European Union today, which is to combat illegal immigration without offering a legal alternative. A visa system that does not lend itself to abuse and allows access to European territory in order to apply for asylum would help to create the conditions for unhinged the business of smugglers and traffickers, also to increase the security of the countries of destination and ultimately to have a more orderly and dignified management of migratory flows. Such a system would be a bold and coherent step taken by the European Union to live up to the values on which it is founded and would meet the frontline countries, such as Italy and Greece, which are often used as countries of entry and transit, but where they are then forced to stay because of the failed Dublin Regulation.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I think that having a system for additional humanitarian visas across Member States is a good idea and should be welcomed. A number of requests for the establishment of such a system have been made and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) has duly adopted the own initiative report containing these recommendations after long negotiations. However, the provision of safe and legal pathways on a Union—wide basis for entry into European territory has yet to occur. Currently humanitarian visas are governed by the national law of Member States and there is no Union—wide obligation in place. This situation leads to high human social and economic costs. We are all aware of the effects of the migrant crisis, both in terms of the deaths caused and the strain on budgetary requirements for search and rescue operations and asylum procedures. Faced with a death toll of 30 000 migrants on European borders since 2000, Parliament has rightfully decided to proceed despite the Commission’s reluctance. The humanitarian visa framework is a good mechanism to reduce the death toll and combat smuggling, particularly since 90% of migrants enter Union territory through irregular means. However, the report still leaves enough autonomy with the Member State to decide on the categories of persons that will be involved in the visa system.  The EU must stand by its treaty obligations and its human rights commitments in respect of guaranteeing the right of asylum. I think this is a good proposal worthy of consideration.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I have only a technical note. Colleagues are not here because there is also a vote on the TERR Special Committee. And unfortunately, the vote, voted on by 2,000 amendments, will end in five minutes. Then I'd like to ask you all if your colleagues can get off here when they get here. Commissioner, I would like to say on this issue that we all know that the European Union has failed to respond effectively to the migration crisis. We have not managed to manage the uncontrolled number of migrants and refugees who have often arrived in the European Union without documents and proper screening. In 2015, I repeatedly visited both refugee camps in Greece and Italy, as well as on my way through the Balkans. It has been seen that the European Union cannot effectively recognise who has the right to asylum and who does not. After third-country nationals were allowed into the European Union, all those who had a so-called Syrian passport at the time, even though the Syrian passport may have been forged, were considered refugees. This situation must not be repeated. Humanitarian visas were supposed to be the instrument by which we were supposed to respond to the whole crisis. I think this idea is very good, but unfortunately we stayed halfway again. This idea needs to be reworked and worked out.

name: Elly Schlein (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking my colleague Juan Fernando López Aguilar for the passion and determination with which he has been fighting this just battle for years. Nationalists across Europe tell us that we cannot take in all migrants and that only those who arrive legally can remain on EU territory. They lie knowing they're lying. There are very few legal channels for access to the European Union, and the lack of safe routes for those seeking protection in Europe is the greatest shortcoming of our migration policies.  There are not many ways to prevent deaths at sea or in the desert, but also to combat – because this seems to be the obsession of European governments – human traffickers, to destroy their business, as they say. There is only one way and that is to create a legal alternative, legal and safe routes for access to Europe. That is why Parliament, even in the face of the Council's reluctance, is finally putting this proposal for a European humanitarian visa on the table. And I very much hope that you will find the vast majority of this House in support.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – Mr President, Salmen Abedi was a European citizen of Libyan descent who committed a suicide attack at a concert in Manchester last May. The act of terrorism claimed 22 lives and injured 139, largely juveniles and children. He had previously been to Syria and returned to Europe with the help of the British Royal Navy during a rescue mission. Its monitoring by British intelligence services on suspicion of being linked to ISIS was suspended a month before the Manchester attack. If this speedy rescue attempt has led to so much misfortune, and I also have evidence that more than 88 000 Schengen and health visas have been issued to Libyan citizens by Malta, why are we thinking of introducing another 'travel document' that will allow people to enter the European area without a thorough assessment of their application? This proposal is dangerous, unnecessary and built on very poor legal bases. This will result in an even greater overload of the system by thousands of applications.

name: Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Monday last week was a tragic day off the coast of Andalusia, my region. The Atlantic coast of Cadiz (in Los Caños de Meca, a beach where I am usually located) was an open grave for nineteen immigrants, who died there. They went on a patera forty people—eleven minors—without knowing how to swim, without life jackets. That same Monday, in Melilla, thirteen immigrants lost their lives. The Civil Guard and Maritime Rescue redouble their efforts, but it is difficult to save those who enter thousands through the western Mediterranean. 90% of asylum seekers arrive irregularly; many of them are unaccompanied minors, pregnant, raped women, who are forced to prostitute themselves to pay for the trip. Europe needs to stop the human market. Europe needs a short- and medium-term strategy on immigration. If there are no legal options, they will keep coming, they will be victims of human trafficking, the traffickers are the ones who will take advantage of it. Legal options, such as a well-applied humanitarian visa, must be given to them, because this will ensure legal transit in the Member States, control whoever enters Europe and check the background, in case there are security problems. Europe has to be true to its values. Solidarity and responsibility are two sides of the same coin.

name: Innocenzo Leontini (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, until now, the issue of humanitarian visas has been discussed at length in the context of the European Union, but without achieving concrete results. That is why, in the face of the European Commission's inaction, Parliament has decided to proceed with the drafting of this legislative initiative report, which calls on the Commission to submit a proposal for a regulation by 31 March 2019.  The shared objective is to lay down common provisions on procedures and to specify under what conditions each Member State must make the possibility of issuing a European humanitarian visa conditional on persons in need of protection. In this way, persons in need of protection may enter the territory of the Member State which issued the humanitarian visa for the sole purpose of submitting an application for international protection in that State.  It is currently estimated that 90 % of those who have obtained international protection have reached the Union illegally. In addition, the estimated cost of irregular crossings in terms of human lives has been at least 30 000 deaths at the Borders of the European Union since the beginning of 2000. For these reasons, too, safe and legal routes to Europe are needed.  I firmly believe that humanitarian visas are an excellent means of dealing with the intolerable death toll in the Mediterranean, of genuinely combating trafficking in human beings and of managing the legal arrival, dignified reception and fair treatment of asylum applications.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Dear Chairman, persons who are exposed in their home countries to the risks of prosecution or serious harm deserve the highest degree of protection. Also, in the context of mass migration and attempts to cross the borders of the European Union, it is necessary to ensure the safe and faster entry of persons who can indeed prove their claims. The introduction of a humanitarian visa could be an appropriate solution, of course, provided that entry is made possible solely for the application for international protection in the issuing Country.  However, I believe that the financial burden resulting from such proceedings should be borne solely by the issuing States and by no means by the Union budget. I am against the harmonisation of EU law, as I believe that the issue of migration and visas should be the primary competence of the individual Member States of the Union, since each of them knows its own specific conditions and possibilities at the given moment.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, in the context of humanitarian visas, I consider it essential to emphasise one thing. In accordance with the judgment of the Court of Justice, Member States are not obliged under European Union law to issue humanitarian visas, but are free to do so on the basis of their national law.  So we are not talking now about any mandatory mechanism, but about the possibility for individual Member States to analyse who is really a humanitarian refugee and who has just seized the opportunity to improve. This principle of volunteering is refreshing and acceptable after years of embarrassing remings of mandatory quotas. The Czech Republic must determine for itself to whom it will give a visa and allow it to enter the country. Refugees must no longer support organised crime run by smugglers and must not forcibly wire across Europe's borders. They should apply for a humanitarian visa in the nearest safe state and wait for the decision of a sovereign state of a Member State of the European Union.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, let us point out once again that immigration is not a natural phenomenon. It is caused by poverty, which is also not a natural phenomenon. So we have to tackle poverty to stop immigration and - above all - illegal immigration. Refugees come because there are wars. Let us fight for peace in order to limit the number of refugees. Greece is under enormous pressure, with thousands of refugees and illegal immigrants. All of them take advantage of the process that exists, abuse the right to asylum and remain in Greece for at least three years until their asylum case is heard. Let us not forget that the Court of Justice, in its judgment in Case C-386/16, pointed out that the granting of humanitarian visas is a possibility for states and not an obligation. Indeed, there is a very important example where Christians from Aleppo had gone to Belgium and applied for humanitarian visas. You realize, then, that we must not simply create a new incentive, in which wealthy illegal immigrants will pass for supposed humanitarian reasons into Europe, while poor illegal immigrants will simply attempt to cross illegally.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this is a really interesting debate. I note that we share the same objective: to provide legal pathways to persons in need of international protection. For this, we need to adopt our proposal to set up a European resettlement framework, as part of the overall reform of the Common European Asylum System. These legislative proposals need to be adopted as a matter of priority. Let me reiterate the Commission’s continued readiness to support the co-legislators with a view to achieving a reform of the Common European Asylum System and, in particular, the swift adoption of the Union Resettlement Framework Regulation.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner, I am very grateful for the interventions, opinions and, in particular, those which have advanced the will to support the initiative on behalf of the respective parliamentary groups of this European Parliament. But I would like to add some consideration, because, first of all, I have heard objections which seek to dilute the evidence that, although some Member States have exemplary practices and legislation in this regard, others do not. And the important thing is that there is no European framework. There is no common European framework that can set out the possibility that, in consulates and embassies, humanitarian visas can be issued to allow such legal entry to those who are going to risk it anyway and lose everything in their efforts. Hannah Arendt, a memorable philosopher of the 20th century, spoke to us that it is as important as having rights or more the right to exercise rights. It's the right to have the right. And there is no point in a right to asylum if, in order to be able to exercise it on European territory , which recognises it in its Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, and obviously does not recognise It to Europeans but to the desperate of third countries — they must risk their lives or lose it in the attempt. It's an unsustainable situation. We have denounced it many times and, worst of all, we have heard how we are denounced by all the partners who have been heard in this European Parliament for years: non-governmental organisations, legal professions, human rights activists. It's about time we answered. It's not true that it incentivizes the business of exploiting people. On the contrary, dismantle part of the so-called business model, part of the so-called "business model" of mafias. Because it offers some people, who will otherwise throw themselves into the arms of these illicit trafficking, an opportunity to try without risk and to submit to the humiliation or exploitation of such illicit trafficking that brutally and unscrupulously violates the fundamental rights of the most vulnerable: women and children. We have missed them so many times in our speeches in the European Parliament. It's about time we did something. And for that reason, I am particularly grateful for the voices I have heard from the People's Group, because they denies that the People's Group does not have a sensitivity to this issue — as I heard in the first shift from the Group, which concerns me — and I am grateful that we are able to live up to this long-oversighted challenge by building the majority needed to tell the Commission that it is time for it to incorporate into the puzzle of the without simplification, also this tool. The migratory fact is complex, insorcible, global. It's there to stay and none of the tools can be worth it alone. Resettlement is a valid programme, endorsed by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, but has its subjective, quantitative and country of origin limitations. It is also a question of accompanying resettlement with this instrument, in addition to this approach, which we wanted holistic, that includes the so-called 'migratory event' in the countries of origin, in the transit countries and in the countries of destination. But above all, allow people who feel desperate, persecuted, with their security, their dignity and integrity threatened imminently, to approach a friendly window: that of delegations abroad of the European Union, knowing that the European Union lives up to its promise, its commitment to the fundamental rights of the most vulnerable people. I therefore call tomorrow for the effort to bring the vote closer to this initiative, which is a call on the Commission to provide the regulatory instrument we need.

name: Președintele. –
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 14 November 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. - Mr President, I would like to thank the European The report initiating the introduction of humanitarian visas would allow third-country immigrants to Europe to obtain visas in an accelerated and simplified procedure at delegations outside the European Union. Quite astonishingly, this entry permit would be granted without a thorough and careful examination of the identity of immigrants and their eligibility for refugee status. By adopting this report, the UNION would in fact waive the right of prior control, circumvent border protection and the rights of national authorities in immigration and asylum matters. The proposal shows that the European Parliament has come up with a new idea that is without any common sense and wants to bring it to the Union instead of solving the problem. The brussels effort to turn Europe into an immigrant zone by taking in as many refugees as possible is completely unacceptable, and I therefore believe that the proposal we are discussing must be rejected in the strongest possible way.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. – Showing no sign of sobriety, the EP has come up with an initiative to bring the masses of migrants to Europe through so-called humanitarian visas. The European Parliament's proposal for a humanitarian visa is in order to allow migrants to enter the European Union through a visa at EU consulates before continuing the asylum procedure against them. This is problematic in many ways. On the one hand, it would give all illegal migrants visas to enter Europe without comprehensive security checks. This would move the migration problem to Europe. On the other hand, tens of thousands of people would flood the consulates of EU Member States, for which our consulates are not prepared in any way. Once again, this is a proposal that is out of reality and imports it into the Union instead of remedying the problem. Therefore, this proposal is unacceptable to us.

name: Dietmar Köster (S&D)
text: Writing. – There is currently virtually no way for people on the run to enter an EU country legally. They are therefore forced to pay smugglers and risk their lives on dangerous escape routes. Thousands die every year in the Sahara, the Mediterranean and elsewhere. We must finally create legal routes of entry into the EU. One option is humanitarian visas. This demand has already been expressed by the European Parliament in several resolutions. The EU is based on the principle of respect for human dignity and is based on humanitarian values. These values must also apply to non-EU citizens. It is therefore essential for us MEPs to vote in favour of Parliament's own-initiative report, because humanitarian visas help to make refugees safer. This would be an important step towards meeting our own demands for respect for human dignity.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. – The European Parliament asks the Commission to present a legislative proposal on European humanitarian visas by March 2019. Today, different national arrangements and procedures apply in the Member States. The common legislative arrangements shall set a minimum range of common standards for the issue, issue and administration of humanitarian visas. Unified practices will support a coordinated Union policy and eliminate organised crime in smuggling. Humanitarian visas should only affect persons seeking international legal protection because of exposure to torture or other inhuman and degrading treatment. Humanitarian visas should be issued as a single sticker registered in the Visa Information System. They should allow holders to enter the territory of the Member State which issued them solely for the purpose of applying for international protection in that Member State. The issue of humanitarian visas may not automatically apply to family members of applicants. They may, after consideration, be subject to asylum policy with regard to the national rules of the Member States. I therefore consider it important that the future regulation carefully defines humanitarian visas and respects the separation of humanitarian visas from other asylum visas, which must continue to take into account the rules of the Member States.

name: Christine Revault d’Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. If the Member States have given in to the populist rhetoric about refugees and if part of this Parliament rejects the inclusion of migrants in our societies, I will defend a completely different vision. These people are only seeking protection and a better life in times of war and conflict. But to do so, they risk their lives on the asylum route and in the Mediterranean and call on smugglers who are nothing but human traffickers. They risk exploitation, abuse and abuse. Everyone remembers the images of thirsty and hungry children in Libya. This situation is inhumane and absurd, because at this stage European law has no provision to remedy it. That is why I am calling for a European humanitarian visa that would allow migrants to travel safely and to fight definitively against the abject trafficking of smugglers who are enriched by the absence of legal channels. I call on all MEPs to vote on this report, in order to formally call on the Commission to legislate on this matter before March 2019.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D)
text: Writing. – With the important legislative own-initiative report, we call on the Commission, on the basis of Article 77(2)(a) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), to submit a legislative proposal for a regulation on 'creating a European visa on humanitarian grounds' by 31 March 2019. The aim is to provide a legal basis for Member States to issue A European visa on humanitarian grounds to persons seeking international protection. Humanitarian visas are an important and long overdue addition. It should long have been possible to apply for international protection on the spot (e.g. at embassies). This is not romantic, but reasonable. In doing so, we are satisinuating our responsibility as legislators to find pragmatic solutions.
